> I'm sorry if you took it that way. It wasn't
> intended that way. I was simply pointing out that
> UIDs are (to my knowledge, which has been known to
> be in error before) always stored, and the OS does
> the translation. 
> 
> We all make mistakes, and sometimes, someone knows
> more than either of us. :)

... Combined.

No problem. Hehe, that's why I pointed out that I use
tar to keep permissions. It actually does store the
user name and group name of the files in archives (not
UID and GID), and you can use the --same-owner and an
other couple of flags to extract the files exactly as
they were on the system that tarred it. Thus making
lots of fun is the user doesn't exist on your system.

Peace,
Vincent Damewood

Russell,

checking for GLIB - version >= 2.0.0... 
*** 'pkg-config --modversion glib-2.0' returned 2.2.1, but GLIB (2.0.4)
*** was found! If pkg-config was correct, then it is best
*** to remove the old version of GLib. You may also be able to fix the error
*** by modifying your LD_LIBRARY_PATH enviroment variable, or by editing
*** /etc/ld.so.conf. Make sure you have run ldconfig if that is
*** required on your system.
*** If pkg-config was wrong, set the environment variable PKG_CONFIG_PATH
*** to point to the correct configuration files no configure: error:
*** GLIB 2.0.0 or better is required. The latest version of
*** GLIB is always available from ftp://ftp.gtk.org/.

  I had previously updated pkg-config and glib -- then ran /sbin/ldconfig.

  Several years ago I ran into this same problem trying to upgrade gtk+/glib
from source (because there wasn't a RH package for the newest version). Some
place on the system there's an environment variable, or old binary/library,
that doesn't get updated or erased when I 'make install' a new glib version.

  I searched my mail archives and partitions for this information but didn't
find it.

Subject: [PLUG] Network popup message on Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303312051510.10965-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0303312051510.10965-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1049210570.3046.2.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-03-31 at 21:02, Wally Wharton wrote:
> On Mon, 31 Mar 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> : In Windows you can send a popup message to everyone in a domain/workgroup.
> :  For example, a window would popup and say, "Please logout of the file
> : server."
> :
> : Does anyone have a suggestion on how this could be done for Linux clients?
> :  In addition, if this could also be initiated from a Windows client, that
> : would be useful.  We have a mixed Windows/Linux environment so ideally I'd
> : like to be able to send messages both ways.
> :
> 
> man smbclient
> 
> WinPopup messages are part of the smb protocol, and are limited to
> 1600 bytes in length.  From Linux to Windows, you can use the -M
> switch to `smbclient'.  See the message command parameter in the
> smb.conf(5) for a description of how to handle incoming WinPopup
> messages in Samba.
> 
I had this working at one time, from linux to windows, from windows to
windows, and all other perturbations.  "Net Send" is the windows
command.

Derek Loree
> Wally

SourceForge carried this news story this morning. I don't know whether
they're just serving-up installation ISO's, or whether they've got the whole
magilla.

 

*   <http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=03/03/31/1256236> Snag the Red Hat 9
ISOs, via Cash or BitTorrent 
Red Hat Linux 9 is out, and as of today the ISOs are
<http://www.redhat.com/mktg/rh9iso/> officially available to Red Hat Network
subscribers ($60/yr). Or, as of right now, you can
<http://bitconjurer.org/BitTorrent/rh9.html> grab the same ISOs using
BitTorrent. For those unfamiliar with this free/Free P2P download protocol,
an introduction follows, written by ololiuhqui. Update: 03/31 23:45 GMT by
<http://jamie.mccarthy.vg/> J: After roughly four hours, BitTorrent has
transferred over 500 full copies of all 3 ISOs, and a total of over 1.5 TB,
at 170 Mbytes/sec. Thanks to the more than 3000 people who helped each other
download the data, and especially to the more than 200 who got full copies
and still have their clients open, to keep serving data to everyone else :)

How?

Got tired of the drone of the laptop's drive so I started playing with 
hdparm -y which reported that it was "issuing standby command" but there is 
no change in sound and an immediate query (-C) reports "active/idle"

So I issue 'hdparm -Y /dev/hda' and it goes to sleep, although

when needed, but apparently not in my case.  Question: is there a way to do 
this manually?

I've disabled apmd since it was causing periodic dirt-naps.  I'm guessing 
it's a bios/hardware-specific issue.  Toshiba anyone?

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Apr  2 07:04:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Apr  2 07:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Waking a sleeping hd?
In-Reply-To: <3E8A820E.7060306@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304020702000.11326-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Kyle,

Here's the recipe I used with some success back when I was using IDE 
drives; I just had it tucked away in rc.local:

# hdparm magic:
# -c 1    = enable 32-bit i/o support
# -d 1    = enable dma transfers
# -k 1    = keep settings through resets
# -m 16   = set multiple-sector i/o
# -u 1    = set interrupt-unmask flag
# -S 241  = power back drives after 30 min of inactivity
/sbin/hdparm -c1 -d1 -k1 -m16 -u1 -S241 /dev/hda

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Apr  2 09:39:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Apr  2 09:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mailman questions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0304020921530.8283-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304020934570.11326-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 2 Apr 2003, Neil wrote:

> 2. Now, in mailman, I have set a couple of moderators. How do they
> send out emails to the list?

After you login to the admin page for your list, go to the Privacy 
options page. From there, scroll down to the 'General posting filters' 
section.

What you probably want to do is set things so that

* Must posts be approved by an administrator? == Yes
* Restrict posting privilege to list members? == No
* Addresses of members accepted == <list of accepted e-mail addresses>

I think that's the right recipe.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Wed Apr  2 10:21:02 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Wed Apr  2 10:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How do I stop people from posting?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0304020958090.5149-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0304020958090.5149-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030402182020.GB3758@dalsemi.com>

On Wed, Apr 02, 2003 at 09:58:53AM -0800, Neil wrote:
> 
> I was wondering how do I stop members of the list from posting?
> 
> This is an announcement only list and people will get pissed if there are
> a lot of individual postings.

su - mailman

./bin/config_list -o my.config listname

Use your favorite editor to find the following lines and read
the documentation for them:

moderated = 0

member_posting_only = 0

posters = [ 'me at home', 'myFriend at hisHouse']

./bin/config_list -i my.config listname

Now, only me at home and myFriend at hisHouse should be able to post, kind of
mimicking multiple moderators but without the explicit approval.

Colin

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Apr  2 11:25:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Apr  2 11:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail, Sendmail, Spamassassin and forwarding
In-Reply-To: <000f01c2f948$78f09730$64010a0a@sta001>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304021120060.11326-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 2 Apr 2003, Russell F. Davis wrote:

> How might this situation be remedied so that inbound messages are
> analyzed by SpamAssassin prior to being forwarded to Exchange?

You can call SpamAssassin during the SMTP-negotiation phase using 
MIMEDefang in combination with sendmail's milter interface.

* MIMEDefang: http://www.roaringpenguin.com/mimedefang/
* Nice HOWTO: http://www.rudolphtire.com/mimedefang-howto/

You can ignore the stuff in the HOWTO about building sendmail with 
libmilter enabled; Red Hat does that for you.

Using this technique, SpamAssassin gets called before inbound messages
get passed off to a local delivery agent.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Apr  2 11:44:01 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed Apr  2 11:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail, Sendmail, Spamassassin and forwarding
In-Reply-To: <000f01c2f948$78f09730$64010a0a@sta001>; from russ.davis@thetraskgroup.com on Wed, Apr 02, 2003 at 10:48:35AM -0800
References: <000f01c2f948$78f09730$64010a0a@sta001>
Message-ID: <20030402114343.A6959@aracnet.com>

If users do their forwarding with a ~/.procmailrc file instead of a
~/.forward file, then fowarding will happen after the message has
been processed by any system-wide filters. The user's ~/.procmail 
file would look like this:

   :0
   ! user at somewhere-else.com

The trick is to make sure that the global procmail file (/etc/procmailrc)
never saves email to $DEFAULT, thus bypassing the user's procmailrc
file. Instead the global file must allow all "good" mail to fall through 
to the end, in which case the user's procmail file will take over and
handle final delivery.

Terry

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Apr  2 15:06:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Wed Apr  2 15:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail, Sendmail, Spamassassin and forwarding
References: <000f01c2f948$78f09730$64010a0a@sta001> <mailman.1049312643.4854.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <868yus33m9.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Terry" == Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com> writes:

Terry> If users do their forwarding with a ~/.procmailrc file instead of a
Terry> ~/.forward file, then fowarding will happen after the message has
Terry> been processed by any system-wide filters. The user's ~/.procmail 
Terry> file would look like this:

Terry>    :0
Terry>    ! user at somewhere-else.com

Terry> The trick is to make sure that the global procmail file (/etc/procmailrc)
Terry> never saves email to $DEFAULT, thus bypassing the user's procmailrc
Terry> file. Instead the global file must allow all "good" mail to fall through 
Terry> to the end, in which case the user's procmail file will take over and
Terry> handle final delivery.

I've found that

  DEFAULT="! user at somewhere-else.com"

also works nicely.  And then you can be SURE that it *does* save
mail to DEFAULT. :)

(I might be slightly off on the syntax... maybe you don't
need the !)

From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Apr  2 15:59:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed Apr  2 15:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Procmail, Sendmail, Spamassassin and forwarding
In-Reply-To: <868yus33m9.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>; from merlyn@stonehenge.com on Wed, Apr 02, 2003 at 03:02:06PM -0800
References: <000f01c2f948$78f09730$64010a0a@sta001> <mailman.1049312643.4854.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <868yus33m9.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <20030402155840.A18311@aracnet.com>

On Wed, Apr 02, 2003 at 03:02:06PM -0800, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> >>>>> "Terry" == Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com> writes:
> 
> Terry> If users do their forwarding with a ~/.procmailrc file instead of a
> Terry> ~/.forward file, then fowarding will happen after the message has
> Terry> been processed by any system-wide filters. The user's ~/.procmail 
> Terry> file would look like this:
> 
> Terry>    :0
> Terry>    ! user at somewhere-else.com
> 
> Terry> The trick is to make sure that the global procmail file (/etc/procmailrc)
> Terry> never saves email to $DEFAULT, thus bypassing the user's procmailrc
> Terry> file. Instead the global file must allow all "good" mail to fall through 
> Terry> to the end, in which case the user's procmail file will take over and
> Terry> handle final delivery.
> 
> I've found that
> 
>   DEFAULT="! user at somewhere-else.com"
> 
> also works nicely.  And then you can be SURE that it *does* save
> mail to DEFAULT. :)
> 
> (I might be slightly off on the syntax... maybe you don't
> need the !)

I don't think that's quite it, but I believe there is a syntax for setting 
a forwarding DEFAULT. The problem is that it doesn't do much good in the 
system-wide /etc/procmailrc file where you don't know where each user 
wants their mail forwarded. In order to do what the user really wants 
(forwarding, sorting mail in to different folders, whatever) you have to 
fall-through to the end of /etc/procmailrc so that the user's 
~/.procmailrc can take over. This can be a real pain to do in procmailrc
syntax. In my view this is a flaw in procmail. There should be a feature 
like this: 

   :0
   $FALLTHROUGH

This would cause the remainder of /etc/procmailrc to be skipped and
processing would pick up with the user's ~/.procmailrc file.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

From phil at alcsoftware.com  Wed Apr  2 16:40:03 2003
From: phil at alcsoftware.com (Phil Schultz)

#mount -t vfat /dev/hdc1 /mnt/hdc

Friends,

I've just returned from the capitol building. I first met with Rep.
Kitts (R) regarding this bill. He indicated the following:

  * IT certainly has taken it "in the chin" during this economic
downturn

  * We need to do more to help the IT community in Oregon beyond R & D
tax credits

  * He looks forward to hearing my testimony tomorrow morning

Our meeting was brief. If any of you know an Intel representative who is
at liberty to discuss this bill, please have them give Rep. Kitts a call
as Intel is in his district; I understand that Intel is officially
neutral on this issue.

Secondly, the Department of Administrative Services will testify in
favor of this bill. This testimony will prove very valuable as they are
prepared to shed light on savings, enhanced functionality, and reduced
vendor dependence by using Open Source Software.

Finally, I am told that the Business Software alliance _will_ be
testifying in opposition of this bill. If some of you could do some
research on the BSA and send me links of articles outlining their
practices, motivation and case history I would be very great full. This
will give me more time to coordinate our efforts without needing to
worry so much about theirs.

I will be working late into the night preparing for tomorrow morning's
hearing. I will keep you updated as I know more.

From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Apr  2 20:32:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed Apr  2 20:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.x EOL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304021923500.1717-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wednesday 02 April 2003 07:27 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 2 Apr 2003, Terry Griffin wrote:
> > Well, thanks to all of you for pointing this out, but it doesn't help me
> > one bit as my boxes are mostly 7.0.
>
> Terry,
>
>   This lets me raise the concern I had when I read the e-mail this morning.
>
>   Based on Red Hat's lumping 7.0 with 6.2 suggests to me that there were
> _major_ changes from 7.0 to 7.1. And, that the releases from 7.1 forward
> are similar enough to be supportable through the end of this year.
>
>   So, my question is whether an upgrade of all your boxes to 7.1, .2, or .3
> would be equally as painful as an upgrade to 8.0 or 9.0. And, if the
> changes between 7.0 and 7.1 were so significant, why didn't they warrant a
> major number change rather than a minor number change?
>

Well, this isn't the discussion I wanted to have, but here's the history
as I understand it.

7.0 was going to be the first system with a 2.4 kernel, but 2.4 took a lot 
longer than expected, so 7.0 had a 2.2 kernel and 7.1 was the first to
have a 2.4 kernel. That's the split between 7.0 and 7.1.

The reason that 7.1 was not called 8.0 was because it was binary compatible
at the application layer. The kernel version generally does not impact binary
compatibility, except for really big things like the transition from a.out to
ELF.

Red Hat's pattern until now was to roll the major number when there was
something that broke binary compatibility, usually something very basic like
a new version of glibc, gcc, or both.

As for upgrading my boxes. It would just be a big pain in the backside
irrespective of the size of the leap, and for no good reason other than to
follow with along with Red Hat's grand plan for making money from bug
fixes. These boxes are all doing their respective jobs perfectly well.
Taking them out of service for upgrades makes no sense if I can avoid it.

Terry

> > This page has a very useful description of the changes present in RH 9.

> 
> This was, indeed, a useful description.  Now the hard question.
> 
> Can anyone surmise what consequences I might face if I try to 
> update a 7.2 system to this 9.0?

*IF* I understand the changes correctly, then an update will work,
*ONLY* if most (all?) of your installed software is replaced with newly
recompiled versions that work with the new threading model. 

Redhat has made a VERY large departure from previous versions with this
release. Almost nothing from previous releases will work with this
release. Hense, that's why they are sunsetting all previous versions at
the end of this year. It would be a major pain for them to maintain two
code bases. 

It will be interesting to see if this gamble on their part pays off. At
this point, my servers are running RH 7.3, and my workstation is running
Mandrake 9.1. 

I have no short term plans to upgrade my servers, as RH still does not
offer all the functionality in 9.0 that's available with 7.3. Apache 1.3
is (as of this writing) much more extended than Apache 2.0.

I can't justify upgrading until Apache 2.0 supports most everything
Apache 1.3 does. 

> I feel like I should have the "latest", but I don't want to spend the next
> week undoing/fixing things so they work again...

I like having the latest too, but that has to be balanced against
usability. 

> Don't know what exactly I'm worried about, but always a little nervous
> about such a big jump...

Especially since what they changed effectively breaks many things.
Recompiling lots of software will take a long time. If you run any
commercial software (closed source) I can almost guarentee it'll need
to be recompiled for the new system. 

Now, I could be WAY off base here, but what I'm relaying here is what
I'm hearing from many early adopters.

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Thu Apr  3 00:56:05 2003
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Thu Apr  3 00:56:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: [lug] Astaro Security Linux: PPTP setup question - Win 2000
 Error 778
Message-ID: <EX-20030327-102150-0005@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

DAve,

IPSEC client software tends to be very specific to the vendor for example Checkpoint's client (http://www.checkpoint.com) will not play nice with Cisco (http://www.cisco.com) same with Netscreen, etc. With the exception of Cisco this is because of the way the clients are for example Free S/wan can talk nicely to Checkpoint and that is what I do. :) IPSEC is *the* standard it is what all the big boys use it is what security auditors look for it is tested and secure as opposed to PPTP which is, of course, not. 

This is why is seemed so odd to me that you where talking about PPTP to a firewall/vpn box simply because the only people who use PPTP are people who are trying to use something MSian for a firewall/vpn box. So as far as getting winders to talk to PPTP on a non-winders vpn box I am sorry but I got nothing. It looks to me like Astaro has a client (http://www.astaro.com/php/statics.php?action=remoteipsec&lang=gb) and if I had decided that I like them enough to deploy them. And as an aside I *really* hope you are not going with them just because the OS that their stuff runs on happens to be Linux and they do look interesting I'm certainly going to read more. I would use their client. In general the best client to use for any given VPN box is the client that that box comes with. This is true for a number of reasons. 

1. You are not going to run into nearly as many *weird* problems. 

2. While all the vendors out there claim to be IPSEC they are all really IPSEC plus. If there is an expection to this rule I have yet to find it. Therefore with the clients you get goodies like being able to enforce "security policies" for example with the Checkpoint client we cut off all traffic to anybody except us when the VPN is on. Various things like that.

Subject: RE: [lug] Astaro Security Linux: PPTP setup question - Win 2000
Error 778


On Mon, 24 Mar 2003, Percival, Ray wrote:

> ARe you trying to talk from a Win2k client to a Linux box?
> If so what are you running on the Linux box and why are you trying PPTP
> which is a protocol with so many problems that basically sending in the
> clear is just as good? Please more detail on what you are doing and why.
>

Ray,

    The Linux server is a firewall running Astaro Security Linux - which
is a very refined, cut down Debian variant.  (Well, there actually isn't
much Debian left.)  Astaro is a large firewall distribution, a bit
like Smoothwall, but much better and much more expensive.  It includes
packet filters, proxy servers, virus scans, IPSEC VPN, PPTP VPN, decent
reporting functions, etc.  Unneeded services have been removed to the
point that there are only about 100 commands left.  Most services run
in chroot jails.  It is pretty nice.

    My client wants to support a variety of Windows clients on the
VPN including Win 98, Win ME, Win 2000, and Win XP.  However, most of
the clients are Win 2000 or Win XP.  I have recommended getting IPSEC
client software for all the PCs or possibly using the IPSEC that
comes with Win 2000 and Win XP, but my client is reluctant to switch
from PPTP for a number of very good reasons.  At this point, it looks
like we will install PPTP and gradually migrate to IPSEC - which of
course is much better for several reasons - like it is relatively secure
and PPTP is not.

    In any case, what IPSEC client software do you normally recommend on:

                 Win 98
                 Win ME
                 Win 2000
                 Win XP

Do you recommend MicroSoft's IPSEC on Win 2000 and/or Win XP or do you
recommend something like SSH Sentinel or is there something more
OpenSource than this?

                                                     Dave Mandel

Speaker(s): Scott Charney, Microsoft's chief security strategist-- Scott
Charney, formerly a principal for PricewaterhouseCoopers' Cybercrime
Prevention and Response Practice, joined Microsoft as chief security
strategist. Charney focuses on developing strategies to enhance the
security of Microsoft? products, services and infrastructures as part of
the Trustworthy Computing initiative. Charney takes a long-term,
industrywide perspective on security strategy and understands the
critical challenge of building safe and secure software and services for
industry." During Charney's tenure at PricewaterhouseCoopers, he
provided proactive and reactive computer security services to major
companies, including designing and building computer security systems
from scratch, testing existing systems, conducting cybercrime
investigations, and assisting companies responding to electronic
discovery requests. Before joining PricewaterhouseCoopers, Charney
served as chief of the Computer Crime and Intellectual Property Section
(CCIPS), Criminal Division, at the Department of Justice, from 1991 to
1999. Under his direction, CCIPS investigated and prosecuted national
and international hacker cases, economic espionage cases, and violations
of federal criminal copyright and trademark laws. Before joining the
federal prosecutive ranks, Charney was an assistant district attorney in
Bronx County, New York, ultimately serving as deputy chief of the
Investigations Bureau. Charney holds a degree from Syracuse University
College of Law as well as bachelor's degrees in history and English from
the State University of New York at Binghamton.

Title:  Technology, Law, and Change: A Global View

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On
Behalf Of Terry Griffin
Sent: Wednesday, April 02, 2003 3:59 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Procmail, Sendmail, Spamassassin and forwarding

On Wed, Apr 02, 2003 at 03:02:06PM -0800, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> >>>>> "Terry" == Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com> writes:
>
> Terry> If users do their forwarding with a ~/.procmailrc file instead of a
> Terry> ~/.forward file, then fowarding will happen after the message has
> Terry> been processed by any system-wide filters. The user's ~/.procmail
> Terry> file would look like this:
>
> Terry>    :0
> Terry>    ! user at somewhere-else.com
>
> Terry> The trick is to make sure that the global procmail file
(/etc/procmailrc)
> Terry> never saves email to $DEFAULT, thus bypassing the user's procmailrc
> Terry> file. Instead the global file must allow all "good" mail to fall
through
> Terry> to the end, in which case the user's procmail file will take over
and
> Terry> handle final delivery.
>
> I've found that
>
>   DEFAULT="! user at somewhere-else.com"
>
> also works nicely.  And then you can be SURE that it *does* save
> mail to DEFAULT. :)
>
> (I might be slightly off on the syntax... maybe you don't
> need the !)

I don't think that's quite it, but I believe there is a syntax for setting
a forwarding DEFAULT. The problem is that it doesn't do much good in the
system-wide /etc/procmailrc file where you don't know where each user
wants their mail forwarded. In order to do what the user really wants
(forwarding, sorting mail in to different folders, whatever) you have to
fall-through to the end of /etc/procmailrc so that the user's
~/.procmailrc can take over. This can be a real pain to do in procmailrc
syntax. In my view this is a flaw in procmail. There should be a feature
like this:

   :0
   $FALLTHROUGH

This would cause the remainder of /etc/procmailrc to be skipped and
processing would pick up with the user's ~/.procmailrc file.

Terry

Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Apr  3 08:39:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Apr  3 08:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.x EOL
In-Reply-To: <3E8BDB9D.9020203@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304030829210.15851-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 2 Apr 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> As a hobbist, I probably upgrade every 1-2 years anyway.  Not a
> biggie, but the forced obselence does sting a little.

"Forced"? There's nothing forced here. It simply means that Red Hat 
will no longer be paying people to do work that the rest of us get for 
free.

I just don't get the griping. Red Hat has to pay its developers, and 
to do so, it's got to make a profit. Does anyone seriously expect that 
Red Hat can maintain long-term support of older distributions that 
generate no income?

If it's in your interest to maintain an older version of Red Hat 
Linux, then grab the source packages and keep up with the security 
patches. No one is forcing anyone to upgrade. If you're willing to put 
in the work, Red Hat 6.x and 7.0 can be kept running for years to 
come.

Red Hat is merely saying that it's working on other projects now --
projects that allow many kernel and application developers to do
trivial things like eat and pay their mortgages.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

                        Aspire to Crudeness -- Issue 37

  April 3, 2003

  by Don Marti, Editor in Chief of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                  This Week's Sponsor: VMware Workstation

      Powerful Virtual Machine Software for the Technical Professional

   Reboot me, delete me, crash me...and do it all over again. VMware
   virtual machines let you run multiple operating systems simultaneously
   on a single box. Crash one machine, and recycle it in seconds, while
   the others keep running. Free 30-day trial here:
   http://www.vmware.com/wl/offer/116/0.
     _________________________________________________________________

   First of all, some of you wrote nice letters to economist Peter
   Passell, inspired by his "Why Open Source Stifles Innovation" article
   that I replied to in the last ATC. Here's one that Michael Bacarella
   sent:

     One mistake that is very commonly made in discussions of the
     software industry is the extension of shrinkwrap software
     development to encompass the entire industry.

     Shrinkwrap software just does not matter. Or if it does, it's
     nothing worth discussing. There are few vendors that can make money
     at it, and it's basically because they have a monopoly. Anyone else
     is selling a gimmick or entertainment content.

     Many believe people who write code spend their time developing
     shrinkwrap software. This is a myth; these developers are in the
     minority. Scan the help-wanted section, and you'll find that 95-99%
     of the ads for programmers are NOT to work on shrinkwrap software.
     Few of the people who do work on shrinkwrap software, consequently,
     ever contribute to free software. That's because free software is
     very tightly associated with custom software systems, not
     shrinkwrap software.

     Companies don't hire programmers to develop shrinkwrap building
     blocks; they're hired because they have (or soon hope to have) a
     ton of information and need to have it processed in a way that is
     unique to their individual business. Shrinkwrap software just
     cannot address this need.

     Some traits typical of custom software systems:

     * One or very few buyers.
     * The buyer often has nothing to do with software industry or even
       IT in general.
     * The buyer is uninterested in reselling the software system;
       they're not shrinkwrap software vendors, they don't know how to
       market it, and it's really not the best use of their time to try.
     * The buyer pays for on-going maintenance, support and enhancement
       of their custom developed system.
     * Competitors do not gain a significant edge if they obtain this
       software. Custom systems are just that, custom--crafted to each
       company's unique needs.

     Of these projects (which far outnumber shrinkwrap software
     projects), items like software licensing are rather irrelevant to
     the bottom line. What is relevant though is if the buyer can find
     ways to decrease their costs ("transaction costs" is a nice way to
     put it, kudos). Additionally, the buyer does not want to depend on
     the developer indefinitely (hit-by-a-bus principle). This situation
     has GPL written all over it.

     For the custom software developer, the GPL is a warm hug of
     industry cooperation. The feeling that you are going out into the
     world not alone, but with the support of your peers. Only this is
     not forced by gunpoint (which is required to be pinko-commie), but
     agreed to by all involved parties in an unspoken way for the
     purposes of mutual gain. It's very much a trade association, but it
     takes so long to realize that it's far more useful than any
     "official" trade association can be. And all you have to do is
     contribute back, which as we know, can have substantial positive
     effects (adoration of peers, bugfixes, etc.).

     Seems pretty pro-business to me.

     --
Michael Bacarella                  24/7 phone: 646 641-8662
Netgraft Corporation                   http://netgraft.com/
      "unique technologies to empower your business"

Finger email address for public key.  Key fingerprint:
  C40C CB1E D2F6 7628 6308  F554 7A68 A5CF 0BD8 C055

   (If the USPTO allowed for patents on analogies in English prose, Doc
   Searls would be raking in the royalties from Michael and others on
   that whole "software is construction" thing. By not allowing prose
   patents, USPTO is destroying billions of dollars of potential Doc
   Searls' wealth!)

  NVIDIA

   Some NVIDIA folks called to boast they're offering a whole separate
   software update and dependency tracking infrastructure to keep their
   proprietary driver stuff up to date--like I'm supposed to thank them
   for a workaround for their own pigheadness.

   Basically, the problem is this: they don't want to publish source for
   a driver because they think they're more likely to get sued for patent
   infringement. This is probably true; there are certainly enough bogus
   software patents out there.

   So, there's something lurking beneath the surface of the proprietary
   binary-only NVIDIA driver that's raw meat for a patent lawyer. The
   fact they release binary-only will slow the lawyers down, but not stop
   them. I wonder which company will try first. Hey! Lawyers! Deep
   pockets! Go get'em!

   One other interesting point about the whole binary-only modules thing
   is the easiest way for the Forces of Evil to subvert Linux security
   would be to distribute a proprietary kernel module to make /dev/random
   a little less random--not enough so you would notice in daily use, but
   enough to make crypto apps use keys just weak enough for the NSA to
   crack.

  Link of the Day: Learn Linux, get hired.

   Learn Linux, get hired:
   http://news.zdnet.co.uk/story/0,,t269-s2132622,00.html:

   "In a survey of skills types in short supply, Linux is the only one to
   have seen any growth over the past year."

> Red Hat can maintain long-term support of older distributions that 
> generate no income?

Technical quibbling, but to be clear RH pays it's developers out of income not 
profit. Profit is revenue minus expenses and the developers are expenses. With 
$300 Million in reserves (last i checked) RH can get by indefinitely without 
profit.

They do need to generate income, though, like you said, and otherwise i agree 
with your line of reasoning.

david pool

forwarded the message to their "abuse at ..." address.

  If any of you are interested in seeing a copy -- and/or playing with the
attachment -- I'll forward it to you. I strongly suspect that the gullible
who blithly run the executable will find their system compromised in one or
more ways.

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Apr  3 09:58:01 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Apr  3 09:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.x EOL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304030829210.15851-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>; from heinlein@attbi.com on Thu, Apr 03, 2003 at 08:38:48AM -0800
References: <3E8BDB9D.9020203@pacifier.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304030829210.15851-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <20030403095738.A21923@aracnet.com>

On Thu, Apr 03, 2003 at 08:38:48AM -0800, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Wed, 2 Apr 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> 
> > As a hobbist, I probably upgrade every 1-2 years anyway.  Not a
> > biggie, but the forced obselence does sting a little.
> 
> "Forced"? There's nothing forced here. It simply means that Red Hat 
> will no longer be paying people to do work that the rest of us get for 
> free.
> 
> I just don't get the griping. Red Hat has to pay its developers, and 
> to do so, it's got to make a profit. Does anyone seriously expect that 
> Red Hat can maintain long-term support of older distributions that 
> generate no income?
> 
> If it's in your interest to maintain an older version of Red Hat 
> Linux, then grab the source packages and keep up with the security 
> patches. No one is forcing anyone to upgrade. If you're willing to put 
> in the work, Red Hat 6.x and 7.0 can be kept running for years to 
> come.
> 
> Red Hat is merely saying that it's working on other projects now --
> projects that allow many kernel and application developers to do
> trivial things like eat and pay their mortgages.
> 

Yes, but the counter argument is that Red Hat, in dropping support for 
these versions that are still in fairly wide use (well, not 6.2 probably, 
but certainly 7.0) is that they are contributing to a less secure 
Internet. While it's certainly still possible to apply the lastest patches 
as you described, it's also more difficult. Some less disciplined, less 
skilled, or resource constrained system admins will just give up. For the 
most part these sys admins are just hurting themselves, but they are also 
hurting the rest of us by providing platforms for worms to advance 
themselves etc.

And from here on out it just gets worse, as cash-strapped businesses, 
governments, and non-profits continue to use the basic Red Hat edition on 
their servers. A year after initial release Red Hat will stop providing 
security updates for the basic edition. Are all those servers going to get 
upgraded yearly in order to remain secure? Not likely.

My view is that Red Hat should continue to provide security fixes for
the typical life cycle of the hardware on which the OS runs. One year
is just *way* too short. A year is nothing. I've got uptimes longer than 
that.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Thu Apr  3 16:33:02 2003

I might be misunderstanding your question, but I'll give it a shot anyway.

 

If you want to change the number people dial to gain access to your company
network (and from there, to the Internet), there should be no change at all
needed on the server's config files. The place where changes are needed is
on the client side. Are your employees all calling from home with Linux
machines, or some other OS?

 

Instead of plugging the modem into the telephone patch-panel jack for the
phone number 555-1212, just move it over to the patch panel jack for the
number 555-1215, for example. If you have a PBX or some other switch-board
beyond just a jack for each phone line, things get more complicated and
you'll need to check with someone who understands your particular phone
system. I've worked with a couple of small PBX systems and I can tell you
that every brand is different.

 

-djp

http://folding.stanford.edu <http://folding.stanford.edu>  - the brain you
save may be your own!

Who summoneth me?  <brimstone puff>

It's a lot of steps, and it works for everyone but Rich. This is how to 
recover a root password in Debian, without a rescue disk. Having a rescue 
disk is better. Hopefully your filepaths are not too different:

As regular user, open /boot/grub/menu.lst and 
write it down, you want the kernel and root lines. Don't use mine. If you 
can't log in at all, and don't know to use GRUB to figure out your kernel and 
root lines, let me know:

## ## End Default Options ##

title           Libranet GNU/Linux, kernel 2.4.19
root  (hd0,2)
kernel  /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.19 root=/dev/hda3 ro 
savedefault

restart machine, when Grub menu appears hit 'c' to get the command prompt
type the root line as you copied it and hit return
type  the kernel line as you copied it, then add this to the end:

init=/bin/bash

and hit return
type boot and hit return

It will boot normally and stop at a command prompt, and will not ask for a 
login. Remount in readwrite:

# mount -o remount,rw /

Using your fave editor, open /etc/shadow. At the top is the line for root's 
hashed password.

root:$1$uz4Kua9u$D/5ySgWS19.dNjNMlRnRO.:12037:0:99999:7:::

Delete the bit between the first set of colons:

root::12037:0:99999:7:::

Now, remount as read-only:

# mount -o remount,ro /

Now sync the filesystem:

# sync;sync;sleep 10;sync;mount -o remount,ro /

Restart init:

# exec /sbin/init

Now when you log in as root, it will not ask for a password.

Slick n quick! Have fun!

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

I would think that the username and passwd are on the box itself. Look
in the /home directory for current users.

To change passwords, do "passwd user", and it will ask you for a
new pass.

To add new users, do "adduser" and fill in the blanks.

On Thu, Apr 03, 2003 at 10:33:44PM -0500, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> Better than legal solutions: Popfile. Bayesian spam filtering. Better
> than anything except building your own neural network. Yet to fail me.

...it probably is better than building your own neural net.. Bayesian
nets (especially if you can build a naive bayes on top of some
informed network) usually kick ass compared to other off-the shelf
learning algorithms. 

Spam also has so many unrealted traits (which is why
spamc/spamassassin work) that even naive bayes nets will do a very
good job compared to many more complex methods (neural nets being just
one example).

I haven't experimented with spam filtering algo's myself
though.. personally I'm more into music classification, but the same
theory applies.

-Rogan

> On Wed, Apr 02, 2003 at 11:11:07PM -0800, Bruce Kingsland wrote:
> > Other than the apt-get feature of Debian, and the fact that it's
> > layout on the FS is way different than what I'm used to on RedHat...
> 
> I'm a bit confused, does this mean you won't consider debian? or you
> just don't want to learn apt-get and a new filesystem layout?

Some years ago, I was having trouble getting linux installed. I forget
what distro it was. A young guru (very smart kid) insisted that debian
would solve all my problems. So, I got the 4 CD set and installed it.
Just as broke as previous attempts, and none of the helps available
anywhere I could find provided any suggestions as to what was what.
Nothing that I read matched anything on the debian fs layout, and I
got really frustrated with it. So, for a really long time, I wanted
nothing to do with it. And more recently, when I ask a question, and
get an answer like "just use apt-get ####", I tend to stay frustrated.
Usually when I ask a question, I want enough data to know _why_
something works a particular way, not just that it works.

That said, I might consider debian now, but I have alot more
experience with the "standard file system" that the rest of the
community proposed some while back; and I'm not sure that debian
follows that. If I really end up with a completely new approach, then
debian is as good as any other (just as much work to re-learn). There
are certainly many good things about debian; and I really don't know
all that much about it. It's just enough different from a RH system,
that cluttering my mind with inappropriate data has been something
I've avoided. Now that I'm considering a different approach... that
data isn't so inappropriate.

> (fwiw, redhat is standardizing the filesystem layout in the newer
> versions, so that may be somewhat unavoidable.)

I think a standard fs layout is very useful. It's also handy for
knowing where to find certain tools and to know what is a system tool
and what is a user tool, and what tools are critical, etc.

The problem I'm having is that when I finally get tired of a missing
feature in the word processor or the spreadsheet, I go out to the web
to see if an upgrade is available. I find that there is, but that the
tools required are not part of the distro I have, so then I have to
upgrade abunch of stuff. The RPM doesn't work because it depends on
some file I don't have, but fails to tell me what I need to get to fix
that. So, I end up downloading source, and recompiling to run on the
system that I have. Then I find that I can't get there from here
because I'm still on a two year old kernel, which won't work with the
new files. The chicken and the egg continue to fight!

So, I'm looking to get away from RPM's and maybe avoid apt-get for the
same reason, and build a system that can be upgraded more sanely. I
like the argument for slackware that was posted earlier. And Jeme was
promoting LFS as a completely distro independent solution last year;
which at this point could be very appealing!

At this particular moment, I'm just trying to gather some level of
intelligent info on the choices, and the experiences of the group,
that help me make a decision that isn't just a different path thru the
same garden.

Thanx!
-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

	The system is going down for reboot NOW!
	INIT: Switching to runlevel: 6
	INIT: No inittab file found
	INIT: Sending processes the TERM signal
	INIT: Sending processes the KILL signal
	INIT: No more processes left in this runlevel

and there it stays. Keypresses produce only their ANSI codes on screen. When
I power off, then power on again, the system doesn't do a POST, then look in
the attached floppy drive for the boot floppy. It just restores the state it
was in when shut down.

  I tried holding down the [Esc] key while powering on, but that made no
difference. I was trying to get to setup so I could turn off the auto-start
feature. Removing the pcmcia card attached to the cdrom drive produces a
beep; reinserting the card produces another beep and the drive spins before
again becoming comatose.

  I'm stuck in mud over the wheels on this and I need some expertise to pull
me out.

On 4 Apr 2003, Cooper Stevenson wrote:

> Here's a link from the Oregonian about our hearing yesterday! 

Cooper, et al.:

  The article noted that the industry is lining up heavily to fight this
because they perceive the purpose to "encourage" FOSS rather than
proprietary software. In the negotiations for language change, work for
language that's neutral and puts both open source and proprietary software
on a completely equal basis. This has two advantages.

  First, it prevents any challange to the law and makes it much easier for a
majority of legislators to pass it and have Gov. Ted sign it. Second, the
many advantages will be obvious -- or easily seen -- when both routes are
laid out side-by-side. Open source software doesn't need an perceived
advantage in the statute's language.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Fri Apr  4 09:09:01 2003
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Fri Apr  4 09:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Urge support for HB2892
Message-ID: <20030404090709.A9424@patch.com>

Dear Ms. Rosenbaum,

This morning I read the coverage of HB2892 that is currently under consideration.

I urge you to support this bill.  I have been an IT professional for almost 20 
years.  Currently I work for Columbia Management Company as a network engineer.
Previously I have worked for companies as large as US Bank and as small as 
a 20 employee consulting firm.

In my experience the biggest roadblock to using open source software is inertia. 
Once that inertia is overcome an unbiased comparison can be made and the benefits
of all competing products can be weighed.  

We use open source software __where appropriate__ and enjoy considerable cost savings.
However, the cost savings are not just in license fees.  We have found that products
handle a greater workload on smaller, less expensive, hardware platforms.  It is 
easier to implement automated monitoring, so that a human being can concentrate 
on other tasks.  

If you were able to hear the testimony of Paul Nelson, you are aware that this 
category of software can be used in the public sector environment successfully.

HB2892 only requires that open source software be considered.  This is an element
of due diligence.  Corporate lobbyists that claim it gives an unfair advantage to 
open source software are (rightfully) doing their job to gain as much business
for their employers as possible.  Unfortunately their employers are not the 
citizens and voters of Oregon.  

Michael Rasmussen
4005 SE Boise
Portland, OR  97202
503-771-9502 home
503-209-6227 cell

-- 
      Michael Rasmussen  aka  mikeraz

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Apr  4 09:11:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri Apr  4 09:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Help needed: notebook stuck in mid-reboot
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304040652110.13576-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304040652110.13576-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

For future reference, the toshiba laptops I've worked with were _very_
difficult to TURN off. pressing the power switch invariably put them
to sleep (they can do this in hardware, I don't know what sleep stat
it is but it appears to keep the ram powered up while everything else
is quiet).

To turn them off I've had to hold the power button for some
innordinate length of time, longer than your typical 5-second ATX
thing, it seems.

Anyhow, this could explain the behavior you saw, and the solution you
came up with fits. The system won't post when you turn it back on
because it wasn't actually off.

-Rogan

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Fri Apr  4 09:47:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Apr  4 09:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB2892: Consideration For "Mabrey's Muslix" Bill
Message-ID: <1049478780.4492.2359.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

The following is an email I sent earlier this morning to Rep. Mabrey:


Dear Representative. Mabrey,

I would like to respond personally to two of your questions during our
committee hearing for HB2892.

Your first question asked effectively, "if I am procuring breakfast
cereal for the state's prison system and I had a choice of trusted brand
names, such as Post or Kelloggs, why would I ever choose "Mabrey's
Muslix?" 

The answer, Representative Mabrey, is that in the real world, "no one
ever got fired for buying Kelloggs." The truth is that IT decision
makers are often compelled to choose a particular cereal not because it
is the most nutritious or is the best value, but because it has brand
recognition. 

Second, you followed up your question asking, "if I know that Kelloggs
brand cereal is reliable and someone asks me to try a relative unknown,
such as "Mabrey's," why would I ever want to do that?"

As a 10 year cereal industry veteran, I know exactly where you are
coming from; I would never risk my production data on an unknown brand
of cereal. 

Fortunately, "Mabrey's Muslix" is actually _very_ well known and backed
heavily by IBM, Hewlette Packard, Sun Microsystems, Oracle, and many
others in the breakfast cereal industry. Further, "Mabrey's Muslix,"
powers the fifth largest "prison system" in the world!

Moreover, many prominent "prison systems" use "Mabrey's Muslix" in their
production environments. Amazon.com, Morgan Stanley, and Intel to name
just three. Here are three references to a long list of "Mabrey's"
customers:

   * http://news.com.com/2100-1001-275155.html?legacy=cnet

   * http://www.vnunet.com/News/1138359

   * http://www.zdnetindia.com/techzone/linuxcentre/stories/78512.html

Personally, I found your questions very pertinent to the matter at hand.
While we used a tongue-and-cheek analogy, these issues are very serious.
I tell you truthfully that I would not have backed HB2892 had I any
doubts that we could dramatically increase the effectiveness of the
State's IT system while at the same time significantly reducing costs.

Representative Mabrey, I encourage your support of HB2892. Oregon will
surely benefit by saving the state millions while at the same time
generating revenue for local Oregon businesses.



Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

  When I installed Slackware-8.1 the 'pcmcia.dsk' had no problems
identifying and using the external cdrom drive connected via pcmcia card.
Now, however, as I try to install 9.0, the drive is seen as the pcmcia
module is loaded, but the drive is not seen when the installer wants to find
the packages to install.

  I've gone through the base.i, install.1, install.2, and pcmcia.dsk
floppies, and formatted/mounted the partitions twice now with the same
results. And, I don't know where else to ask for insight. With the pcmcia
card the drive is supposed to be seen as an IDE/ATAPI one and that was just
fine before.

  I suppose that as a last resort I could re-install 8.1, then upgrade to
9.0 but that's a chunk of time I'd like to avoid if possible.

Thoughts, anyone?

Second, you followed up your question asking, "if I know that Kelloggs
brand cereal is reliable and someone asks me to try a relative unknown,
such as "Mabrey's," why would I ever want to do that?"

As a 10 year cereal industry veteran, I know exactly where you are
coming from; I would never risk my production data on an unknown brand
of cereal. 

Fortunately, "Mabrey's Muslix" is actually _very_ well known and backed
heavily by IBM, Hewlette Packard, Sun Microsystems, Oracle, and many
others in the breakfast cereal industry. Further, "Mabrey's Muslix,"
powers the fifth largest "prison system" in the world!

Moreover, many prominent "prison systems" use "Mabrey's Muslix" in their
production environments. Amazon.com, Morgan Stanley, and Intel to name
just three. Here are three references to a long list of "Mabrey's"
customers:

   * http://news.com.com/2100-1001-275155.html?legacy=cnet

   * http://www.vnunet.com/News/1138359

   * http://www.zdnetindia.com/techzone/linuxcentre/stories/78512.html

Personally, I found your questions very pertinent to the matter at hand.
While we used a tongue-and-cheek analogy, these issues are very serious.
I tell you truthfully that I would not have backed HB2892 had I any
doubts that we could dramatically increase the effectiveness of the
State's IT system while at the same time significantly reducing costs.

Representative Mabrey, I encourage your support of HB2892. Oregon will
surely benefit by saving the state millions while at the same time
generating revenue for local Oregon businesses.



Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri Apr  4 10:57:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri Apr  4 10:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB2892 Made The Oregonian
In-Reply-To: <1049481177.762.10.camel@kokopelli>
References: <1049473230.4502.2042.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
	 <1049475397.991.8.camel@main>  <1049481177.762.10.camel@kokopelli>
Message-ID: <1049482562.992.29.camel@main>

On Fri, 2003-04-04 at 10:32, Brian Beattie wrote:

> hmmm, maybe I'm blind, but I don't see how the bill in it's original
> form requires, or encourages the rewrite of any software currently in
> use.  It addresses _future_ purchases.
> 
> I am concerned that the bill will get watered down too much.  I think
> that FOSS needs a powerful salesman, just like all the other solutions. 
> The other solutions have the cost of selling bundled into the price of
> the software.  FOSS does not, I think it is appropriate for the public
> by it's proxy the government to level the playing field by acting as a
> salesforce for FOSS.
> 
> > 
> > -- 
> > Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>
> > 
> > 
> > _______________________________________________
> > PLUG mailing list
> > PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

At first glance, Section 1, paragraph 2, sub-paragraph d and e seem to
be fair mandates - I believe they are. Unfortunately it puts the state
in a situation where there will be no additional purchases of MS
platforms. This will force all of the applications that have been
developed in that environment to be rewritten to open standards. There
are many ( MANY ) applications in the states inventory that rely in MS
front, middle and back-end platforms that will require rewrite in order
to comply with this language.

Here's the excerpt:

  (d) Avoid the acquisition of products that do not comply with
open standards for interoperability or data storage; and
  (e) Avoid the acquisition of products that are known to make
unauthorized transfers of information to, or permit unauthorized
control of or modification to state government's computer systems
by, parties outside the control of state government. + }
 

The effect on MS is not the only issue here. What about the huge volume
of CICS, TSO, MVS and like mainframe apps that we all rely on? The
impact there is more than money, it comes down to the fact that no
company has been successful at recreating mainframe apps in a
client/server environment and been able to sustain the requirements.

There you have it!

-- 
Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>

[PDXLUG March 06, 2003 Meeting Announcement]

PDXLUG (Portland Linux User Group) presents:
   "Linux at the FireSide"

Speakers: Everyone who comes

When: Tuesday, April 6th, 2003, 7-? pm

*** Starting in May, the meeting will be on the first Tuesday.

Where: Fireside Lodge, located at 1223 SE Powell Blvd
(http://home.attbi.com/~firesidecoffeelodge1/)

Cost: Free

--

PRESENTATION(S)

Matt King will be giving us a presentation on installing and
optimizing Apache, MySQL, PHP and mod_ssl from source.  He
will be using a remote server owned by one of the PDXLUG
members for the demonstration.

--

THE MEDIA LIBRARY

We will be continuing our project with the PDXLUG virtual library
(http://library.pdxlug.org), and if you've already used it, the meeting is
a good chance to get your books you reserved, and hand out books you're
lending.

*** Remember to bring back your books that you checked out of the PDXLUG
    Library, and bring any books that someone has asked to borrow!


FYI, as of this morning we have 123 books and growing.

If you have books that other members wish to borrow, please look at your
list of books that others have requested:
http://library.pdxlug.org/borrow.php?op=owner_reserved

You can look at the books that you have requested to borrow from other
members
here:
http://library.pdxlug.org/borrow.php?op=my_reserved

If you are not a member and wish to join, please send an email to me and I
will
add you to the library or visit: http://library.pdxlug.org/

--

LOCATION

Fireside Lodge has wired internet access, and are having wireless
installed very soon, but it's not certain if they will have it up by the time
we have the meeting.

We'll have the wireless access point setup again, so bring your laptop
with a wireless card if you want.

Again this is very informal so just come expecting to hang out, drink
coffee and talk Linux!

--

LOCATION:

Fireside Coffee Lodge
1223 SE Powell Blvd
Portland, OR 97202

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304031854300.5867-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030404205047.GD15385@rauhaus.org>

* Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> [030403 19:31]:
>
>   Well, I _was_ going to upgrade to 9.0 anyway, but this is a bit sooner
> than planned. My question to you SysAdmins is this: without /etc/fstab will
> I have to repartition the hard drive or will fdisk keep the information and
> let the system recreate /etc/fstab?

It's been a long time since I last used Slack, but the upgrade should
be able to handle it. Your partitions haven't changed, however you will
need to be able to tell it which partition is mounted where - i.e.
that /dev/hda1 is mounted on /, /dev/hda2 is /home, /dev/hdb1 is /tmp.

--Stafford

On Thu, 03 Apr 2003, Rich Shepard wrote: 
> On 3 Apr 2003, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:
> 
> > Hard drive is the same..
> > Only the information in /etc has changed!!!!
> 
>   Well, ... yes. All the config files are gone. I'll see if the upgrade
> replaces them all, then I can re-figure out what needs to be done manually.
> 
>   Now I know: first thing to do is make an alias for 'rm -i'.

Rich,

Surefire way to protect vital directories, alias or no...

[bigfish at kippered tt]$ alias rm
bash: alias: `rm' not found
[bigfish at kippered tt]$ touch -- -i
[bigfish at kippered tt]$ touch this that the other
[bigfish at kippered tt]$ ls
-i  other  that  the  this
[bigfish at kippered tt]$ rm th *       # oops, I really meant to do `rm th*'
rm: cannot remove `th': No such file or directory
rm: remove `other'? n
rm: remove `that'? y
rm: remove `the'? y
rm: remove `this'? y

pathname expansion is your friend :-)

Sandy

On Fri, 2003-04-04 at 13:09, Brian Beattie wrote:
> > At first glance, Section 1, paragraph 2, sub-paragraph d and e seem to
> > be fair mandates - I believe they are. Unfortunately it puts the state
> > in a situation where there will be no additional purchases of MS
> > platforms. This will force all of the applications that have been
> > developed in that environment to be rewritten to open standards. There
> > are many ( MANY ) applications in the states inventory that rely in MS
> > front, middle and back-end platforms that will require rewrite in order
> > to comply with this language.
> > 
> > Here's the excerpt:
> > 
> >   (d) Avoid the acquisition of products that do not comply with
> > open standards for interoperability or data storage; and
> >   (e) Avoid the acquisition of products that are known to make
> > unauthorized transfers of information to, or permit unauthorized
> > control of or modification to state government's computer systems
> > by, parties outside the control of state government. + }
> >  
> > 
> > The effect on MS is not the only issue here. What about the huge volume
> > of CICS, TSO, MVS and like mainframe apps that we all rely on? The
> > impact there is more than money, it comes down to the fact that no
> > company has been successful at recreating mainframe apps in a
> > client/server environment and been able to sustain the requirements.
> > 
> > There you have it!
> > 
> 
> I disagree, the cost of converting software is a reason to buy
> proprietary software.  The law does not require the use of FOSS, just
> that it be considered and the be a reason for not using FOSS.
> 

But the law does prohibit the use of software that functions as is
described in sub-paragraphs d and e of Section 1 paragraph 2 ( if it
does not prohibit this then why does it contain this language? ). This
fact, in effect, forces the state to buy platforms that do not act like
this, thus removing Windows from consideration. Once it's determined
that Windows is not an option, the application components are going to
have to be upgraded to an environment that incorporates fair and
reasonable practices.

Again, I agree with the spirit and language included in the bill. I'm
only speaking up to raise awareness that, while it is the right thing to
do, it is not going to be very budget friendly.

>  
> Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Fri Apr  4 14:27:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Apr  4 14:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB2892 Makes Worksession!
Message-ID: <1049495555.6444.376.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Friends, 

First, I cannot stress enough how proud I am of all of you who have
taken an active roll to see this legislation get first to committee and
now to a work session! I am not exaggerating when I say had it not been
for your active support, none of this would have been possible. Thank
you all again! 

Okay, so many of you are dying to know: we made it to work session! This
is historical. This means that the Representatives for the General
Government Committee feel that there is sufficient interest in the bill
to warrant further action! Again, I am very proud. 

Basically, Ken Barber started testimony with what I felt was a crisp
representation of the bill. His words were powerful and I could tell
that he felt very deeply about this issue. It showed. I'm telling you,
Ken was in rare form. 

Secondly, There was testimony from a representative of O'reilly
discussing how critical it is for government to use open standards. Good
stuff. Thanks are extend to the O'reilly team for their support. 

Third, I kind of "took one for the team" and testified on Open Source
Security. I covered the idea that Open Source developers write code in a
particular manner because their heart was in it, and that the code that
they do write is under intense scrutiny as it develops. I also covered
the idea that an application cannot be truly secure unless it's design
is known to all and yet is still difficult to exploit. 

Believe me, I would love to have testified that as a 10 year IT veteran,
that I have tracked IT trends and can testify that some proprietary
vendors (Microsoft in particular) are definitely not nice guys, "and
here's why..." 

I listened to the audio stream when I came home and I am confident that
I did a good job. The reality is that my testimony was easy to make: it
was the truth. 

After the first panel (we testified in groups of three), the "education
squad" came ready for bear. 

They made a fantastic presentation; Eric Harrision (Lane School
District), Paul Nelson (Riverdale High School), and Quentin Hartmen
(Multnomah Ed. Service Dist.) really were the engine that moved our
testimony forward.

Others supporters followed. There was no shortage of interest in this
bill.

After we had finished our testimony, the Initiative For Software Choice,
the Computing Technology Industry Association, and the Business Software
Alliance testified as a panel. 

The Initiative for Software Choice testified among other things that 
"No law rule or regulation stands in the way of Oregon Software
procurement professionals from obtaining the most appropriate software
for it's needs."

That may be true, but that doesn't mean that we're necessarily dealing
with a level playing field in the Software marketplace. Imagine Ford
Motor Company had a monopoly on the auto market. While there's no law
prohibiting Government agencies from buying another brand of car, the
reality in the market place is that everybody buys Ford and ships
taxpayer dollars to Dearborn Michigan in the process.

The Business Software Alliance testified that, "...And [Oregon's
thriving technological innovation] is in no small part due to the fact
that this body has wisely and successfully chosen to let market forces,
not legislative mandates, drive that innovation."

Is that why Intel laid off 4,000 workers last spring? Is that why we
have so much competition in the Operating System and office productivity
suite markets?

Finally, the Oregon Department of Administrative Services testified.
They basically said first that they support "the concept of using open
source software, and does so today, but is unable to support the bill
without changes to the measure's language."

I look forward to working with the Department of Administrative Services
to address any concerns they may have.

Over the weekend I will post the opponent's written testimony on our web
site.

I will keep you posted.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org








Cooper

> In reality, "avoid" == "don't consider" == "prohibit purchasing" which
> goes back to the need for some minor language changes.

I disagree, my experience with government procurement is that they read
this language very carefully and read it in the most favorable light
towards the procurement of the system most favored by the procuring
agency.  Avoid means you need to say why you picked it, they won't have
to try hard to come up with a reason.

This bill if passed would not actually require any change it the
software purchased, since you can always come up with an excuse.  The
pratical effect of this biilo would be two fold, it would give "cover"
to any agency that chose and open source product so that when the
inevtable problems occur and some MS flack won;t be able get people
fired for chosing some <insert derogatory label here> instead of the
"industry standard well proven..." product from Redmond Washington.

Second it will and a hoop to jump thorough so that sometimes it may just
be easier to chose a FOSS product than the crap from MS, to offset the
effort of learning about the alternatives and educating you boss.

On Fri, 2003-04-04 at 17:02, Brian Beattie wrote:

> It says "Avoid", avoid indicates a dispreference, not a prohibition.
> 

Sorry Brian, that is not at all correct, no matter how you attempt to
twist the language the fact remains that to avoid is to not extend
consideration. The only saving grace is that the language in the bill
does stipulate that communication to entities outside of state control
is "unauthorized". The very fact that MS does disclose that their
operating system does communicate like this, and you agree to this by
using the product, then it might be construed as "authorization" and
therefor not subject to these mandates. This is, at least, as sketchy as
confusing "avoid" with "not preferred".

> agency.  Avoid means you need to say why you picked it, they won't have
> to try hard to come up with a reason.

I too have a some recent experience with government procurement. In
fact, I am the one that purchased the Linux dist for use on the ODOT
mainframe. It will be arriving next week.

> 
> This bill if passed would not actually require any change it the
> software purchased, since you can always come up with an excuse.  The
> pratical effect of this biilo would be two fold, it would give "cover"
> to any agency that chose and open source product so that when the
> inevtable problems occur and some MS flack won;t be able get people
> fired for chosing some <insert derogatory label here> instead of the
> "industry standard well proven..." product from Redmond Washington.
> 
> Second it will and a hoop to jump thorough so that sometimes it may just
> be easier to chose a FOSS product than the crap from MS, to offset the
> effort of learning about the alternatives and educating you boss.
> 

There is one more benefit to this bill. Whether it passes or not, it is
forcing MS to rethink their business practices, fix their garbage OS and
lower the cost. This is having a positive impact that's much bigger than
any of us.

Great lead-in to this comment - Ken, Cooper and all involved; You have
done an awesome service for the entire IT community at large that will
be felt for years to come. Your parents have spawned greatness - THANK
YOU!

Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>

avoid  	1: To make legally void.
	2: VOID, EXPEL
	3: a: to keep away from : SHUN

	   c: to refrain from
	4. to depart or withdraw from : LEAVE

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Sat Apr  5 10:09:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Sat Apr  5 10:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] redhat on RISC?
In-Reply-To: <E191r6k-0005fB-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E191j73-0007zw-00@bergie.net>
	 <E191r6k-0005fB-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1049566058.2946.15.camel@main>

For what it's worth, SuSE in the s390 build is labled SLES7 and SLES8.
Redhat also builds and markets an s390 and z/Series version in the 7 and
8 versions. It's doubtful that many will use these builds since they run
exclusively on the IBM mainframe environments and are pretty expensive
to support. For example, SuSE supports the SLES builds through a web
site ( not adequate for prime-time ) and Mainline offers 3rd party live
support agreements with the total support+OS package prices around ~42K
annually. Redhat builds AS for the z/Series and s/390 platforms and
fully supports it in Basic and Enterprise packages ( 12x7 or 24x7
support respectfully ), and the cost is ~15K annually.

On Sat, Apr 05, 2003 at 11:13:17AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   With Red Hat, a user's initial group is a group with that username as in
> 'tux.tux'. In Slackware, all new users are placed in an initial group of
> 'users', as in 'tux.users'.
> 
>   Does this difference make any practical difference?
> 

Yes, it does.  It allows finer control of group access.  I was used to
the old Unix way of having the primary group be 'users', but this way
allows you to things like the following:

There are accounts andy, joe, sally & thelma.  You can assign joe and
sally to the groups for andy.  Then they will have access to andy's
group-accessible files, but thelma will not.

andy

Andy Davidson	pheon at hevanet.com

On Sat, 2003-04-05 at 10:07, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> For what it's worth, SuSE in the s390 build is labled SLES7 and SLES8.
> Redhat also builds and markets an s390 and z/Series version in the 7 and
> 8 versions. It's doubtful that many will use these builds since they run
> exclusively on the IBM mainframe environments and are pretty expensive
> to support. For example, SuSE supports the SLES builds through a web
> site ( not adequate for prime-time ) and Mainline offers 3rd party live
> support agreements with the total support+OS package prices around ~42K
> annually. Redhat builds AS for the z/Series and s/390 platforms and
> fully supports it in Basic and Enterprise packages ( 12x7 or 24x7
> support respectfully ), and the cost is ~15K annually.

I believe RH also ships a PowerPC distro for IBM pSeries (nee RS/6000). 
The binaries work on Macs but the kernel and installer are specially
built for pSeries.

When I have my work laptop I use at work at home and on our network we 
have 7 systems going sometimes and they're only two of us in the house. 
I have an 8th system which was my OpenBSD firewall test system at home 
but I took it work to use as a print/time server for our Linux and 
Windows systems in the office. 

One of the problems with Linux and the BSD operating systems I'm finding 
is that they allow older systems to remain useful years after they are 
incapable of running a newer versions of Windows. This has led me to 
have a rather large cache of useful systems running in my house.
Realistically we only have 3 or 4 systems going at any one time although 
if I'm doing some upgrades or other things I'll have 6 machines going 
at once.

On Thu, 3 Apr 2003, Bill Trost wrote:

> Here's some questions ahead of time -- how do I get out of the nasty
> PowerPoint rut? How do I prepare a presentation in Squeak?

  Whether or not you squeak is up to you, but I've used MagicPoint for
presentations for several years and it works great. It may not have all the
bells and whistles of PowerPunt, but you write the script as an ASCII text
file and can display it in another virtual terminal simultaneously.
Presentation, of course, is full screen.

  At a meeting last year a co-presenter couldn't find a Windoze portable for
her presentation so we sat down at a table and I created hers (from the hard
copy) in mgp. Then she used my notebook for her talk. IIRC, the text file
was about 4K in size. Her ppt file was about 1M in size.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Sun Apr  6 11:42:03 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Sun Apr  6 11:42:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UML command line for console on a remote box
In-Reply-To: <86pto05i6g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86pto05i6g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20030406184107.GC1009@rauhaus.org>

* Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> [030405 20:07]:
>    INIT: Id "0" respawning too fast: disabled for 5 minutes
>    INIT: Id "1" respawning too fast: disabled for 5 minutes
>    INIT: Id "2" respawning too fast: disabled for 5 minutes
>    INIT: Id "c" respawning too fast: disabled for 5 minutes
>    INIT: no more processes left in this runlevel

I had the same problem, and figured out that my uml root_fs inittab was
trying to spawn gettys on ttys that didn't exist. You can confirm that
by loopback mounting your root_fs on your host machine, something like:

mount -o loop /usr/local/uml/root_fs /mnt

Then you can "tail /mnt/var/log/messages", and that should show you what
is wrong. I ended up changing the tty device names in the root_fs
inittab to ttys that actually existed. When you get them right, you'll
have an xterm pop up on your host system for each tty that has a getty
on it in the uml system.

--Stafford

From drl at drloree.com  Sun Apr  6 16:14:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun Apr  6 16:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UML command line for console on a remote box
In-Reply-To: <86he9b4bwr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86pto05i6g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <20030406184107.GC1009@rauhaus.org>  <86he9b4bwr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1049670820.1025.59.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sun, 2003-04-06 at 13:19, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Stafford" == Stafford A Rau <srau at rauhaus.org> writes:
> 
> Stafford> I had the same problem, and figured out that my uml root_fs
> Stafford> inittab was trying to spawn gettys on ttys that didn't
> Stafford> exist. You can confirm that by loopback mounting your
> Stafford> root_fs on your host machine, something like:
> 
> Stafford> mount -o loop /usr/local/uml/root_fs /mnt
> 
> Yeah, that's what I did to "fix" it.  In my case, I just commented out
> all the ttys and made sshd work instead.

You can also override this with command line parameters when you start
the uml, I use something like this to start the file "root_fs":

linux eth0=tuntap,,,192.168.0.50 con=port:9000 con1=tty:/dev/tty11 con0=tty:/dev/tty12

which directs the boot message stuff to tty12 (<ctrl>+<alt>+<F12>) on
the host, first console to tty11 (<ctrl>+<alt>+<F11>), and the rest
redirected to port 9000 on the host.  To login, just "telnet hostname
9000", even if the tuntap network isn't working.

HTH,

Derek Loree

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Apr  6 16:57:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Apr  6 16:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Listing system users
In-Reply-To: <1049668242.1167.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1049668242.1167.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1049673427.1217.1329.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-04-06 at 15:30, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> How do I list the users of my system via the command line?  I know
> `users` shows the logged in users and redhat-config-users shows all the
> system users via the gui, but haven't been able to find the command to
> list all my users via the command line.

$ awk -F: '{if ($3 >= 500) { print $1 }}' /etc/passwd

Assuming system users are those with UID < 500.  Or in a networked
environment, which may be using NIS or LDAP:

getent passwd |awk -F: '...'

Wil

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Sun Apr  6 16:58:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Listing Linux Users

This assumes that the user has a directory in /home but you can adapt
this command to suit your environment:

  cat /etc/passwd | grep /home | awk -F : '{ print $1 }'

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Apr  6 17:41:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Apr  6 17:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS inside/outside configuration?
In-Reply-To: <1049672846.1024.92.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <86znn32pu0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1049672846.1024.92.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <86k7e72l92.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Derek" == Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com> writes:

Derek> The only real drawback that I've come across using user-mode is
Derek> the lack of control over the user-mode by the host kernel.  I
Derek> can't figure out a way to have the host shutdown the user-mode
Derek> when the host gets the halt or reboot command.  

  ssh -l root uml-host-ip /sbin/halt 

If the host can secure shell to uml's root without a password
(i.e. with appropriate uml /root/.ssh/authorized_keys), that seems to
work.  Then just have that in the "stop" portion of your
/etc/init.d/uml-foo script, just like you start and stop other
services.
