On Sun, 2003-04-06 at 20:20, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I'm going to show my ignorance here.
> 
> I don't know what most of these designations are. Ate they architectures?

Yes:
  axp = DEC Alpha
  ia64 = Itanium, Intel's 64-bit CPU
  ppc = PowerPC, a RISC chip co-developed by Apple and IBM, in the   
        family of IBM's POWER architecture
  s390 = IBM Mainframe, S/390, now called the zSeries
  SPARC = Sun's architecture; actually the 32-bit is a standardized 
          architecture, ratified by one of the big standards orgs (OSI 
          or ANSI maybe?)

> It's for and old HP9000 with a DX370 160MHz cpu.

An HP-9000 is a PA-RISC processor; I dunno if there are any current
distros for it.

Wil

Debian. Debian runs on the following architectures: The Dec ALPHA
(that's the ev5 and ev56, not the new alpha), the ARM processors that
you see in lots of handhelds, the PA-RISC,
(http://www.debian.org/releases/stable/hppa/install), our friendly x86,
the Itanium (ia64), the Motorola 68k, MIPS, DEC MIPS, the PowerPC, the
s390, and the SPARC.

And, of course, NetBSD runs on it.

Then again, NetBSD runs on some toasters.

Jeff

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Apr  7 13:46:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon Apr  7 13:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Questions
In-Reply-To: <F83idc8CADAiKM10KR60001a393@hotmail.com>
References: <F83idc8CADAiKM10KR60001a393@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20030407204346.GE6520@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Young <deafphate at hotmail.com> [2003-04-07 13:39]:
> 
> I have a domain that I want to add some subdomains or virtual hosts to.  
> The main domain is registered with DNS yet it appears that the subdomains 
> also have to be registered with DNS in order for me to browse to them.  I 
> thought that apache would handle all of the sub domain information.
> 
> Any one know what setting I could have wrong, I can paste my config for the 
> virtual hosts if that is needed.

As far as I know, you do have to have the subdomains listed in the
domain for a browser to find them. 

If you have the domain "domain.com", and you put a webpage there, the
browser finds it, and apache sends it. 

If you then set up apache to serve "subdomain.domain.com", it knows
about it, but the browser won't, until you put "subdomain.domain.com" in
your dns. The reason is that as far as the 'net is concerned,
"subdomain.domain.com" doesn't exist until it's listed in your dns. 

Hope that helps. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Apr  7 14:19:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Apr  7 14:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS inside/outside configuration?
In-Reply-To: <86znn32pu0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86znn32pu0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1049750256.3338.10.camel@red>

On Sun, 2003-04-06 at 16:01, Russell Senior wrote:
> In playing with user-mode linux, I've been thinking about how to
> configure my name servers.  In the past, I've run two separate servers
> on two separate machines, one for "outside" with the public IPs and
> another one for servicing the inside machines and giving "inside"
> answers to queries.
> 
> I'd rather stick to one physical machine these days, since I lost my
> airconditioning.  Question I am pondering is whether to use the
> Bind9's view feature, or run a user-mode linux on the same physical
> machine to serve the inside machines.  Opinions?

If you use views, you only consume one IP address. If you run
two DNS daemons, you use two IP addresses - since both need to use
UDP port 53.

Of course, if you use the same BIND daemon for both your authority
server and your recursive name server, you run the risk of
cache poisoning. The best solution (with BIND) is to run two BIND
daemons (one in a UML if you choose) and have one devoted to
the authority server function using views for inside/outside
answers. The other is your recursive name server.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

> main domain is registered with DNS yet it appears that the subdomains also 
> have to be registered with DNS in order for me to browse to them.  I thought 
> that apache would handle all of the sub domain information.

Apache will handle all of the mapping sub domain to particular points in your 
web tree (if configured correctly).  The issue is that the client needs DNS to 
tell it what IP address to associate with a subdomain host name so that it 
can send the request to apache to process.  

The client cannot assume that (for example) www.subdomain.domain.samp
is at the same IP address as www.domain.samp.  So a DNS entry is required.

-- 
      Michael Rasmussen  aka  mikeraz

       http://blog.patch.com/sandbox/

If it happens twice, it's a feature.
If it happens more than twice, it's a design philosophy.



From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Apr  7 14:59:02 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon Apr  7 14:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Questions
In-Reply-To: <F83idc8CADAiKM10KR60001a393@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304070611001.6893-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Mon, 7 Apr 2003, Stephen Young wrote:

> 
> I have a domain that I want to add some subdomains or virtual hosts to.  The 
> main domain is registered with DNS yet it appears that the subdomains also 
> have to be registered with DNS in order for me to browse to them.  I thought 
> that apache would handle all of the sub domain information.

If you do not have the dns information correct for the subdomains, how is 
anyone going to know which IP addresses they resolve to?

It is possible to default all of the subdomains to a single IP, but I 
forget how to do it.  (I try not to deal with Bind, unless I absolutly 
have to.)

Talk with the people who maintain your DNS tables.

Until DNS is resolved, you can hack the domains into /etc/hosts and test 
things from the same machine.

Computerworld has an article that mentions that Rhode Island and Hawaii
are getting into the act:

http://www.computerworld.com/softwaretopics/os/story/0,10801,80053,00.html


<snip>
Sharing can be especially helpful if your software needs are different from
those of most organizations, notes Jim Willis, director of eGovernment at
the Rhode Island Department of State.

His office used open-source software to design a repository for the vast
library of content, which ranges from rules and regulations to the minutes
of municipal meetings, that the State Department must keep on hand and make
available to the general public. A colleague from the state of Hawaii heard
about Willis' work and e-mailed to ask his advice about a similar project.
That got Willis thinking that states could help one another by sharing the
open-source software they had modified for special state uses. "We're now
trying to set up [an online] repository of which state agencies are using
open source and for what projects," he says.

Although the details have yet to be ironed out, Willis plans for the states'
open-source repository to be available to everyone, so the rest of the
open-source community can benefit -- and contribute. The plan is for
Rhode Island and Hawaii to jointly create and maintain a Web site that
will archive the documentation of the work each state has done on its
open-source software. The hope is that in the future other states will
also document their work.

"Documenting our practices with the intent to share them with others
has threefold benefits," Willis notes. "We learn from the experience of
other states, we share development resources with other states, and we
have better internal documentation of our own practices. All this for
the effort of articulating our practices and documenting our internally
developed software such that it makes sense to others."
</snip>

>>>>> "Ed" == Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> writes:

Ed> If you use views, you only consume one IP address. If you run two
Ed> DNS daemons, you use two IP addresses - since both need to use UDP
Ed> port 53.

That's okay, I've got at least ... er, lets see, 192.168.0.0 to
192.168.255.255, uh 2 carry the four, uh, 65536 to work with. ;-).

Ed> Of course, if you use the same BIND daemon for both your authority
Ed> server and your recursive name server, you run the risk of cache
Ed> poisoning. The best solution (with BIND) is to run two BIND
Ed> daemons (one in a UML if you choose) and have one devoted to the
Ed> authority server function using views for inside/outside
Ed> answers. The other is your recursive name server.

I guess Bind can do that too:

  view "internal" {
     recursion yes;
  };

  view "external" {
     recursion no;
  };

On Mon, 2003-04-07 at 18:28, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Ed" == Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> writes:
> 
> Ed> If you use views, you only consume one IP address. If you run two
> Ed> DNS daemons, you use two IP addresses - since both need to use UDP
> Ed> port 53.
> 
> That's okay, I've got at least ... er, lets see, 192.168.0.0 to
> 192.168.255.255, uh 2 carry the four, uh, 65536 to work with. ;-).

I keep forgetting that most people have no need to have their
recursive name servers available to the outside as I do.



> Ed> Of course, if you use the same BIND daemon for both your authority
> Ed> server and your recursive name server, you run the risk of cache
> Ed> poisoning. The best solution (with BIND) is to run two BIND
> Ed> daemons (one in a UML if you choose) and have one devoted to the
> Ed> authority server function using views for inside/outside
> Ed> answers. The other is your recursive name server.
> 
> I guess Bind can do that too:
> 
>   view "internal" {
>      recursion yes;
>   };
> 
>   view "external" {
>      recursion no;
>   };

That should do it if it works as advertised. I'm still nervous
about one daemon handling both functions so I usually separate
them, have them run as non-root, and chroot them to their own
directories. Paranoid? Maybe.

Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Apr  8 12:54:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Apr  8 12:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] smtpd failures
In-Reply-To: <20030408185941.GA3748@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304081248410.27928-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Michael Montagne wrote:

> It never gets to Exchange.  I believe the "peer" is easystreet
> sending on our mail.  They do keep retrying....and getting rejected.  
> What does "fd" mean?

The 'client fd' is the file descriptor used to read from the tcp
socket.

The puzzling part is the 'Connection reset by peer' error, which
typically indicates that the remote application halted operation
unexpectedly. You'd see that if, for instance, the remote MTA died in
the middle of sending the DATA portion of the message.

You see an analagous messages in web logs if a remote user presses her 
browser's Stop button before it downloaded the whole page from your 
server.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From alan at clueserver.org  Tue Apr  8 14:07:01 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Tue Apr  8 14:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat Enterprise ES ISO's
In-Reply-To: <EX-20030408-160016-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304080516520.13159-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Daggett, Steve wrote:

> 
>   I've been trying to reach Red Hat sales for two weeks.  I'm not getting any emails or callbacks from their staff.  
> 
>   I'm in a time crunch.  I need to make sure my kernel modules will compile against their the "Enterprise Linux ES" kernel.  Does anyone have some "Enterprise ES" ISO's or CD's I can grab?  


Have they even released the ES product?

The "Advanced Server" product was a hacked version of 7.2.  (2.4.9 
kernel.)

The "enterprise" code seems to be pretty conservative when it comes to 
versions.

Redhat 7.3 is running 2.4.18 with modifications.

Redhat 8.0 is running 2.4.18 as well.

Redhat 9 is a weird beast and runs 2.4.20 with a bunch of backports from 
2.5.x.  (Enough that it is kind of both and neither.)

If your code works for any of the stock 2.4 Redhat kernels, you should be 
OK.  I would especially test if you run with the Redhat 9 kernel, as it 
has the most knarly changes.  (nptl thread library and scheduler changes.)

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Apr  8 14:52:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Apr  8 14:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Questions
In-Reply-To: <F5ThfFE8tjc0RiLx3uy00015d65@hotmail.com>
References: <F5ThfFE8tjc0RiLx3uy00015d65@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20030408214930.GE8140@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Young <deafphate at hotmail.com> [2003-04-08 14:14]:
> Say my documentroot is /var/www/, could possibly add foo.liquidwire.org and 
> have foo.liquidwire.org work without messing with DNS.  I haven't had a 
> chance to try it out, just thought of it actually hehe.  Any comments ?  
> (This is the first time I have used apache so I am a little slow with it)

Apache doesn't care if the names exist in DNS or not. It's the browser
that will have the problem finding the site if it doesn't exist in DNS. 

If you point your browser at somename.firewire.com, and "somename" isn't
listed in the "firewire.com" domain table, the browser doesn't know
where to find it, so it gives up.

Short answer: There isn't a shortcut. You must add them to DNS.

Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

On Tuesday 08 April 2003 14:49, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Stephen Young <deafphate at hotmail.com> [2003-04-08 14:14]:
> > Say my documentroot is /var/www/, could possibly add foo.liquidwire.org
> > and have foo.liquidwire.org work without messing with DNS.  I haven't had
> > a chance to try it out, just thought of it actually hehe.  Any comments ?
> > (This is the first time I have used apache so I am a little slow with it)
>
> Apache doesn't care if the names exist in DNS or not. It's the browser
> that will have the problem finding the site if it doesn't exist in DNS.
>
> If you point your browser at somename.firewire.com, and "somename" isn't
> listed in the "firewire.com" domain table, the browser doesn't know
> where to find it, so it gives up.
>
> Short answer: There isn't a shortcut. You must add them to DNS.

From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Apr  8 20:42:02 2003

Russ has got it. If you want to type an address in the address bar and
have it go there, it must be in the DNS tables. Lots of sites, including
my credit union, do not have their DNS set to do this. Try
http://www.ptcu.org and http://ptcu.org. the latter does not have a DNS
entry, so you can't get to it without the www.

If you have access to /etc/hosts on the machine doing the browsing, you
can add it there and avoid the of-site DNS lookup, but that's the only
way I know of.

Mike

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Apr  8 21:45:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Apr  8 21:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Questions
In-Reply-To: <1049854372.25151.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <F5ThfFE8tjc0RiLx3uy00015d65@hotmail.com>
	 <1049854372.25151.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1049863448.3342.239.camel@red>

On Tue, 2003-04-08 at 19:12, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> Russ has got it. If you want to type an address in the address bar and
> have it go there, it must be in the DNS tables. Lots of sites, including
> my credit union, do not have their DNS set to do this. Try
> http://www.ptcu.org and http://ptcu.org. the latter does not have a DNS
> entry, so you can't get to it without the www.
> 
> If you have access to /etc/hosts on the machine doing the browsing, you
> can add it there and avoid the of-site DNS lookup, but that's the only
> way I know of.


Most of what you say is true. However, the Web server still needs to
know the name if you're doing name-based virtual hosting. Using your
example, if www.ptcu.org is a virtual host and you don't also tell
the virtual server about the name ptcu.org, it will not work even
though the DNS has both names. If you're running Apache, you'll
need to have these in your virtual host configuration:

ServerName   www.ptcu.org
ServerAlias  ptcu.org


If your Web server is running www.ptcu.org as the main server
(not a virtual host), then what you say is completely true.

Ed

authenticate as?

For example, Bob goes to mysite.com and is prompted with a typical
htaccess login box.  He logs in as graphics/password and is taken to
mysite.com/graphics.  But if he logs in using accounting/password, he's
taken to mysite.com/accounting.  If someone goes directly to one of the
URLs, then it would also prompt them for a login, of course.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Apr  9 17:26:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] XML tags/DTD for literature
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304091657180.16102-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Rich,

DocBook has an entire bibliographic subset:

  http://www.docbook.org/tdg/en/html/bibliography.html

I'm not into editor wars, but the psgml mode in emacs makes DocBook 
editing much simpler than it might otherwise be.

Also, I understand that the OpenOffice.org 1.1 beta can spew DocBook, 
but I haven't tried it.

My bias is to go with the XML schema for DocBook, not SGML. In the 
short run, you won't be able to use the Jade tools, but I think the 
tool support will be better for XML in the long run.

I'm heavy into DocBook XSL stylesheet customization these days, so I'm 
probably way more into this stuff than I ought to be...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> Is there a way to redirect a user to a specific location based on who they

Yes. You'd have to have some script (perl, python, php or ???) examine
the environment, and react accordingly. 

I use these variables on occasion:

$user = $ENV{REMOTE_USER};
$userip = $ENV{REMOTE_ADDR};
$userhost = $ENV{REMOTE_HOST};

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Apr 10 09:13:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Apr 10 09:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892 Update
Message-ID: <1049995147.5038.3146.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Friends, 

I attended the meeting yesterday at the Capitol meeting to help hammer
out a compromise on HB 2892, the Open Source bill. 

Proponents of the bill comprised Rep. Barnhart, Ken Barber, Paul Nelson
with Multnomah ESD, and myself.

Opponents comprised of a representative of Microsoft, the Initiative for
Software Choice, legal council, and the Dept. of Administrative
Services.

The bill is currently in the amendment phase. It seems that there is
sufficient need to warrant a bill over simply modifying the current
Oregon statutes. 

It turns out that language already exists in the Oregon Statutes
discussing "Open Systems." It was expressed that in this area of the
bill simply modifying the existing Oregon Statutes may prove more
flexible in the long term. Statutory recognition of Open Source, in
conjunction with the bill itself, was deemed by DAS as the most
appropriate way to achieve the desired "leveling" affect.

DAS has offered to propose the amendments that we discussed. I am
pleased with our current progress and look forward to reviewing DAS's
proposed amendments.

Finally, Rep. Krummel took a few moments to oversee our progress. He
"laid it down" and expressed that he really would like to see a level
playing field and open standards with the State's IT procurement
process. Those of you who live Wilsonville are lucky to have him. 

I will keep you posted including a complete transcript of the DAS's
proposed changes to both the Oregon Statute and the bill itself.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

From shahms at shahms.com  Thu Apr 10 13:42:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Thu Apr 10 13:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892 Update
In-Reply-To: <1049995147.5038.3146.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
References: <1049995147.5038.3146.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
Message-ID: <1050007253.17994.10.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Thu, 2003-04-10 at 10:19, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Friends, 
> 
> I attended the meeting yesterday at the Capitol meeting to help hammer
> out a compromise on HB 2892, the Open Source bill. 
> 
> Proponents of the bill comprised Rep. Barnhart, Ken Barber, Paul Nelson
> with Multnomah ESD, and myself.

Sorry to correct you again, but Paul Nelson is with Riverdale School
District, Eric Harrison (also present and a proponent of the bill) is
with the Multnomah ESD.

> Opponents comprised of a representative of Microsoft, the Initiative for
> Software Choice, legal council, and the Dept. of Administrative
> Services.

So, Microsoft had two representatives present? ;-)

Also, from what I've heard, while the DAS is "officially" against the
bill in its current form, they are generally for an amended bill that
makes it easier to get Open Source (or any products without a vendor)
purchased through the regular channels (which currently have no concept
of Open Source mostly because the purchasing process focuses on
comparing offers from *vendors* without regard to comparing *products*
that don't have any real vendor behind them).

Still, the most important thing that will (hopefully) come from this
bill is the mandate on providing data in an open format.  I, as a
citizen, feel I should not be required to purchase a proprietary product
to access information made available by the state.  As a government, it
is their duty to provide the information in a format that is accessible
to all its citizens, regardless of their philosophical leanings or (more
importantly) economic standing.  I'm sorry if the Microsofties feel that
this will somehow damage their "competitive advantage" by eliminating
the possibility for vendor lock-in in public institutions.  But that's
the way the cookie crumbles; as a private institution, you have no right
to use the state to coerce the public into purchasing your product.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 9 install on Asus P4GE-V

First off here is the error:
CPU 0: machine check exception 0000000000000004
Bank 0: A200000084010400

My hardware in test mode is all new:
Asus P4GE-V
2  512M DIM DDR PC2100
Western Digital 80GB drive.

I get this error when installing RH 8 (my download and burn), 9 ( a friends
download and burn) and Mandrake 9 from home burned CDs.  I have tried text
mode and still get the error.  The error consistently locks the computer
when the install goes to format the drives or is writing the packages to the
disk.

At first I thought it was memory, so I exchanged it, no joy.  I yanked out
all network cards and have only one hard drive. I removed my DVD-CDR and
used a plain old CD, no joy. I have switch memory to different banks and
tried one module, no joy.

So I thought it was the main board and was about to exchange it when I got
the idea to try my original WinNT disk.  Well to my surprise it installed.
Well then I tried my DVD for Mandrake 8.1 Pro-Suite and it installed.

My Mandrake 9 CDs installed flawlessly on my IBM A21p so I know I can
download and make ISO CDs that work.  I also had my RH 8 installed on this
box in a software RAID but I wanted to try RH 9 and change the RAID
configuration so the RH 8 disks worked once, but now it fails.

My questions: 

What does the error mean?
Is are there incompatibilities in home burned ISO images that affect
hardware?
Suse says that their disto works on this MoBo, should I try that?
Will commercial CDs of RH 9 work?

I'm going bonkers with this and have spent about a week futzing with this
box on and off.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Apr 10 20:33:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Apr 10 20:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 9 install on Asus P4GE-V
In-Reply-To: <003701c2ffd8$2ab810c0$e300a8c0@launi.com>
References: <003701c2ffd8$2ab810c0$e300a8c0@launi.com>
Message-ID: <20030411033037.GA27081@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Launi <launi at zaramyth.net> [2003-04-10 20:14]:
> First off here is the error:
> CPU 0: machine check exception 0000000000000004
> Bank 0: A200000084010400

Looks like a memory error. When you switched the memory to different
banks, did the error move?

If not, I'd suspect either the memory slot on the MB, or the chipset on
the mainboard. 

This web page (http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue77/lg_tips.html search
for 'cpu0') lists that it may be a memory error too. 

> At first I thought it was memory, so I exchanged it, no joy.  I yanked out
> all network cards and have only one hard drive. I removed my DVD-CDR and
> used a plain old CD, no joy. I have switch memory to different banks and
> tried one module, no joy.
> 
> So I thought it was the main board and was about to exchange it when I got
> the idea to try my original WinNT disk.  Well to my surprise it installed.
> Well then I tried my DVD for Mandrake 8.1 Pro-Suite and it installed.

It could be a flaky connector on the MB. 

> What does the error mean?

According to more googling, there's a decoder out there. This page
(http://www.cs.helsinki.fi/linux/linux-kernel/2002-03/1336.html) tells
you more about it. 

> Is are there incompatibilities in home burned ISO images that affect
> hardware?

Not to my knowledge. However, I have run across ISOs that only seem to
burn properly at 4x and lower.

Sure looks like memory to me.  If the error is exactly the same after
you swapped memory sticks, maybe you have bad cache?  Have you run
MemTest86?

> Is are there incompatibilities in home burned ISO images that affect
> hardware?

Not that I've come across, and I cannot imagine a scenario that would.
 
> Suse says that their disto works on this MoBo, should I try that?
> Will commercial CDs of RH 9 work?

The commercial CD's will work about as well as the ones that you have
burned, there may be some _very_ old drives that the commercial pressing
will work on that the burned copies won't, but that is an all or nothing
deal, either it works, or it doesn't.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 11 08:22:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 11 08:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntp isn't keeping the clock accurate
In-Reply-To: <1050073204.1103.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304110812350.8815-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 11 Apr 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> ntpd runs on my RH8.0 workstation, but the time drifts over an hour
> a day.
> 
> It starts at boot, is running whenever I check it, but the clock
> varies wildly. I can have it log in manually and it corrects the
> time, but it won't do it automagically.

Your ntpd is probably not syncing to a remote clock. Run ntpdc and 
type 'peers' at the prompt, e.g.,

[heinlein at pecos heinlein]$ ntpdc
ntpdc> peers
     remote           local      st poll reach  delay   offset    disp
=======================================================================
=LOCAL(0)        127.0.0.1       10   64  377 0.00000  0.000000 0.00095
*caesar.cs.wisc. 10.58.11.14      2 1024  377 0.07771  0.009911 0.01483
=br3.umtnet.umt. 10.58.11.14      2 1024  377 0.07413 -0.006702 0.01483

If all you see is the LOCAL peers, then you're not in touch with any 
remote servers.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Fri, 11 Apr 2003, Kelly wrote:

> Second, I'd like to know (armed with my list of government
> representatives) what I, a voter/constituent/girl with an opinion can do
> to help make this a reality. I have internet and fax and phone capability,
> and if takes any of that paper stuff I think I have some around here

Kelly,

  The most important -- and meaningful -- thing to do is find your
representative and senator, then send each an e-mail (or letter)
beginning with the words, "I strongly support HB-2892 and I want to to
support is as my {representative|senator}".

  I was testifying in support of a bill at a senate hearing this past
Wednesday and discussing the process with one of the trade association's
lobbyists. The key is to make a loud noise. The louder the noise (i.e., the
more constituents from whom a legislator gets input) the greater attention
paid. Constituents -- not professional (or amateur) lobbyists -- vote.
Politicians are genetically selected for perpetuation of their elected
office. So, they pay very close attention to those who can re-elect them.

  If you've already done the above, send another e-mail with the same
starting sentence and add, "I want to remind you to continue supporting this
legislation as you focus on all the important issues that come to your
attention." Doesn't hurt to let them know you're paying attention.

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 11 09:22:10 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 11 09:22:10 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntp isn't keeping the clock accurate
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304110911290.22417-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304110916450.15172-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 11 Apr 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> >      remote           local      st poll reach  delay   offset    disp
> > =======================================================================
> > =LOCAL(0)        127.0.0.1       10   64  377 0.00000  0.000000 0.00095
> 
>   Why the local? I have only remotes:

It's just a hack: the clock can sync with itself just in case remote 
peers are unavailable. In /etc/ntp.conf, I declare the local host to 
have a high (i.e., low-priority) stratum number:

  server          127.127.1.0
  fudge           127.127.1.0 stratum 10

That way, ntpd never loses touch with all peers. There's always one 
around, even if it's itself. :-) Once the remote, higher-priority 
servers are contacted again, ntpd will re-sync with them.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

>   >different banks, did the error move?

That supports the mainboard theory. Could be a dirty memory slot. Could
be something more. 

>   >It could be a flaky connector on the MB. 
> 
> Why do WinNT and my Mandrake DVD work on the hardware?

I have seen Windows of all flavors install on hardware that is known
defective. I've then seen these same systems run for several weeks, and
then fail with some BSOD. 

The fact that Mandrake worked says that it may be an intermittent issue.
You may have a memory slot that just meets specs, and then thermal
expansion sets in, and it has a problem. 

There are many reasons this could be happening.

And I've spent an entire day (might have been two, except I got lucky at
the last minute) installing Windows NT 4 on a P4B (I think, don't
remember right now) motherboard because the IDE drivers that shipped
with NT didn't work correctly (i.e. were horribly horribly broken) and
were too dumb to fall back to PIO mode long enough for me to install the
correct ones from the CD-ROM that shipped with the motherboard. (Yes, I
manually disabled DMA, but it didn't help)

NT would install fine (well, after a really long time and a lot of
interaction from me; Windows is easier to install than Linux? HA! Never
has been, never will be) because the install drivers and the "working"
drivers were different.  Boot it up, any heavy disk activity would hang
the machine.  So you think, well, wait to install the server software
until you've updated the drivers.  All well and good except for one
small fact: installing the drivers involves heavy disk activity and
would hang the machine.  The problem was doubly bad installing from the
CD-ROM ;-).  
Compounding this irritation was the fact that the machine hung halfway
through installing IDE drivers, meaning that any future boot would
involve a BSOD very early on and without IDE drivers, recovery was
essentially impossible. This, inevitably, lead to another NT install
with the bloody mandatory format!!!! (why do NTFS filesystems take
FOREVER to format? ext2, ext3, ReiserFS, etc. take almost no time at all
unless you check for bad blocks).

So, sure, Windows might install on defective hardware, but it seems to
have a problem doing so on perfectly adequate hardware.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 11 11:01:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 11 11:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntp isn't keeping the clock accurate
In-Reply-To: <1050082929.1073.6.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304111055000.15172-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 11 Apr 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> [root at rhws sbin]# ./ntpdc
> ntpdc> peers
>      remote           local      st poll reach  delay   offset    disp
> =======================================================================
> =time.nist.gov   5.0.0.0         16   64    0 0.00000  0.000000 0.00000
> =clock.via.net   5.0.0.0         16   64    0 0.00000  0.000000 0.00000

The '5.0.0.0' local address is the key: ntpd is unable to reach the 
remote hosts.

For troubleshooting, make sure

* you can ping those hosts

* your client has permission to sync with them:

  ntpd -q time.nist.gov
  ntpd -q clock.via.net

* you don't have a packet filter rule that's blocking ntp traffic

> Note that /usr/sbin does not appear to be in my path, so I have to
> enter the ./ to make it run. I'm logged into X as a user, but I su'd
> to root for this check.

Typically, you don't need to be root to run ntpdc.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Mike,

You probably executed "su" instead of "su -", which means that your root 
session didn't pick up root's environment and, hence, didn't have /usr/sbin 
in its path.  See the su man page for more info.

I now return you to your ntpd thread.

Mark

On Fri, Apr 11, 2003 at 10:42:09AM -0700, Mike De La Mater typed:
> [root at rhws sbin]# ./ntpdc
> ntpdc> peers
>      remote           local      st poll reach  delay   offset    disp
> =======================================================================
> =time.nist.gov   5.0.0.0         16   64    0 0.00000  0.000000 0.00000
> =clock.via.net   5.0.0.0         16   64    0 0.00000  0.000000 0.00000
> ntpdc>
> 
> Note that /usr/sbin does not appear to be in my path, so I have to enter
> the ./ to make it run. I'm logged into X as a user, but I su'd to root
> for this check.


Mike, Note that the "reach" column has a value of 0.  This means that you
are not actually contacting those servers.

You should see something like:

       remote           refid      st t when poll reach   delay   offset    disp
  ==============================================================================
  *stjohn.mainecoo prowlingtabby.m  2 u   30 1024  377    84.18   -6.820    2.58
  +bdsl.66.13.45.2 usno.pa-x.dec.c  2 u  532 1024  377    61.20    3.168    9.81
  +mcs.anl.gov     ntp0.mcs.anl.go  2 u  147 1024  377   177.38  -35.110   11.70


the 377 indicates full connectivity.  If your clock is too far off you won't 
be able to synronize with the remote servers.

From gherteg at herteg.net  Fri Apr 11 13:28:02 2003
From: gherteg at herteg.net (Geoffrey Herteg)
Date: Fri Apr 11 13:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 9 install on Asus P4GE-V
In-Reply-To: <003701c2ffd8$2ab810c0$e300a8c0@launi.com>
References: <003701c2ffd8$2ab810c0$e300a8c0@launi.com>
Message-ID: <20030411202731.GA10065@newcastle.devrandom.net>

This is a followup to a private email I sent to Launi last night...

After getting to work this morning I consulted the Word of Intel (a.k.a.
Intel SMD, Vol. 3).  Turns out the MCE Status register might be indicating
a bad microcode patch checksum, rather than just a bad processor state and
fatal error (the IA32_MCx_STATUS register seems to indicate a simple status
error 0x4, which is the bad uCode patch error).

This could explain why NT loaded, but not some of the newer distributions.
The newer kernels may be trying to load a bad microcode patch into the
processor during boot.

Tried something older than RH8, or compiling the newest kernel on a
different box and booting it off a floppy?

- Geoff

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 11 13:48:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 11 13:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ntp isn't keeping the clock accurate
In-Reply-To: <86smso6ch6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304111329470.15172-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 11 Apr 2003, Russell Senior wrote:

> What benefit is there in syncing with itself?  Surely clock A and
> clock A are _already_ in sync.  I think this needs a little more
> explanation.

Right. Somewhat unusually, ntpd can be (and often is) simultaneously a
server and a client.

In the typical case, you're doing two things with the local clock
fudge:

1. telling ntpd-as-server to activate the local clock and set its 
   stratum

2. telling ntpd-as-client that the local ntpd-as-server is the 
   fallback choice.

ntpd is typically configured to keep a drift file that constitutes
ntpd's best guess as to how the local hardware clock gets skewed over
time.

The drift file is written, but not consulted, when ntpd acts as client 
to a higher-stratum server.

When no remote server is available, ntpd will sync back to itself, but 
local-ntpd-as-server will consult the drift file, which presumably is 
a good guess as to local skew, so that local-ntpd-as-client can get 
the benefit.

In other words, the local ntpd-as-server, aided by the drift record, 
ends up being the "remote" peer for ntpd-as-client.

That's my understanding, anyway.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Apr 11 13:50:03 2003
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)

Subject: [PLUG] Sent Mail + Postfix
Message-ID: <20030411154930.126e1515.jason@vancleve.com>

For years I've been scratching my balding head over the problem of
saving old emails, so they can be referenced and searched.  It's hard
enough trying to convert one's email archives for use with a different
client; but now I find myself wanting to receive email here on my
workstation and onto my laptop as well (you know, via WiFi while sipping
coffee somewhere).  Of course I can leave incoming mail on the server
long enough to grab it with both clients, which I do.  But what about
sent emails?  How can I keep all those archived in both places?  I
probably search my sent mail as often as any other.

Having just installed Spamassassin, I have much of the postfix
configuration still fresh in my head.  Is there, then, a postfix
solution for doing this?

The two clients in question are Mozilla on my lap and Sylpheed on the
workstation; so the mailbox formats are different, to begin with.  From
what I learned installing spamassassin, perhaps I could use a postfix
filter to save my outgoing mail somehow, or forward it back to myself
maybe (so it becomes inbound mail).  It may be nice to save it on the
server, since that would be a more permanent and reliable
archive--except that then I'd be archiving all my spam and attachments,
and there would be little organization to it.

So I'm just looking for suggestions.  Anyone ever tried this?

Thanx,

--Jason Van Cleve

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Apr 11 14:25:03 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

On Fri, 2003-04-11 at 15:49, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> For years I've been scratching my balding head over the problem of
> saving old emails, so they can be referenced and searched.  It's hard
> enough trying to convert one's email archives for use with a different
> client; but now I find myself wanting to receive email here on my
> workstation and onto my laptop as well (you know, via WiFi while sipping
> coffee somewhere).  Of course I can leave incoming mail on the server
> long enough to grab it with both clients, which I do.  But what about
> sent emails?  How can I keep all those archived in both places?  I
> probably search my sent mail as often as any other.

I keep all my mail on my server and access it only through IMAP, using
Cyrus IMAP on the backend.  This lets me access mail through any MUA
that supports IMAP, which is almost all of them.  MUA will also let you
use a folder on the IMAP server as your 'outbox', so that's also stored
centrally.  IMAP also has an "off-line" feature, which lets you download
the mail, disconnect, then sync back up later.  Of course, you need an
MUA that supports it too.

missing Date headers which makes sorting chronologically
dissatisfying.

> But Mr. Senior has reservations.  Can we get some more opinions on the
> POP3 vs. IMAP debate in this thread?  Can I run both at once with the
> same postfix install?  Is IMAP slower on the client than POP?  Is the
> date header thing really a problem?  I'm willing to install Cyrus if

> 
> Thanks agin',
> 
> --Jason Van Cleve

The MTA (postfix) has nothing to do with the MUA.  You can happily run a
pop3 and imap server together, provided they're set up correctly ;-)

IMAP tends to be faster on the client because the client doesn't need to
download all of the messages all at once.  In fact, I doubt if I've
*ever* downloaded the bodies of 75% of my PLUG mail, simply because the
subject didn't interest me.  IMAP is designed in such a way that the
typical IMAP client only downloads the message headers, waiting to fetch
the bodies until you're actually ready to read them.

Cyrus is certainly worthwhile, given that the other popular option is
from Washington University and therefore falls under the old axiom
"avoid software produced by UW or WU."
(And yes, pine does qualify as its authors have routinely ignored
security complaints, but I digress).

There are other IMAP options that may be more suited to your
environment, Cyrus works best on a dedicated mail server without user
accounts, while some of the others require user accounts be present.

Please, lets all make the world a better place and kill off POP3.


-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

Well put, Shahms.

I've been using Courier-IMAP at home. It reads mail stored in maildir 
format, which Postfix and Exim both support. I use Fetchmail to pull 
mail off my ISP's POP3 box and deliver it to my mail server to avoid 
using a POP3 client. IMAP clients are plentiful, including a few 
web-based mail clients that don't suck, such as Squirrelmail. Most can 
use SSL tunneled IMAP / IMAPS.

Once you get used to IMAP, POP3 will give you a nasty rash.

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Fri Apr 11 17:00:03 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Fri Apr 11 17:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sent Mail + Postfix
In-Reply-To: <1050096266.987.141.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20030411154930.126e1515.jason@vancleve.com>
	 <1050096266.987.141.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1050105501.1317.181.camel@zadie>

> I keep all my mail on my server and access it only through IMAP, using
> Cyrus IMAP on the backend.  This lets me access mail through any MUA
> that supports IMAP, which is almost all of them.  MUA will also let you
> use a folder on the IMAP server as your 'outbox', so that's also stored
> centrally.  IMAP also has an "off-line" feature, which lets you download
> the mail, disconnect, then sync back up later.  Of course, you need an
> MUA that supports it too.
> 
> Wil

As this is my main objection to IMAP, I have to ask: can you reference
any clients that do this?

I find that it's much more convenient for me, since I generally read all
of my email (or at least skim it) and since I don't generally have a
particularly fast connection to my email servers, that it's far more
convenient to tell Evolution to go get all my email, and come back to it
10 minutes later, rather than having it get all the headers, then having
to wait 20-30 seconds per email. 

IMAP is, however a more intelligent protocol (or implementations are
more intelligent), as when I was using IMAP, I never had the problem of
a client downloading the same email twice from the server, which I get
all the time with POP3 (proxies REALLY confuse most pop3 implementations
unless you always access your email from one place through the proxy)

Jeff

Ken,

I apologize if I have offended you. I encourage you to take a look as
DAS's standards document here:

  http://spr.das.state.or.us/standoc.pdf

>From this document you can clearly see that their "Selected Standards"
for Operating Systems are, "GUI, DOS, Windows 98, and Windows 2000;"
their "standard" productivity suite includes "Office 95, Office 97, and
Perfect Office." While the document does not address document standards
directly, it is reasonable to assume .doc, .xls, and .mdb on the client
side, and NDS, Exchange database, etc. on the server side.

What I am proposing is not a huge amendment. This "single word"
amendment calls only for the standard to be published to qualify as
"open."  This helps ensure that the State's data is protected over the
long term; it means that a developer 10 years from now can use a tool
(or build one) that can read the data because the data conforms to a
published standard. 

Further, a system that conforms to a published open standard is less
likely to contain code that "phones home," potentially compromising the
security of the State's data. It still allows the flexibility for
"cookies," for example because they are documented as a standard by the
W3C.

This is important to me, Ken, because I have had to walk into my boss's
office before and say, "we can't make a simple but critical change to
the production inventory tracking system because the software vendor
doesn't support our platform anymore, our consultants can't change the
system without the source code and the company has refused to release it
to us under any circumstances."

Again, I stress that I support the rest of DAS's amendments so this
should not be a "show stopper." I am confident that together we can see
this to a beneficial outcome. 


Sincerely,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Apr 12 07:39:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Apr 12 07:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] "NETFILTER_DEBUG messages go where?" or "Where are the
 knobs on this syslog.conf thingie???"
In-Reply-To: <86y92g2pkt.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304120731330.16201-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 11 Apr 2003, Russell Senior wrote:

> Nothing is showing up, so I guess there must be another knob
> somewhere.  Hints anyone?

Russell,

Take a peek in iptables(8) and look for the LOG target along with the 
attendant --log-level and --log-prefix options.

If, by way of a trivial example, your INPUT table's default policy is
DROP, then your rules might look like

  iptables -A INPUT -p all  -i lo -j ACCEPT
  # other accept rules
  iptables -A INPUT -m limit --limit 12/m \
           -j LOG --log-level INFO --log-prefix "DROP: "
  iptables -P INPUT DROP

This particular LOG rule limits the number of log entries to 12 per
minute, to avoid a DOS based on log flooding. YMMV.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

Russell> somewhere.  Hints anyone?

Yeah, I know about the LOG target.  I want to know where the
CONFIG_NETFILTER_DEBUG printk's are going.  But, also, thanks for
bringing up the LOG target, because it made me think of a way I can
look to see what is going on ... but it doesn't answer my original
question.

I am beginning to think that there is a problem in recent 2.4.x
kernels (including 2.4.21-pre7) between the netfilter stuff and
"advanced routing" (? la policy routing).  It appears that DNAT'd
connection replies are getting routed _before_ their source address is
translated back.  This breaks source address based routing rules (see
iproute2's "ip rule from <foo> table <bar>").  Normal source address
based routing works fine, but DNAT in that context seems to break.  My
understanding is that the DNAT'd connections should be translated
before routing takes place, both inbound and outbound.  Trying to
drill down to find out what is going wrong.  I thought it was working
before, but am now wondering if maybe it just worked for me by
accident.

Judges do not always ``look it up" in a Webster's Collegate dictionary.
Most -- if not all -- will consult Black's law Dictionary. My copy --
admittedly an old version -- has two definitions for the word ``open":
as a verb --

``To render accessible, visible, or available; to submit or subject to
examination, inquiry or review, by the removal of restrictions or
impediments."

and as an adjective --

``Patent; visible; apparent; notorious; not clandestine; not closed,
settled, fixed, or terminated. Pratt v. Bloggs, 171 Ky. 106,
186 S.W. 901, 902; Dale v. Hartson (D.C.) 289 F. 493, 495."

Black's also provides definitions for the terms ``open a case",
``open a credit", ``open a street or highway", ``open bids", ``open court",
``open fields or meadows", ``open season" & ``open theft."

Does the proposed bill provide a definition of the term ``open source"
that means substantially software that is provided with the source code,
& the user is allowed to modified that source code to her/his benefit?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Apr 12 15:49:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat Apr 12 15:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A net admin question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304121539190.30064-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I understand that linux -- as with all unices -- can operate in both
peer-to-peer and client-server network modes. For many -- if not most -- of
the end-user apps we use here (e.g., OO.o and gnucash) the client-server
mode is more desirable because there's only one copy of the executable
installed and everyone works off of that. Easier to maintain and so on. In
prinicple, at least.

  However, a lot of end-user apps have their binaries installed (by 'make
install' or by a package manager) into /usr/bin and /usr/lib. I don't know
how, in this case, to make those binaries executable on other hosts. What I
end up doing is installing (and upgrading) a copy on each host.

  Trying to export /usr from the "server" host doesn't work well because
there's no way of nfs-mounting it on another, client, host. And I don't know
of a way to install the OS _without_ /usr/bin.

  I'm sure that I've missed something very simple all these years, but since
I just upgraded gnucash from 1.6.6 to 1.8.2 on two machines the question
came up again: just how is such an application installed once and used
across the network?

TIA,

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Apr 12 16:22:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Apr 12 16:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A net admin question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304121539190.30064-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304121613140.16201-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Sat, 12 Apr 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I'm sure that I've missed something very simple all these years, but
> since I just upgraded gnucash from 1.6.6 to 1.8.2 on two machines
> the question came up again: just how is such an application
> installed once and used across the network?

Rich,

Do you want to the application to execute and display on each 
workstation, or is it within bounds for it just to display?

If the latter, then just use ssh, e.g.,

  [workstation]$ ssh -f serverhost soffice

Or, with less security

  [workstation]$ telnet serverhost
  [serverhost]$ export DISPLAY=workstation:0.0
  [serverhost]$ sofffice

If the former, then you either

* install the binaries, libs, and resources on each machine
* install the binaries, libs, and resources in a nfs directory

The situation is tough when you're dealing with just a couple hosts. 
On a larger network, it's easier to justify the time needed to build a 
package (deb, rpm, ...) of the app in question. On a two- or three- 
node network, it's harder to justify the packaging time.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From scott_list at mischko.com  Sat Apr 12 17:07:02 2003
From: scott_list at mischko.com (Scott Chapman)

On Saturday 12 April 2003 16:46, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 12 Apr 2003, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > Do you want to the application to execute and display on each
> > workstation, or is it within bounds for it just to display?
>
> Paul,
>
>   If two of us are working simultaneously -- on different data files,
> obviously -- then it needs to execute twice, no?

Linux will typically share code in memory so it's run twice but not using as 
much memory as if it was actually run twice.  Did that make sense?!

You can telnet/ssh to a machine on the LAN and run the app there with the 
display being on the PC in front of you.  So, it's running on the Server and 
being displayed on the Client.

You should also check out the Linux Terminal Server Project (www.ltsp.org).

Your post brings up one of the primary disadvantages of Peer-to-Peer 
networking - maintaining seperate copies all over the place.  Client-Server 
computing gives the huge advantage of central administration (typically in 
one place, not many). Thin clients are the epitome of this model where the 
client doesn't even need its own hard drive.

Scott

Can't imagine that "restart" does something different than "stop" "start"
The script /etc/rc.d/init.d/network case statement does the same thing

  	restart|reload)
         	cd $CWD
         	$0 stop
         	$0 start
         	;;

Unless a matter of microseconds makes a difference to the hardware--
not to rule out the metaphysical space that occupies a CPU's thoughts 
bewteen 2 subsequent calls.


/sbin/service is a small shell script that does what you typed above with a 
little sanity checking.

I take it the question is how to renew the dhcp lease.  Maybe `killall 
dhcpcd -HUP`  (substitute the name of your dhcp client.)  When this starts 
driving you insane, you can

# grep -r 192.168.0.0 /etc

To see where your old unwanted ip is hiding out. and start fumegating.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Apr 12 21:15:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Apr 12 21:15:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304121640330.30064-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 12 Apr 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> If two of us are working simultaneously -- on different data files,
> obviously -- then it needs to execute twice, no?

Right. If a large portion of the app's functionality comes from shared
libraries, however, then the amount of memory needed for the second
instance is relatively low.

In fact, I'd be really surprised if even your lowest-powered 
workstation couldn't support multiple users working at the same time.

> In this case it comes as a RPM package. But, the package installs
> into /usr/bin.

Hmm. I guess I don't get it. What's the hassle of doing 'rpm -F' on 
two machines. It sounds like a really easy solution to the problem.

> As a naive, non-professional SysAdmin I would like to have all
> end-user apps optionally installed either into /usr/local or /opt
> (if such a partition exists).

For simple binaries, that's easy to do. rpm supports installation in 
non-default paths via the --relocate option.

Some apps, however, have a difficult time with relocation; just about 
any package that installs stuff into /etc falls into that boat.

There's a long discussion to be had about the merits of system
installation versus completely modular installation -- but I'm too
tired right now to launch it...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From drl at drloree.com  Sun Apr 13 00:23:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun Apr 13 00:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Renew IP address
In-Reply-To: <1050195975.1219.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1050195975.1219.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1050218541.2395.945.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2003-04-12 at 18:06, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> What is the command to renew my ip address?  I have a computer that I
> set up on a 192.168.0.0 network and will be switching it to a
> 192.168.1.0 network.  These addresses are coming from a cable/dsl
> router.  I've had trouble in the past switching computer between these
> two routers and have had to set IP address statically.  Service network
> restart does not do it.  I understand there is another command that does
> the same (equivalent to windows ipconfig /release ipconfig /renew).

ifdown eth0

ifup eth0

these should read from a file called /etc/network/interfaces, where the
interface should be defined like this for dhcp:

iface eth0 inet dhcp

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Sun Apr 13 12:39:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Sun Apr 13 12:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A net admin question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304121539190.30064-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304121539190.30064-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200304131420.57426.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

On Saturday 12 April 2003 17:48, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I understand that linux -- as with all unices -- can operate in both
> peer-to-peer and client-server network modes. For many -- if not most -- of
> the end-user apps we use here (e.g., OO.o and gnucash) the client-server
> mode is more desirable because there's only one copy of the executable
> installed and everyone works off of that. Easier to maintain and so on. In
> prinicple, at least.
>
>   However, a lot of end-user apps have their binaries installed (by 'make
> install' or by a package manager) into /usr/bin and /usr/lib. I don't know
> how, in this case, to make those binaries executable on other hosts. What I
> end up doing is installing (and upgrading) a copy on each host.
>
>   Trying to export /usr from the "server" host doesn't work well because
> there's no way of nfs-mounting it on another, client, host. And I don't
> know of a way to install the OS _without_ /usr/bin.
>
>   I'm sure that I've missed something very simple all these years, but
> since I just upgraded gnucash from 1.6.6 to 1.8.2 on two machines the
> question came up again: just how is such an application installed once and
> used across the network?
>
> TIA,
>
> Rich

Rich,

Here's a suggestion.  You could build and install the desired apps on the 
server using source and configure them so that their components are installed 
in nontraditional places.  For the purpose of this example, let's say that 
you install the software and associated libraries, man pages, etc. under 
/usr/local/remote_apps so that executables are in /usr/local/remote_apps/bin, 
the libraries are in /usr/local/remote_apps/lib, and so forth.  For software 
built using the common configure/make combination, you can configure these 
locations when you construct the make file using the configure script.  Type 
"./configure --help" to get a list of the arguments to configure for the 
given app.  Typically, you would want to set the prefix when running the 
configure script using a command like

./configure --prefix=/usr/local/remote_apps

Once you have built the software and installed it in a nontraditional place, 
then you can export the nontraditional directory tree to the remote machine 
without disrupting the remote machine's operation.  In my example, you would 
export /usr/local/remote_apps and mount it on /usr/local/remote_apps on the 
client.  Then users can use apps from the server on the client by simply 
adding /usr/local/remote_apps/bin to their paths.  Also, if you need to build 
software using shared libraries in the nontraditional location, e.g. 
/usr/local/remote_apps/lib, simply add the nontraditional library directory 
to /etc/ld.so.conf and run ldconfig.  (Of course, if you do this on a client 
machine, you'll need to mount the remote directory tree first.)

This is also very rarely possible to do with rpm packages.  Some rpm packages 
are "relocatable", which means that you can specify a root for the 
installation that differs from the default location during an installation, 
upgrade, or freshening.  See the INSTALL AND UPGRADE OPTIONS section of the 
rpm man page for more information.  However, rpm builders almost never make 
their packages relocatable.

Debian or Slackware packages probably have similar facilities.  But I am 
completely ignorant on this topic.

Of course, one of the keys here is centralizing software installation.  If the 
users currently have the capacity to install software on their own machines, 
this could annoy them since they'll have to wait for you to install software.  
You also have to have enough bandwidth and processing power on the server to 
handle the expected level of activity over the nfs mount.  And the apps will 
run slower (or at least load slower) even under the best circumstances due to 
the latency of the nfs mount.  Furthermore, the architectures of the client 
machines have to be compatible with the architecture of the build machine or 
you have to build executables and libraries specifically for the client 
machines.  However, despite these caveats, I can report that there are places 
that very successfully use this technique

I hope that this helps.

Mark
--

Mark A. Martin, Ph.D.

Currently available for employment.
See http://www.amath.washington.edu/~mmartin/resume/ for details.

#!/usr/local/bin/bash
#|  Author: Tyler Creelan <tyler.creelan at orst.edu>
#|  Description: Prompt-related preferences; see .bashrc for package info.
#|  Filename: .bash_prompt 
#| --------------------------------
#|    Notes:  Type 'prompt' to edit this file.
#|            Use 'plainprompt' for simple colorless PS1 prompt.

PS2='input> '  # secondary prompt, additional input expected. default-">".
PS3='select> ' # tertiary prompt, displayed in a select loop.
PS4='shopt+ '  # 

plainprompt() {
	export PS1="-(\t)-(\u@\h)-(\w)-\n-(\$) "
}

prompt_actions() { # evaluated after every action.
	# --- Get system load average over last minute.
	
	waittime=$(uptime | sed -e "s/.*load average: \(.*\...\), \(.*\...\), \(.*\...\)/\1/" -e "s/ //g")
	
	if [ "$HOSTNAME" = "ein" ]; then
	    batteryState=$(apm | sed -e "s/.*: \(.*\)%.*/\1/")
		 
		 if [ $batteryState -gt 90 ]; then
				battColor="\[\033[0;32m\]"
		 elif	[ $batteryState -gt 80 ]; then
				battColor="\[\033[0;34m\]"
		 elif [ $batteryState -gt 0 ]; then
				battColor="\[\033[1;31m\]"
		 fi

	fi

#	echo $waittime
#	echo $batteryState
	# If waittime goes over 1, highlight the number.
	if [ ${waittime:0:1} -gt 1 ]; then 
		LOAD_COLOR='1;36' # light cyan 
	else 
		LOAD_COLOR="0;36" # cyan
	fi
	
	# --- Display info in title of terminal emulator
	case $TERM in
	xterm*|rxvt*|Eterm*) 
		echo -ne "\033]0;${USER}@${HOSTNAME}: ${PWD}\007"
		;;
	*)
		;;
	esac
}


niceprompt() { # Colorful, nice prompt.

	PROMPT_COMMAND=prompt_actions # Evaulate this function constantly.

#	if [ $UID -eq 0 ]; then
#		local mark="#"
#	else
#		local mark="$"
#	fi

	# Define color codes.
	local    LGRAY="\[\033[0;37m\]"
	local    DGRAY="\[\033[1;30m\]"
	local   LGREEN="\[\033[1;32m\]"
	local    LBLUE="\[\033[1;34m\]"
	local    LCYAN="\[\033[1;36m\]"
	local  LPURPLE="\[\033[1;35m\]"
	local     LRED="\[\033[1;31m\]"
	local NO_COLOR="\[\033[0m\]"
	local  DEFAULT="\[\033[0m\]"
	local   BLACK="\[\033[0;30m\]"
	local    BLUE="\[\033[0;34m\]"
	local   GREEN="\[\033[0;32m\]"
	local    CYAN="\[\033[0;36m\]"
	local     RED="\[\033[0;31m\]"
	local  PURPLE="\[\033[0;35m\]"
	local   BROWN="\[\033[0;33m\]"
	local  YELLOW="\[\033[1;33m\]"
	local   WHITE="\[\033[1;37m\]"
	
	# Here is the prompt itself
	# time:  -(00:00:00)-
	local time="$DGRAY-$CYAN($LGRAY\t$CYAN)$DGRAY-"
	# user_host: (rogue at escher)
	local user_host="$CYAN($LBLUE\u$DGRAY@$LBLUE\h$CYAN)"
	# working_dir: -(~/bash/.bashrc-files)-
	local working_dir="$DGRAY-$CYAN($LGRAY\w$CYAN)$DGRAY-\n"
	# cursor_prompt: -($) 
	local cursor_prompt="$DGRAY-$CYAN($LGRAY\$$CYAN) $DEFAULT"
	
	if [ $HOSTNAME = "ein" ]; then
	    # apm_status: -(100%)
	    local apm_status="$DGRAY-$CYAN($battColor\${batteryState}%$CYAN)"
	    PS1=$time$user_host$apm_status$working_dir$cursor_prompt 
	else
	    PS1=$time$user_host$working_dir$cursor_prompt
	fi
	export PS1


       	# 1. user at host
	#if [ $UID -eq 0 ]; then
	#	local namehost="$BLUE[$LIGHT_CYAN\u$BLUE@$CYAN\h$BLUE]"
	#else
	#	local namehost="$BLUE[$CYAN\u$BLUE@$LIGHT_CYAN\h$BLUE]"
	#fi

	# 2. time
	#local tdate="$BLUE($CYAN\@$BLUE|$CYAN\$(date '+%m/%d')$BLUE)"

	# 3. wait time averaged over last minute (dynamically colored!)
	#local cpuload="(\[\033[\$(echo -n \$LOAD_COLOR)m\]\${waittime}cpu$BLUE)"

	# 4. tty -- 'mytty' global to preserve value for subshells
	#mytty=$(temp=$(tty) ; echo ${temp:5}) # show the tty (fubars vim syn)
	#local termname="$BLUE[$CYAN\$mytty$BLUE]"

	# 5. shell level if > 1
	#if [ ! $SHLVL -eq 1 ]; then
	#	local shlvl=" $CYAN$SHLVL"
	#else
	#	if [ "$shlvl" ]; then 
	#		unset shlvl 
	#	fi
	#fi

	# 6. working directory, $ or # mark.
	#local cwdir="$WHITE \w$BLUE\n"

	#if [ $UID -eq 0 ]; then
	#	# special root prompt.
	#	local rootbanner="$BLUE{$LIGHT_CYAN""superuser mode""$BLUE}"
	#	PS1="$namehost$rootbanner$termname$shlvl$cwdir$BLUE$mark $DEFAULT"
	#else
	#	PS1="$namehost$tdate$cpuload$termname$shlvl$cwdir$BLUE$mark $DEFAULT"
	#fi
	#export PS1
}

# Experimental VGA-font prompt.
oldRed() { 
	PS1="\[\033[31;41;1m\]\333\262\261\260\[\033[37;41;1m\]\u@\h\[\033[0m\033[31;40m\]\333\262\261\260\[\033[37;40;1m\] \d \$(date +%I:%M:%S%P)\n\[\033[31;40;1m\]\w/\[\033[0m\] "
	PS2="\[\033[31;40m\]\333\262\261\260\[\033[0m\]>"
}

I always alter RH's /etc/bashrc because I too like the full path in the 
prompt (most of the time) by just changing the W->w.  This way all users 
benefit from my preference--of course, I'm the only user.

The only colorization I do is for root's prompt. In /root/.bashrc

# Make root prompt noticable
if [ `id -un` = root ]; then
     PS1="[\[\033[1;31m\]\u\[\033[0m\]@\h:\w]\\$ "
else
     PS1="[\u@\h:\w]\\$ "
fi

Make sure the permissions on the file .procmailrc, and the directory it's in, only
allow the user (not the groups, and especially not everyone) to write.

Jason,

On the MUA front, I have been using squirrelmail
(http://www.squirrelmail.org) since testing it for a client last year. I
access it from https to utilize SSL and I find it very nice. My drafts,
sent and trash are kept on the server. I have broadband at work and home,
but ovet spring break I checked mail from my sister-in-law's AOL account
and it was a champ. It was sure nice not having to set up any IMAP account
info and then remove it.

Make sure you give security a good thought if you are accessing your mail
over a insecure network such as the internet.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Apr 14 10:21:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Apr 14 10:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CIDR in ipv4 addressing questions...
In-Reply-To: <20030414170548.7431.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304141016300.12299-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 14 Apr 2003, Michael Robinson wrote:

> There's an RFC , I believe 1519, that defines Private class C
> networks in CIDR notation.  How is 192.168.0.0/16 a supernet for
> class C networks?  I believe that the latter idea of classes was
> based on ranges of octet bound numbers where the current idea is
> based on how many bits are in the subnet mask.  This isn't
> completely correct through because certain numbers are known to be
> special such as 192.0.2.0/somenumber which is supposed to be used
> for test nets and 0.0.0.0/0 which is a broadcast special address.  
> Help.

Michael,

I don't really understand your question.

192.168.0.0/16 is the total boundary of the IANA-unassigned range that 
may be assigned to private networks (along with 10/8 and that funky 
set in 172.16/12 or whatever it is).

If you want a class-C-style network in the unassigned range, then just 
pick one, e.g., 192.168.33.0/24.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Apr 14 11:02:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Apr 14 11:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CIDR in ipv4 addressing questions...
In-Reply-To: <20030414174941.7477.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304141056160.12299-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 14 Apr 2003, Michael Robinson wrote:

> If I use this 192.168.0.0/16 or 172.16.0.0/12 in a firewall for
> class A and class B can I use them to block all private class B and
> private class C nets?

I think the answer is 'yes.' Here's what I did back when I was using 
Linux/iptables for my home firewall:

# ------ snip -------

iptables=/sbin/iptables
if_ext=eth1
any=0/0
unassigned="0.0.0.0/8 10.0.0.0/8 127.0.0.0/8 169.254.0.0/16 172.16.0.0/12"
unassigned="${unassigned} 192.0.2.0/24 192.168.0.0/16"

for net in ${unassigned}; do
  $iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $if_ext -s $net -d $any -j DROP
done

# ------ snip -------

Is that what you're asking?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

redirects standard output STDOUT to a file.

the "/" on ofsbu was there from your example.  It really does nothing
except make it very clear that you're dealing with a directory and I
think it's completely optional.

> networks in CIDR notation.  How is 192.168.0.0/16 a supernet for class C
> networks?  I believe that the latter idea of classes was based on ranges
> of  octet bound numbers where the current idea is based on how many 
> bits are in the subnet mask.  This isn't completely correct through 
> because certain numbers are known to be special such 
> as 192.0.2.0/somenumber which is supposed to be used for test 
> nets and 0.0.0.0/0 which is a broadcast special address.  Help.

CIDR = Classless InterDomain Routing

The key word is "classless".  Classless routing allows us to do cool
things like supernetting, subnetting, and non-standard'netting. :)

The RFC defines the 192.168 space as a supernet: 192.168.x.x is really
what it is saying.  This means that 192.168.47.0/24 and 192.168.0.0/24
are both in a private range.  If you saw 192.168.0.0/16 in a routing
table, it is most likely a summary route (all 192.168.x.x routes.. go
this way).

> Will ipv6 have private addressing?  Is ipv6 addressing going to
> support ipv4 addressing as the lower half of an ipv6 number?
> How does ipv6 with 128 bit numbers not pose a problem for the
> routing infrastructure?  Will ipv6 be used at the home level or
> just on backbones, at research locations, and on certain
> campuses for training?  Is ipv6 restricted to hex notation
> for addresses?  Will ipv6 need CIDR or is it more flexible for
> getting the correct number of hosts for a particular network?

Can't help ya here.  I havent studied up on my IPv6.

-- 
I'm just a packet pusher.

>
> # ------ snip -------
>
> iptables=/sbin/iptables
> if_ext=eth1
> any=0/0
> unassigned="0.0.0.0/8 10.0.0.0/8 127.0.0.0/8 169.254.0.0/16 172.16.0.0/12"
> unassigned="${unassigned} 192.0.2.0/24 192.168.0.0/16"
>
> for net in ${unassigned}; do
>   $iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $if_ext -s $net -d $any -j DROP
> done
>
> # ------ snip -------

and destination addresses in any ip packet have to be

From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Apr 14 11:47:02 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon Apr 14 11:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CIDR in ipv4 addressing questions...
In-Reply-To: <20030414174941.7477.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304141016300.12299-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <20030414174941.7477.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20030414184659.GA9797@rauhaus.org>

* Michael Robinson <michael at ns1.robinson-west.com> [030414 10:53]:
> The class B boundary blows my mind.  16 in binary is 2^4.
> But CIDR notation is the leftmost bits that are 1 I think meaning
> that 172.16.0.0/12 would refer to this: 

It would probably be best to forget all about classful networks, as
the classful boundaries don't really mean anything anymore. But
a quick Google on "ipv4 classful boundaries" reminded me:

      Class A networks: Describe the range of networks from 1.0.0.0/8
through 126.0.0.0/8.
    *
      Class B networks: Describe the range of networks from 128.0.0.0/16
through 191.255.0.0/16.
    *
      Class C networks: Describe the range of networks from 192.0.0.0/24
through 223.255.255.0/24.

> 11111111 11110000 00000000 00000000.
> 
> The latter doesn't appear to be the binary representation of 172.16.0.0 at 
> all and if I remember right the upper bound is 172.31.xx.yy for class B 
> private networks.  What am I missing here?

That's the binary representation of the netmask. 

A "0" in the subnet mask means we can have a "0" or a "1" in the host
number. So:

10101100 00010000 00000000 00000000	172.016.000.000
11111111 11110000 00000000 00000000	255.240.000.000
10101100 00011111 11111111 11111111	172.031.255.255

So we get 172.16.0.0 through 172.16.255.255.

> 
> The latter I have done.  Trying to figure out a firewall scheme though knowing
> the broader picture of how addressing works is important.  For one thing there
> are martians, XMAS tree packets, NULL packets, spoofed packets...

If you want to block all Martians, then you'll need to keep up with Rob
Thomas's Bogon List. Note that this includes networks that haven't been
assigned to registries, but may be in the future, so you need to keep up
with the updates to it as new networks are assigned so as not to block
what turns out to be legitimate traffic.

http://www.cymru.com/Documents/bogon-list.html

--Stafford

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Apr 15 10:23:01 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue Apr 15 10:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] hiding email info
In-Reply-To: <20030415171114.GA7200@boora.com>
References: <20030415171114.GA7200@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20030415172155.GC4226@dalsemi.com>

On Tue, Apr 15, 2003 at 10:11:14AM -0700, Michael Montagne wrote:
> Is it possible to hide email addresses
> on your web site by using a php or javascript script to buidl the
> address?

Yes, see Slashdot archives.

> What if all email addresses come from a text file?  Are those
> crawled too?

I'd guess that most spiders only parse HTML, and not more unusual
formats like ASCII, PDF, doc, xls, etc.  But ask yourself this, how
hard is it really to do MIME-type detection and custom backend
processing on the spider?

> If your whole site is generated dynamically can it still
> be harvested?  Can google index it?

The spiders follow links just like users do, so any content on your website
that can be reached by a link can be searched/indexed.

This behavior is exploited by the spider honeypots/SPAM traps to tie up
resources on the spider's computer.

Note that this is also something that can be used to protect email addresses.
Suppose you have to make a list of email addresses available on the web but
you don't want them to be easily searchable.

You provide a 2-page solution via CGI or other programmatic method.
Page 1 is a list of names with radio buttons (all default off) and a
submit button.  A human will select a name and press submit and get an
email address.  A spider will probably just follow the submit link,
which can be a frontend to a SPAM trap.

It's a little less convenient to your users, but it provides a measure
of protection for the people with email address on the site.  It also
doesn't scale very well to a general purpose email address solution.

Colin

From cp at onsitetech.com  Tue Apr 15 11:45:02 2003
From: cp at onsitetech.com (Curtis Poe)
Date: Tue Apr 15 11:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] hiding email info
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304151010270.20296-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <019401c3037e$f7214060$1f01a8c0@ot.onsitetech.com>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Rich Shepard" <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
> On Tue, 15 Apr 2003, Michael Montagne wrote:
> > Just had a discussion with a coworker that was left unresolved due to
> > lack of experience on our part.  Is it possible to hide email addresses
> > on your web site by using a php or javascript script to buidl the
> > address?  What if all email addresses come from a text file?  Are those
> > crawled too?  If your whole site is generated dynamically can it still
> > be harvested?  Can google index it?
>
>   Do you have a robots.txt file on your home page? It's _supposed_ to let
> you control what bots can see and what they cannot. Of course, my copy --
> and understanding -- may well be outdated by now.

Regrettably, the robots.txt file is ignored by spammer's email harvesting
programs.  The robots.txt is a "keep off the grass" sign that they're not
obligated to respect.

One strategy, if you don't want the overhead of PHP or JavaScript, is to do
a static replacement of all email addresses with their HTML entity
equivalent.  For example:

  not at home.com

You can convert that to:

&#110;&#111;&#116;&#64;&#104;&#111;&#109;&#101;&#46;&#99;&#111;&#109;

If you want to convert an entire mailto link, it looks like this:

<a
href="&#109;&#97;&#105;&#108;&#116;&#111;&#58;&#110;&#111;&#116;&#64;&#104;&
#111;&#109;&#101;&#46;&#99;&#111;&#109;">&#110;&#111;&#116;&#64;&#104;&#111;
&#109;&#101;&#46;&#99;&#111;&#109;</a>

Believe it or not, your web browser will still recognize that as a valid
mailto: link, allow you to click on it and will still display it correctly.

If you want to utilize this technique, but don't want to change a bunch of
HTML documents, here's a bit of code that can do the following (WARNING:
the following is a couple of minutes worth of work and should be considered
*pseudo-code*.  Back up your work).  It takes a directory as an argument and
recursively travels through the directories beneath it, converting all email
addresses below the __DATA__ tag to their HTML entity equivalent.

Cheers,
Ovid

  #!/usr/bin/perl -lw
  use strict;
  use HTML::Entities;
  use File::Find;

  my $home_dir = shift or die "Usage:  $0 [target_dir]";
  unless ( -d $home_dir ) {
      die "($home_dir) does not appear to be a directory";
  }

  my $escaped_chars = '\x00-\xff';

  my %encoded_email;
  foreach my $email (<DATA>) {
      chomp $email;
      $encoded_email{$email} = encode_entities("$email", $escaped_chars);
  }

  my $mailto = encode_entities( 'mailto:', $escaped_chars );

  find( \&hide_email, $home_dir );

  sub hide_email {
      return unless /\.html?$/;
      open DOC, "+<", $File::Find::name
          or die "Can't open $File::Find::name for updating: $!";
      my $html = do { local $/; <DOC> };
      while (my ($email, $encoded) = each %encoded_email) {
          $html =~ s/\Q$email\E/$encoded/m;
      }
      $html =~ s/mailto:/$mailto/m;
      seek DOC, 0, 0 or die "Cannot seek to start of $File::Find::name: $!";
      print DOC $html;
      truncate DOC, tell(DOC) or die "Cannot truncate $File::Find::name:
$!";
      close DOC;
  }

  __DATA__
  spamtrap at heaven.mil
  not at home.com
  ovid at ovidinexile.com
