From rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Tue Apr 15 15:54:02 2003
From: rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Tue Apr 15 15:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NetWare & Linux?
Message-ID: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A018C5875@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>

Specific Netware feature(s) I'd like to see replicated elsewhere: 

1)  Deleted file restore is awesome - don't have to go to tape to restore a
file, just browse out to the diretory, select salvage files, voila.  Saved
many man hours in many jobs for me.  You look the hero as the sysadmin, and
it's simply built into the Netware OS.  To get the same sort of thing for NT
or Unix requires buck$, from what I've seen.  If someone can show me similar
functionality, I'd be ecstatic to see it.

2)  File permissions - It's so easy to modify permissions, restrict
permissions, etc.  No one else seems to have been able to make it so easy,
and yet advanced control features also.  (allow permissions to inherit or
restrict inheritance of permissions as you go down a folder)

Non specific to Netware:  They do have a nice directory services... Zenworks
management of M$ O$'s is pretty nifty.

>From what I have seen of the Novell marketing plan - (granted, they don't
pay attention to us anymore, as we haven't bought anything in 2+ years, so I
don't hear from them often anymore) - they don't care so much if you run
Netware - they just want to layer their other services over whatever
platform you are running.  example, they wanted awhile back to make NDS
(Novell Directory Services) work on UNIX/Linux, so they did.  They want
people to use Zenworks, regardless of what file server you are using, so
they made ZENworks work under NT and I believe planned to do it under Linux,
also.  (LINK HERE: http://www.novell.com/products/zenworks/sysreqs.html) 


One of the more odd things I've noticed lately was that at one of the
Netware brain trust events, they are having a seminar on how to make Apache,
Mysql, PHP work while running on Netware.  While I don't completely grok why
someone would want to do that, hey, it's neat that it's happening.

From michael at ns1.robinson-west.com  Tue Apr 15 16:17:01 2003
From: michael at ns1.robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue Apr 15 16:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up backup qmail server...
Message-ID: <20030415231345.10455.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

Do I need to set up imap accounts with the same usernames and user id's 
as my original mail server on the backup box?  Do I need to use NIS or ldap?  
I'd prefer to have both of these boxes work autonomously and not depend on 
each other for authentication, otherwise I defeat the idea of a backup.

How do I configure the backup server to attempt relaying mail recieved to 
the original mail server where I want the mail to be read?  I prefer to relay 
through the local network connecting my servers instead of the Internet.  I 
also want to relay backup mail server generated mail to my mailhub also.

I'm thinking that backup mail exchangers should not allow reading of the
spools they are holding though I am not certain what common practice is.  

If I understand correctly, a backup exchanger attempts to send messages 
recieved during a main failure to the primary exchanger which should recieve 
them as soon as it is back up.  What concerns me are mail overflow 
situations, situations where the main goes out of service simply 
because it is recieving too much mail.  The backup in this case may 
make it difficult to get the main back up since it will likely be flooded 
with mail also that it will relay to the main as soon as the main comes
back online.  I guess the main when it comes back up should not
accept mail until the backups have completely emptied.  At this time
the backup, being emptied, shouldn't accept new mail either?  The 
mail capacity of my site with the backup the way I'm thinking is two 
mail servers worth.

I'm using qmail.

                         | Opus gaeway  |
                          -----------
                                    |
              ------- Internet ---------------
             |                                                               |
     ________     lan    ________   lan   _____________________________
     | gateway | <---> | Mailhub |<--->| Backup mail and Backup Gateway |
     -------               ------             -------------------------

which I am currently building.  The gateway is a 386 so I don't want
to put a backup mail site on it because it is already too slow, I run
6.2 on it.  The Mailhub is also a 7.2 Redhat box.  I am running 2.2.14
and 2.4.20.  The problem on the 386 is the DI30 tape drive, otherwise

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue Apr 15 17:09:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue Apr 15 17:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NetWare & Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304151626300.17694-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304151626300.17694-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1050451718.6854.26.camel@main>

On Tue, 2003-04-15 at 16:28, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Tue, 15 Apr 2003, Schlosser, Ryan wrote:
> 
> > Specific Netware feature(s) I'd like to see replicated elsewhere: 
> 
> [snip lots of good comments]
> 
> 3) Netware's security record. From what I can tell, there just aren't 
>    that many known vulnerabilities. It may be security through 'who 
>    cares?' -- but my hunch is that there's more to it than that.
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
> 

Novell, for the longest time, was a staunch supporter of the IPX
protocol. Only with Netware 5 did they finally get close to out of that
protocol and even then it was still - in most installations - required
internally to the server. Not connecting to an IP network with native IP
throws up a giant roadblock to those would-be crackers with an eye on
cnn.com. There were a few known exploits associated with the
BorderManager product (Novell's proxy/firewall product offering) but
they were short-lived since the folks in Provo jumped on those issues
straight away.

Also, the product followed a strict adherence to certain code practices.
For the most part there was only one compiler that would allow properly
built NLMs, and only those NLMs that were built on this compiler were
honored by the OS. For the life of me I can't remember the name of that
compiler (senior moment I guess). This practice put virus, worm and
root-kit(ish) code to a non-existent state on Netware - the compiler was
very expensive. I do know that they have backed off on that a little in
NW5 and up with the allowance for .DLL code (but there are still strict
code practices so not just any M$ junk DLL will run). Of course, all of
this just rat-holed Netware, who wants a server that requires this much
overhead to run applications.

Another thing that kept them tight was the BSD style of "install
nothing, give no rights". Adding users meant that the user had nothing
until you gave it rights. Adding the OS meant that it was a pristine
environment, you had a file server without permissions until you added
services and data.


-- 
Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>




From michael at ns1.robinson-west.com  Tue Apr 15 17:10:02 2003
From: michael at ns1.robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue Apr 15 17:10:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304151626300.17694-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

I have heard from many sources that Netware's security
record is impressive.  Yet I know someone who works for U.S.
Fish & Wildlife that says that Netware was dumped for NT
because of number of users or Netware didn't integrate well
with Windows or something.  I tried to take a Novell course
at PCC but 98 and Novell just don't get along and the materials
for the course were contradictory where one chapter would
say one thing while another chapter would say the exact
opposite.  The course seemed to be more geared toward a
political than a practical approach, a waste of money.
Instead of focusing on a specific way to answer questions
I really wish the course would have focused on understanding
the Novell Netware 4.7 environment more.  At the time the
concern was about Netware 5 and I think the quality of
education slipped. 

Ironically, Netware 5 is touted because it use the ip
protocol where I thought the point of using Netware
was to get away from the ip protocol with all it's
inherent security protocols.  Look at the complex of
a good netfilter firewall when your lan uses ip and
it's no surprise there's good reason to use a 
different protocol for your lan.  Just think, all the
RFC's, 1517,1518,1519.1520, which talk about
renumbering lans because of routing issues 
could be ignored.  With Netware only one
box needed to be special to be able to go out
on the ip networks.

There has been some question as
to whether or not Linux users need Novell integration
and I for one have wondered why Novell didn't open source
NDS.  At least if Novell licensing was cheap enough I bet
it'd go a lot further than NT.  Netware, NT, and exchange etc.
have been around long enough that I would hope to see
an open source standard for providing the same services
develop.  Just the valuable services that are worth keeping
thinking specifically of exchange server, whatever that is.
On the other hand maybe integrated software isn't the way
to go.  There's something to be said for simple programs
that are well defined and perform their tasks correctly.

     -- Michael C. Robinson

From michael at ns1.robinson-west.com  Tue Apr 15 18:20:02 2003
From: michael at ns1.robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue Apr 15 18:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NetWare & Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1050452656.6854.38.camel@main>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304151626300.17694-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <20030416000622.10505.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com> <1050452656.6854.38.camel@main>
Message-ID: <20030416011655.10835.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

> Was Netware 4.7 a typo? I've been through 4 revisions of that OS and can
> tell you that I have not had that experience (but then, I never took an
> instructor led course, it was all hands on and challenge).

Mike Neal studied a lot of Netware but he said to just stick with Linux now.
I'd like at some point to either adapt the Netware protocol philosophy prior
to 5 and develop an open source protocol replacement for ip that works 
under Linux and any other OS that wants it or get a different kind of Novell
training.  I like online do it yourself better.  I need to know in a short 
period of time why I'm studying something and enough about shortcomings,
etc to not come out the other end with nothing useful.
 
I still think the licenses are too expensive for Netware and the failure
to advertise/develop Netware as an OS agnostic product will probably
prove fatal for the environment in the future.  Caldera Openlinux was an 
interesting notion, but Novell should have developed a product that 
brings Netware to a standard Linux environment.  There is good stuff
in Netware but Novell as a company is probably no better than Microsoft,
an intractable problem.

It would be interesting to develop a different operating system than Linux 
with Linux as the inspiration that is geared toward workstation use with the
intention of having Linux as the server.  The reasons to do this are: be able
to use a network filesystem that is better than samba or nfs, have a
workstation system with better networking than Windows, and achieve 
simpler configuration than Linux.  Develop a lan networking protocol and 
use that with your workstation Linux-like OS removing all ip stuff.  Get X 
working cleanly and steal one idea from 98, a graphical device manager.  
Don't borrow the having to reboot all the time issue.  On top of this, 
develop your workstation targeted Linux-like OS to be network bootable off 
your Linux server so that you don't have to have a local hard drive to use 
it.  This is where a network filesystem that intelligently uses a ramdrive to 
read a file out of that it needs to retrieve quickly really starts to matter. 
Especially when net speed is limited to 100 mb/s.  Abandoning ip allows
using a better networking protocol and securing ones lan can be made
easier with an intelligent plan and the absence of the ip junk.  
Abandoning samba abandons the myriad of issues that it inherits
from trying to support Windows networking.  Abandoning the need for a
local hard disk makes the system more valuable than Windows giving it
flexibility.  Intelligent use of a ramdisk makes this system better than an 
LTSP solution, unless there's a way to use a ramdisk enhanced network
filesystem instead of NFS.  Most importantly is for your linux-like
workstation OS to be small footprint and open source.  It would be wise
to solve the different header files for different versions of the same library
and other similar compilation/upgrade issues which seem to have gotten
out of hand.

    --  Michael C. Robinson

resolvable, "hiding" the ip, or, is this hiding something different?  I've 
run into a lot of notices on the Internet that I need to stop advertising my 
own ip for better security.  Seems like security through obscurity to me.  
If you have an Internet ip you can be connected to even if you
are harder to find than a name that can be resolved by an Internet
nameserver.  Maybe the notice is about having open ports.

http://www.m-arriaga.net/software/libtrash/


>From the README file in the tarball
-----------------------------------------
libtrash is a shared library which, when preloaded, will intercept
calls to a series of GNU libc functions and make sure that, if an
attempt to destroy certain files is made, these won't be permanently
destroyed but rather moved to a "trash can".  It also allows the user
to mark certain directories as "unremovable", which means that calls
to functions which would result in the loss of files under these
directories will always fail, leaving those files untouched in their
original locations.

(This last feature is meant as a higher-level substitute for ext2fs'
"immutable" flag for use by those of us who rely on other file
systems. An important difference is that libtrash allows
non-privileged users to use this with their personal files.)

The GNU libc functions which can be overriden/"wrapped" are

- unlink();
- rename();
- fopen() / fopen64();
- freopen() / freopen64();
- open() / open64().

You can individually enable / disable each of these "protections"; by
default, only calls to the first two functions are intercepted.


libtrash works with any GNU/Linux program, both at the console and
under XFree86, and operates independently of the programming language
the program was written in. The only exception are statically linked
programs, which you probably won't find.

So that calls to the different GNU libc functions are intercepted,
you must "preload" this library. This is can be done in two ways:
either edit /etc/ld.so.preload or set the LD_PRELOAD environmental
variable.


On Tue, 15 Apr 2003 15:52:47 -0700, Schlosser, Ryan said:

> Specific Netware feature(s) I'd like to see replicated elsewhere: 
>  
>  1)  Deleted file restore is awesome - don't have to go to tape to restore a
>  file, just browse out to the diretory, select salvage files, voila.  Saved
>  many man hours in many jobs for me.  You look the hero as the sysadmin, and
>  it's simply built into the Netware OS.  To get the same sort of thing for NT
>  or Unix requires buck$, from what I've seen.  If someone can show me similar
>  functionality, I'd be ecstatic to see it.
>  
>  2)  File permissions - It's so easy to modify permissions, restrict
>  permissions, etc.  No one else seems to have been able to make it so easy,
>  and yet advanced control features also.  (allow permissions to inherit or
>  restrict inheritance of permissions as you go down a folder)

* Michael Robinson <michael at ns1.robinson-west.com> [2003-04-16 00:41]:
> She also wants quicken but a google search turned up that 
> there is no Linux version and that there is some Java substitute, but you 
> have to buy it and convert your data files.  Trouble is people feed their
> Quicken stuff into TurboTax.  Is there any replacement for TurboTax under
> KDE or better yet GNOME.

This has been my "Golden BB" for several years. I'm addicted to keeping
my finances on my computer, and in turn, reconciling what my bank and my
computer say on a fairly regular basis (several times a week). 

For me, the important part is having an app that will connect to, and
download the transactions from, the bank, automatically. So far, only MS
Money and Quicken do this. Unfortunately, both are Windows only. 

The only way I can do this, is to run VMWare with some form of Windows,
and then run the financial app of my choosing inside that. I suppose I
could dual boot, but that means I have to shutdown my linux box, and
then, what's the point? 

I've heard noises that Quicken will run in wine. I've never been able to
get anything other than notepad and solitaire to run in wine. Even those
were unstable, and didn't seem very reliable. I just wouldn't want to
trust my financial data to something that crashed while running notepad.
At least VMWare doesn't crash.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Apr 16 10:10:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Apr 16 10:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Make cron not email
In-Reply-To: <43756.209.210.31.8.1050510616.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <43756.209.210.31.8.1050510616.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030416180953.GB16931@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Steven Raymond <stever at woo-hoo.com> [2003-04-16 09:31]:
> I created a new cron job for root and it works fine however it emails me
> upon every execution (2 hrs).  Is there any easy way to stop this from
> happening, for this particular job only?

Redirection is your friend. :)

*/10 * * * * /command/to/run >/dev/null 2>&1

What this does is pipe the output of the command (standard out or
STDOUT) to /dev/null and the output of standard error (or
STDERR) to the same place.

I've heard noises that gnucash is almost there with your bank download
requirement. It works in Germany and it works with the OFX protocol. Which
banks use OFX today? I don't know. Check their web-page www.gnucash.org for
details:

- OFX Import:
    GnuCash is the first free software application to support the Open
Financial Exchange
    protocol that many banks and financial services are moving to use. The
development of
    OFX and HBCI support has also resulted in an improved transaction
matching system that
    more accurately picks duplicate transactions.
- HBCI Support: 
    GnuCash is the first free software application to support the German
Home Banking 
    Computer Information protocol which includes statement download,
initiate bank 
    transfers and direct debits.

-djp

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Apr 16 10:23:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Apr 16 10:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Make cron not email
In-Reply-To: <20030416180953.GB16931@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1965-56480@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 16 Apr 2003, Russ Johnson russj-at-dimstar.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> * Steven Raymond <stever at woo-hoo.com> [2003-04-16 09:31]:
> > I created a new cron job for root and it works fine however it emails me
> > upon every execution (2 hrs).  Is there any easy way to stop this from
> > happening, for this particular job only?
> 
> Redirection is your friend. :)
> 
> */10 * * * * /command/to/run >/dev/null 2>&1
> 
> What this does is pipe the output of the command (standard out or
> STDOUT) to /dev/null and the output of standard error (or
> STDERR) to the same place.

I'll often redirect to a file without appending so you can see the results
of the most recent run.  This generally doesn't use much disk space, and
it can be really helpful when troubleshooting.  For example:

*/10 * * * * /command/to/run >/var/tmp/run.cron.txt 2>&1

  -- Steve

While some banks allow for a manual OFX file download, it pales in
comparison to the simplicity of Quicken's downloads.  Intuit makes special
arrangements with a number of banks to support direct downloads in
Quicken's special format.  This means that the end user doesn't even need
to visit each Bank's website-- Quicken does it for them.

I run Quicken in VMware mostly since Windows patches break Quicken 2002
rather badly.  This allows me to run a heavily firewalled copy of
unpatched Windows used only for Quicken.

My big gripe about Quicken is that it doesn't make it easy to do
accrual-based accounting.  If your March gas bill gets paid in April, it
blindly assumes you had no gas payments in March, and a really harsh
payment in April-- which makes the reports inaccurate.  (Don't even get me
started about the mysterious ways in which Quicken calculates some of its
reports.)

At some point I plan to use Quicken for data retrieval, but export to
GNUCash for reporting.  This has been "planned" for quite some time, but
if I ever actually do it I'll be sure to pass along how well or poorly it
worked.  ;-)

  -- Steve

From bergie at bergie.net  Wed Apr 16 15:57:01 2003
From: bergie at bergie.net (Jason Bergstrom)
Date: Wed Apr 16 15:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To secondary MX or not to
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304161524060.26409-100000@appl-ecosys.com> from "Rich Shepard" at Apr 16, 2003 03:25:51 PM
Message-ID: <E195vpe-0006xO-00@bergie.net>

The advice should've been not to have a secondary MX if your primary MX
is always available.

The reasons spammers target secondary MX servers are:
1. They hope the policies are lenient on the secondary (usually due to
   not having authoritative account information held locally).
2. They believe the secondary will not be faster due to most mail routing
   through the primary.
3. They don't think anyone examines the logs on the secondary.

The reasons to have a secondary MX anyway are:
1. Scheduled or unscheduled maintenance on the primary MX.
2. Network outages.
3. Too much load on the primary.

Of course, you can just make the remote site queue until the primary MX
is available, but some consider that practice taking advantage of
spool space on the sending servers...

Jason,
bergie at bergie.net

From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Apr 16 16:13:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Wed Apr 16 16:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NetWare & Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1050457211.6856.56.camel@main>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304151626300.17694-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
	 <20030416000622.10505.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

	 <20030416011655.10835.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <1050457211.6856.56.camel@main>
Message-ID: <1050534686.25214.188.camel@red>

On Tue, 2003-04-15 at 18:40, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> On Tue, 2003-04-15 at 18:16, Michael Robinson wrote:
> 
> > Mike Neal studied a lot of Netware but he said to just stick with Linux now.
> > I'd like at some point to either adapt the Netware protocol philosophy prior
> > to 5 and develop an open source protocol replacement for ip that works 
> > under Linux and any other OS that wants it or get a different kind of Novell
> > training. 
> 
> NCP, the Netware core protocol of NW4< is in the 2.2.x > kernel.


No. It is support for the IPX protocol that is included in the Linux
kernel source tree - not NCP. You can configure a Linux box to route
IPX packets but without additional software, such as mars-nwe, Linux
cannot speak NCP.

Also, don't confuse the ability to mount NetWare volumes as support
for NCP.

Finally, NCP is still the native protocol for all versions of NetWare,
including all versions beyond NW4.
-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

On Sat, Apr 12, 2003 at 10:27:02AM -0700, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> I encourage all to seek enlightenment from Webster. In this magical book
> you will find many definitions for the word "open", all of which are are
> arranged in order of precedence. In the case of the word "open", there
> are at least 3 definitions that directly relate to Open Source within
> the top 5 ( of the 13 listed definitions ). None of these definitions,
> when preceded by the word "Published", imply "not defined".
> 
> http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary

The companies who create dictionaries do so based upon words that people
use.  That is dictionaries do not create or define the language.  People
define and create the language.  When a new term is coined and widely used
passed a certain threshold, dictionary makers start putting it in the books.

Dictionaries are reactionary reference guides rather than definitive
reference guides.  Thus, being not definitive, it probably wouldn't hold in
court.

http://www.m-w.com/about/wordin.htm

Cory

On Wed, 2003-04-16 at 16:11, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> 
> No. It is support for the IPX protocol that is included in the Linux
> kernel source tree - not NCP. You can configure a Linux box to route
> IPX packets but without additional software, such as mars-nwe, Linux
> cannot speak NCP.
> 
> Also, don't confuse the ability to mount NetWare volumes as support
> for NCP.
> 
> Finally, NCP is still the native protocol for all versions of NetWare,
> including all versions beyond NW4.

Look again Ed, NCP is in the list of Network File-Systems in make config
for the 2.4.20 kernel (I only assume that it works, it's rather unlike
this community to add modules that intentionally don't). You might want
to take a look, it does describe that as the component to "Mount Netware
volumes".

True, NCP is still in use for all current versions of Netware but the
NW4 version was the source that our linux kernel piece was based on
(this was released as experimental in version 2.2.<something>, I
discovered it when building an RH6 box a few years ago. I can not
testify to how well it works since I have never had a need to use it but
I do remember the tissy that Novell threw when the source was released. 

Oh yeah, after working with the Netware OS since the early 80's I don't
think that I'm apt to confuse NCP with IPX.

From dzeut at microsharp.com  Wed Apr 16 22:13:01 2003
From: dzeut at microsharp.com (Dale Zeutenhorst)
Date: Wed Apr 16 22:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard problems? Watch the capacitors!
Message-ID: <1050556367.4768.28.camel@mach3.intra.zeutenhorst.com>

I have been having a lot of problems with motherboards lately and have
been trying to find out why. This time it turns out there is a serious
problem that affects a lot of manufactures.

Leaking capacitors have become a serious problem and are affecting many
different motherboard manufacturers and their consumers. The following
web site has a lot of information: http://www.careyholzman.com/

All would be advised to inspect their motherboards for swelling caps.
They may cause intermittent problems as the dialectic compound degrades.

Intel and IBM have both extended the warranty on some of their server
grade motherboards because of this issue. I have two ABit motherboards
that I lost to this (one where the cap exploded).

The funny part in all this is a report in Passive Component Industry
Magazine claims that capacitors produced by Taiwanese companies are
liable to sudden failure as a cheap chemical used in their manufacture
was based on an incomplete, stolen process.

A scientist working for Rubycon Corporation in Japan left the company
and began working for Luminous Town Electric in China, where he
developed a copy of a Rubycon electrolyte used in the manufacture of
low-ESR aluminium electrolytic capacitors. Unfortunately, some of his
staff defected, taking the formula with them, and began to sell a
cut-price electrolyte to many of the major aluminium electrolytic makers
in Taiwan - the magazine claims as many as 11 companies were affected.

>   Not much sense in my having two mail servers on a very small network.

Not until your own mail server goes down.  It's true that remote sites
are supposed to queue the mail for a while, but that doesn't mean they
do.  With a site of your size, it probably doesn't matter much, because
you're not handling mail from lots of different people.  If you were,
however, it might be an issue.

Date: Thu Apr 17 07:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To secondary MX or not to
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304161933060.26528-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <mailman.1050560473.29176.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <868yu9444u.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Wil" == Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> writes:

Wil> Not until your own mail server goes down.  It's true that remote sites
Wil> are supposed to queue the mail for a while, but that doesn't mean they
Wil> do.  With a site of your size, it probably doesn't matter much, because
Wil> you're not handling mail from lots of different people.  If you were,
Wil> however, it might be an issue.

I just asked this recently of a group I respect, and the answer is
that if your system is offline less than 4 hours a quarter, you
probably don't need an MX.  If your system is offline every night,
then you do.  In between, it's a judgement call.

Or put another way, if you have two paths to the backbone and an
ASN'ed machine in the same cardcage with a UPS, you can avoid the MX.
If your only connectivity is a cable modem or a DSL to your house, get
an offsite MX.  (And then *it* should have two paths to the backbone
with an ASN'ed machine nearby.)
--

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Apr 17 07:06:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Thu Apr 17 07:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] hiding email info
References: <mailman.1050544872.20563.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <864r4x43um.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Roman" == Roman Robinson <sigma_x at attbi.com> writes:

Roman> The site I operate stores the addresses as addresses, but
Roman> displays them as, ex, 'Roman AT PCExtreme DOT net' Most users
Roman> figure this out ;)

This may have changed recently, but in our tests, nearly all spammers
are doing literal scraping, such that "merlyn at stonehenge.com" will be
noticed, but "merlyn&#64;stonehenge.com" will not.  Thus, you can
write your email links as:

        <a href="mailto:merlyn&#64;stonehenge.com">mail me at
        <tt>merlyn&#64;stonehenge.com</tt></a>

and it all works, and displays properly, and yet it's invisible to the
spammers.

(The CPU to de-entitize a page is not worth it for the spammerscraper,
given that so many pages are still coded in the normal way providing
the spammer with their millions of addresses anyway.)

The other thing if you have control over the email address is to
violate the "normal" email address rules that every believes.  For
example, I have an email address of fred&barney at stonehenge.com that
has been widely published in usenet and on the web.  And yet it has
*never* gotten a spam.  Sure, I've gotten a lot of spam to
<barney at stonehenge.com>, which I've blackholed.  But they don't seem
to get that the ampersand can be part of the email.  Hooray for us!

(Go ahead, send email to fred&barney at stonehenge.com - it's an
autoresponder.)

From phil at alcsoftware.com  Thu Apr 17 08:22:02 2003
From: phil at alcsoftware.com (Phil Schultz)
Date: Thu Apr 17 08:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] "headers" & "footers" on Web pages
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304170810250.29058-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

This php line would work:
<?php include 'header.html'; ?>

The problem with this method is that you have to either change all of your
files from .html to .php, or setup the php parser to parse .html files.  If
this isn't an option I would suggest looking into SSI, it should work on a
properly configured Apache.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Apr 17 08:24:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Apr 17 08:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] hiding email info
In-Reply-To: <000001c30484$efcadef0$e92be00c@dual>
Message-ID: <30214-44169@sneakemail.com>

> Just had a discussion with a coworker that was left unresolved due to
> lack of experience on our part.  Is it possible to hide email
> addresses on your web site by using a php or javascript script to
> buidl the address?  What if all email addresses come from a text file?  
> Are those crawled too?  If your whole site is generated dynamically
> can it still be harvested?  Can google index it?

Generally anything not in the usual form of <name>@<domain> doesn't get
spammed.  As more people hide their E-mail addresses in alternate forms,
this is likely to change.

I'm a big fan of places like http://www.sneakemail.com or
http://www.spamgourmet.com that offer unique E-mail addresses that forward
back to your real address.  Each time I need to enter my E-mail
address (site registration, USENET post, etc.) I'll create a new
address.  This is extra nice since you can then find out which address
gets spammed and hence, who it was that leaked your E-mail address.  If
the abuse is bad enough, the address can be completely disabled.

Couple this with the latest SpamAssassin and you get a winning
combination.

  -- Steve

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   I have the same image & title and contact information on each

Rich> "header" file and the other in a "footer" file and do the

Besides the PHP answers given already, you can also use mod_perl with
any one of a few dozen templating systems (mod_perl is often already
compiled in to the apache within linux distros these days).  I prefer
Template Toolkit as the most full-featured, with a tutorial on using
it with Apache at <http://www.tt2.org/tpc4/index.html>.  TT can also
be used from CGI scripts or even from a static "build my site from
these pieces" tree, if no dynamic content is needed.  Then you don't
even need mod_perl!

Yep.  Exactly the same idea.

I'll add bogus "apartment" numbers to my address for the same purpose.  
By far, most of my junk mail comes from my USPS change-of-address form.

I try to keep my name the same since I read about a court case where
someone was suing a junk mailer for misusing his identity by sending him
junk.  He knew who it was since they had a typo in his name.  
Unfortunately the court ruled that since the name with the typo was wrong,
the identity they were using was not his and hence, he had no case.

I wish I could find a link to the story, but Google seems to have failed
me.

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Apr 17 09:27:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Apr 17 09:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB2892 Update: Bill Moves Forward!
Message-ID: <1050596788.4474.1.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Friends, 

I am pleased to report that the Department of Administrative Services
submitted HB 2892's amendments and the Bill is moving forward! 

The leadership at the Information Resource Management arm of DAS, in
conjunction with members of Education system and Open Source community,
made a good bill even better. 

Specifically, DAS indicated that if the finer points of IT procurement
guidelines were placed in the Oregon Statute rather than law, the State
could react quickly to the ever-changing technology landscape. 

I find this ideal as it allows the State a greater degree of flexibility
while dealing with IT issues that are both complex and fast moving.

On the technological side with regard to Open Source, the leadership at
DAS really gets it. Over the past six months, DAS has both evaluated and
actively used Open Source in the State's IT infrastructure. Further,
they seem to have an awareness for the potential pitfalls with regard to
sometimes unreasonable software copyrights, patents, and End User
Licence Agreements.

We kept what are perhaps the most critical lines of the bill:

    "(2) For all new software acquisitions, the person or governing body
    charged with administering each administrative division of state
    government, including every department, division,agency, board or
    commission, without regard to the designation given the entity,
    shall consider acquiring open source software products in addition
    to proprietary software products."
    
Did we lose the justification piece? Not really. See, as many of you
know the idea is to _level_ the playing field, not to exclude
proprietary software. If we require justification only in the case of
proprietary software, that could potentially push out a vendor simply
because Open Source would not require justification for procurement. The
truth is that there are justification mechanisms built in to the State
procurement process. Currently, a study must be completed before any
software purchases over a certain monetary threshold are made. 

I am thoroughly impressed with everyone's efforts on HB 2892. I tell
you, when Republicans and Democrats alike sit down in a non-partisan
effort for a common goal, it's a good thing. 

The proof is in the pudding. You may find the proposed amendments to
HB2892 in PDF format here: 

 http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/HB2892_proposed_amendments.pdf
    
These amendments refer to the PDF version of HB 2892 here:

  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/hb2892.pdf

HB 2892 is scheduled for a committee work session today.

Meanwhile, if the bill passes into law DAS will define, during a public
rules process, the terms of "open systems" and "open standards." DAS
will hold public hearings and listen to input from the public on these
issues. To participate, one should join the "interested persons" mailing
list. I will provide details for joining the list upon request.

Also, I understand the opposition is _very_ interested in seeing this
bill disappear. It seems they are pressing very hard in their desire to
keep the status quo. As I understand it, one of the members of the
opposition visited Rep. Barnhart's office and "sternly" said, "make this
thing go away."

Let's keep up the support for this bill; we've a long way to go and it's
only through your support that this can be a true success!

Finally, I want to thank all of you who have written with your support
for our efforts. It really makes a difference.

I'll keep you posted.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org






From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Apr 17 09:33:01 2003

On Thu, 17 Apr 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I have the same image & title and contact information on each of my
> 11 Web pages. I would like to put the code for one in a "header"
> file and the other in a "footer" file and do the equivalent of
> #include <...> on each page. That makes updating much easier.

Rich,

The answer is highly dependent on what web server software is running 
on the machine that hosts your site.

In Apache land, server-side includes are the easiest approach:

  http://httpd.apache.org/docs/howto/ssi.html#includingastandardfooter

Most webmasters allow user-supported pages to use SSI, but you'll need 
to check it out with your admins.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

* Dale Zeutenhorst <dzeut at microsharp.com> [2003-04-16 22:13]:
> Leaking capacitors have become a serious problem and are affecting many
> different motherboard manufacturers and their consumers. The following
> web site has a lot of information: http://www.careyholzman.com/

Is this still a problem to this day? 

I know there WAS a problem, about two years ago. That's when I bought a
set of 21 abit motherboards. 18 of them died within the two year
warrenty period. The other 3 lasted until 2 months after warrenty
expired, and Abit refused to honor the warrenty, even though these MBs
had classic symptoms of the defective caps. 

At the same time, I've purchased MBs from many manufactures (Abit, ASUS,
Intel, Soyo, MSI, and others) that haven't shown any sign of failure. 

It was my understanding that the bad electrlyte problem was relatively
short lived, and only affected a few manufactures. 

I suspect that any MB purchased within the last year is probably fine.
Boards purchased 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 years ago may be suspect. 

But that's just my guess, based on the following paragraph from the IEEE
article:

Aluminum electrolytic capacitors with a low equivalent series resistance
(ESR) are high-capacitance components that generally serve to smooth out
the power supply to chips. Throughout 2002, they have been breaking open
and failing in certain desktop PCs. Motherboard and PC makers contacted
by IEEE Spectrum have stopped using the faulty parts, but because the
parts can fail over a period of several months, more such failures are
expected.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

> advantages to doing it on the server, too.

Well... In HTML 4.01 (at least) there's an <iframe> (in-line frame) tag,
which makes it sort of a client-side include, without the framey-ness of
regular frames.  But not all browsers support it, AFAIK, and might not
even be rendered consistently.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Thu Apr 17 14:35:02 2003
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Thu Apr 17 14:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [donwolfe@ipns.com: Fw: FC: Ex-DoubleClick privacy officer heads to Dept of Homeland  Security]
Message-ID: <20030417143432.G2885@patch.com>

Remember the "problems" DoubleClick has had with security and privacy?

http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A39211-2003Apr16.html

Homeland Security To Fill Privacy Post


By Brian Krebs
washingtonpost.com Staff Writer
Wednesday, April 16, 2003; 3:45 PM


The former privacy officer of Internet advertising giant DoubleClick
will be the Department of Homeland Security's first privacy czar,
Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge announced today.

The administration will appoint Nuala O'Connor Kelly to the privacy
post, where she would be responsible for vetting proposals or programs
that involve collecting and using U.S. citizens' personal information.
O'Connor Kelly currently serves as a Commerce Department attorney.

O'Connor Kelly, 34, will report to Ridge.

The privacy rights community generally views O'Connor Kelly as a
consensus builder, but it is too soon to say how much influence she
will have in protecting Americans' privacy rights, said Ari Schwartz,
associate director at the Center for Democracy and Technology.

"One of the things we liked (about her job) at DoubleClick was that she
worked hard to build relationships with the privacy community and to vet
their new policies with these groups," Schwartz said. "There is still
some question as to what level of access will she have, and whether she
will be able to speak her mind internally and publicly on privacy issues
or will she simply be giving the agency line on everything."


-- 
      Michael Rasmussen  aka  mikeraz

             The Linux Clinic - third Saturday of every month

    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.

                               Linux Clinic

                              April 19, 2002

                                1PM - 4PM

                            Riverdale High School                                                          
                          9727 SW Terwilliger Blvd,                                                     
                             Portland, Oregon

   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.

   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials

   For directions to the school see:

From dzl at frenetic.com  Fri Apr 18 02:29:02 2003
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Fri Apr 18 02:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ssh & mozilla weirdness
In-Reply-To: <3E9F4D03.2090704@pacifier.com>
References: <3E9F4D03.2090704@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030418022637.1d9fa844.dzl@frenetic.com>

Mozilla uses X to determine if another mozilla session is already
running and connects to it if possible. It doesn't matter if it's
running off of another machine. 

You can disable this by starting the second session with the --no-xshm
option.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 18 05:58:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 18 05:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] "headers" & "footers" on Web pages
In-Reply-To: <20030417213141.4bfbe97c.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304180551290.4035-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 17 Apr 2003, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Point taken, sir, but I wouldn't agree that client JS should be
> killed off just because of IE's security problems.  It's useful for
> more than rollovers:  client-side form validation, for instance,
> saves a lot of hits (and hence a lot of waiting).  Are you throwing
> out the baby with the bathwater, or is a really secure JS sandbox
> just a pipe dream?

Firewalling in general is a blunt tool, but I agree that a complete
ban on JavaScript can disable some useful tools. Each business would 
have to decide for itself what the best policy is for any given 
network.

Then again, maybe the courts will tell us that blocking JavaScript 
and/or images is a violation of the DMCA and that firewalling will 
get you a fine or jail time. Stranger things have happened.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From dpool at hevanet.com  Fri Apr 18 08:50:02 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (David Pool)
Date: Fri Apr 18 08:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB2892 Update: Bill Moves Forward!
In-Reply-To: <1050596788.4474.1.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
References: <1050596788.4474.1.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>
Message-ID: <3EA01EAC.7060903@hevanet.com>

Cooper,

Can you reconcile your report with the Oregonian's today in the business section 
titled "Open Source software bill stalls on opposition"? Where they say that the 
  House General Governement Committee passsed over the bill for discussion?

What's going on?

david pool

Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Friends, 
> 
> I am pleased to report that the Department of Administrative Services
> submitted HB 2892's amendments and the Bill is moving forward! 
> 
> The leadership at the Information Resource Management arm of DAS, in
> conjunction with members of Education system and Open Source community,
> made a good bill even better. 
> 
> Specifically, DAS indicated that if the finer points of IT procurement
> guidelines were placed in the Oregon Statute rather than law, the State
> could react quickly to the ever-changing technology landscape. 
> 
> I find this ideal as it allows the State a greater degree of flexibility
> while dealing with IT issues that are both complex and fast moving.
> 
> On the technological side with regard to Open Source, the leadership at
> DAS really gets it. Over the past six months, DAS has both evaluated and
> actively used Open Source in the State's IT infrastructure. Further,
> they seem to have an awareness for the potential pitfalls with regard to
> sometimes unreasonable software copyrights, patents, and End User
> Licence Agreements.
> 
> We kept what are perhaps the most critical lines of the bill:
> 
>     "(2) For all new software acquisitions, the person or governing body
>     charged with administering each administrative division of state
>     government, including every department, division,agency, board or
>     commission, without regard to the designation given the entity,
>     shall consider acquiring open source software products in addition
>     to proprietary software products."
>     
> Did we lose the justification piece? Not really. See, as many of you
> know the idea is to _level_ the playing field, not to exclude
> proprietary software. If we require justification only in the case of
> proprietary software, that could potentially push out a vendor simply
> because Open Source would not require justification for procurement. The
> truth is that there are justification mechanisms built in to the State
> procurement process. Currently, a study must be completed before any
> software purchases over a certain monetary threshold are made. 
> 
> I am thoroughly impressed with everyone's efforts on HB 2892. I tell
> you, when Republicans and Democrats alike sit down in a non-partisan
> effort for a common goal, it's a good thing. 
> 
> The proof is in the pudding. You may find the proposed amendments to
> HB2892 in PDF format here: 
> 
>  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/HB2892_proposed_amendments.pdf
>     
> These amendments refer to the PDF version of HB 2892 here:
> 
>   http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/hb2892.pdf
> 
> HB 2892 is scheduled for a committee work session today.
> 
> Meanwhile, if the bill passes into law DAS will define, during a public
> rules process, the terms of "open systems" and "open standards." DAS
> will hold public hearings and listen to input from the public on these
> issues. To participate, one should join the "interested persons" mailing
> list. I will provide details for joining the list upon request.
> 
> Also, I understand the opposition is _very_ interested in seeing this
> bill disappear. It seems they are pressing very hard in their desire to
> keep the status quo. As I understand it, one of the members of the
> opposition visited Rep. Barnhart's office and "sternly" said, "make this
> thing go away."
> 
> Let's keep up the support for this bill; we've a long way to go and it's
> only through your support that this can be a true success!
> 
> Finally, I want to thank all of you who have written with your support
> for our efforts. It really makes a difference.
> 
> I'll keep you posted.
> 
> 
> Very Truly Yours,
> 
> 
> Cooper Stevenson
> MWVLUG Coordinator
> Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
> Www: http://www.mwvlug.org
> 
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

All, 

I am confident that with a strong showing of support from each of you
that we can make this bill move forward.

Let us not forget that it is not the industry trade groups that have to
live with bad IT procurement practices resulting in wasted taxpayer
dollars as a result of Administrative tunnel vision for proprietary
software. 

It is we.

Please take just a few moments to write to your representative about
this very important bill. Also, if you have not made an appointment with
your Representative, I encourage you to do so. I would be more than
happy to coordinate this if you would like.

You may write to your legislator here:

  http://www.leg.state.or.us/writelegsltr/writeset.htm

HB 2892 has received national attention; let's show 'em what we've got!

It is critical that we push this bill to the committee vote stage. If we
can achieve this goal, the awareness for Open Source will skyrocket as
it is likely to then go to a vote on the House floor. Oregon businesses
and IT professionals nationwide are counting on us to bring this bill to
the forefront. Let's make it happen!


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
MWVLUG Coordinator
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

> > know the idea is to _level_ the playing field, not to exclude
> > proprietary software. If we require justification only in the case of
> > proprietary software, that could potentially push out a vendor simply
> > because Open Source would not require justification for procurement. The
> > truth is that there are justification mechanisms built in to the State
> > procurement process. Currently, a study must be completed before any
> > software purchases over a certain monetary threshold are made. 
> > 
> > I am thoroughly impressed with everyone's efforts on HB 2892. I tell
> > you, when Republicans and Democrats alike sit down in a non-partisan
> > effort for a common goal, it's a good thing. 
> > 
> > The proof is in the pudding. You may find the proposed amendments to
> > HB2892 in PDF format here: 
> > 
> >  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/HB2892_proposed_amendments.pdf
> >     
> > These amendments refer to the PDF version of HB 2892 here:
> > 
> >   http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/oregon/hb2892.pdf
> > 
> > HB 2892 is scheduled for a committee work session today.
> > 
> > Meanwhile, if the bill passes into law DAS will define, during a public
> > rules process, the terms of "open systems" and "open standards." DAS
> > will hold public hearings and listen to input from the public on these
> > issues. To participate, one should join the "interested persons" mailing
> > list. I will provide details for joining the list upon request.
> > 
> > Also, I understand the opposition is _very_ interested in seeing this
> > bill disappear. It seems they are pressing very hard in their desire to
> > keep the status quo. As I understand it, one of the members of the
> > opposition visited Rep. Barnhart's office and "sternly" said, "make this
> > thing go away."
> > 
> > Let's keep up the support for this bill; we've a long way to go and it's
> > only through your support that this can be a true success!
> > 
> > Finally, I want to thank all of you who have written with your support
> > for our efforts. It really makes a difference.
> > 
> > I'll keep you posted.
> > 
> > 
> > Very Truly Yours,
> >

> > MWVLUG Coordinator

From dpool at hevanet.com  Fri Apr 18 11:28:01 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (David Pool)
Date: Fri Apr 18 11:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Open Letter regarding Bill 2892 on Open Source Software
Message-ID: <3EA043B7.8060808@hevanet.com>

Fellow Pluggers,

I'm asking for your help, open source style, with the crafting of a letter to my 
representatives. Once revised, it will be published into the public domain 
through Creative Commons (http://old.creativecommons.org/license/publicdomain-2 
) That allows anyone else to basically sign on and say "Yeah, what he said", or 
to rewrite the pieces you disagree with.

Mostly I'm asking for people to point out any factual errors. I am also open to 
hearing other comments.

Thanks,

David Pool

ps Once again that website for finding your representatives is:
http://www.leg.state.or.us/findlegsltr/findset.htm


Dear ________,

I am writing to you to express my concern over an article in today's Oregonian. 
The April 18th business section has an article by Jeffrey Kosseff ?Open-source 
software bill stalls on opposition.? (also online here 
http://www.oregonlive.com/business/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/business/1050666959318260.xml).

To quote Mr. Kosseff, the bill would ?would require state agencies to consider 
open source software when purchasing computer programs?. Please note that it 
doesn?t require the use of Open Source, just the consideration. The point is we 
are trying to achieve a level playing field.

It is VERY IMPORTANT to me that this bill receive a fair hearing and the support 
of my representatives. So much so that I have gone through the trouble of 
tracking you down to tell you about it (a first for me).

A few points for you to consider:

1) Again quoting Mr. Kosseff, ?Microsoft...(has) squared off against a 
grassroots group of open-source programmers and school districts pushing for the 
bill.? . Microsoft is a convicted Felon, found guilty of excercising monopoly 
power, illegally. They have roughly $30 billion in reserves. Thus: the 
grassroots folks and school districts could use a helping hand to level the 
playing field.

You can read about the findings against Microsoft here: United States of America 
vs. Microsoft (http://usvms.gpo.gov/ms-findings2.html)

2) The National Security Agency (NSA) has adopted the Open Source operating 
system Linux due to security concerns. To quote their website
?Why was Linux chosen as the base platform?
Linux was chosen as the platform for the work because of its growing success and 
open development environment. Linux provides an excellent opportunity to 
demonstrate that this functionality can be successful in a mainstream operating 
system and, at the same time, contribute to the security of a widely used 
system. A Linux platform also offers an excellent opportunity for this work to 
receive the widest possible review and perhaps provide the foundation for 
additional security research by others.?

If the NSA trusts Open Source, I believe it would be imprudent of Oregon to fail 
to atleast consider it as an option. I realize that as a legislator, you may not 
keep up to date on technology issues, but numerous people have experienced 
security problems (viruses) and bugs (crashes) using Microsoft products. It 
might be prudent for Oregon to consider what our nation's foremost security 
authorities are doing.
http://www.nsa.gov/selinux/

3) Oregon is a hotbed of Open Source development. There are thousands of local, 
high-wage jobs that depend on the success of Open Source. If the legislature is 
unwilling to flat out direct development projects towards local Oregonian 
programmers instead of sending millions of dollars up to Washington, I beg of 
you ? atleast consider the possibility!

In these budgetary times, I believe it is an outrage that this legislature is 
unwilling to atleast consider possibilities for saving money. I would not be 
surprised if the very idea of saving money for other uses like funding schools 
or police, for example, were to come up as an issue in upcoming elections. If 
nothing else, I'd appreciate knowing where you, as my representative, would 
rather spend our money?

For information on Oregon Open Source activities, please consider that all of 
these local groups are dedicated to Open Source software:

Portland Linux/Unix Group ? an extremely active group of IT professionals that 
meets monthy in Portland drawing up to a hundred users per meeting and 
maintaining a mailing list that runs much higher.
http://www.pdxlinux.org/

The Open Source Development Lab
OSDL is dedicated to providing Open Source developers with resources and 
guidance to build data center and carrier grade enhancements into Linux and its 
Open Source software stack, enabling it to become the leading UNIX-like 
Operating System for e-Business deployment and development.
Sponsored by: IBM, Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Dell, Toshiba and others
http://www.osdl.org/sponsors/
http://www.osdl.org/sponsors/

Portland Perlmongers ? an Open Source programming group that meets monthly and 
sports a membership that includes world renowned programmers and authors.
http://pdx.pm.org/

Eugene Unix and GNU/Linux User Group (EUGLUG) - a volunteer group whose goal is 
to promote and exchange information about Linux, Unix and Open Source Software 
in Eugene, Oregon and surrounding cities.
http://www.euglug.org/

Mid-Willamette ? "We are a group dedicated to bringing you the highest level of 
performance, reliability, and stability for your computing platform. This site 
will help you make sense of it all. We go out of our way to help you gain the 
most from your computer."
http://www.mwvlug.org/

Portland Linux Users Groups ? another linux group...
Free Geek ? a nonprofit that recycles computers to run Open Source software and 
donates them to nonprofits and citizens.
BizNix ? a coalition of businesses in Oregon that support Open Source software.
http://www.biznix.org/about/index.html

LinuxChix - Portland Chapter "LinuxChix is a community for women who like Linux, 
and for supporting women in computing. The membership ranges from novices to 
experienced users, and includes professional and amateur programmers, system 
administrators and technical writers."
http://www.linuxchix.org/content/chapters/portlandor.html

Open Source Users of the University of Oregon: The Open Source Users Group is a 
way for University of Oregon students to promote open source on campus and share 
information and resources.
http://www.cs.uoregon.edu/open/index.html

Beaverton Linux Users Group
http://www.bluegroup.org/

Klamath Falls Linux Users Group
http://www.maneuveringspeed.com/klug/index.html

Tillamook Linux User Group
To advance our knowledge and understanding of the Linux Operating System and 
it's uses, and to help others in they're quest for freedom of choice in the OS 
and Software they use. To encourage the spread of the Free Software Movement in 
our community, our state, our country, and the world. And finally, to try to 
have some fun doing it.
http://www.geocities.com/elflakosr/tlug-home.html

Linux Fund ? a Portland based nonprofit that funds Open Source development projects.
http://www.linuxfund.org/

The Open Source Convention ? an annual conference that draws thousands of people 
to Portland. There are three Open Source conferences within this huge event:
Convention Conferences
   ? Perl Conference 7
   ? The Python 11 Conference
   ? PHP Conference 3
http://conferences.oreillynet.com/os2003/

K-12 Linux ? An initiative to run Open Source software in schools
http://k12linux.org/contents.html

The point is that Oregon's Economy supports a lot of Open Source developers. For 
the most part, they are focused on computers, not politics or elections. Please, 
help them get consideration, at the very least. Please do what you can to see 
that law-breaking monopolists don't scuttle this bill before it's even 
considered in the light of day!

Thank you for your time,

David Pool, Oregon Resident

Well, here is my report.  No, I didn't upgrade a 7.x -> 9.0.  I decided 
to move my dual Celeron RedHat 7.2 box to the attic as a server, and 
start over with a new machine. :)

I left all my 7.2 config on the old box as-is, so if I need to log in
and "do work", it will still function the way it was.  Now my desktop is
a RedHat 9.0 (also dual boot XP) FIC IceCube - P4 2.26GHz.  The RedHat 9 
install went just fine, and I have /usr/local mounted from my 7.2 box.  
So far, I've only had to recompile one app.  We'll see how it goes, but
as far as a standalone machine, everything checks out so far.

For details on the IceCube, see http://www.fic.com.tw/product/sff/mini/ice-cube.aspx

From krisa at subtend.net  Fri Apr 18 17:26:16 2003
From: krisa at subtend.net (Kris)
Date: Fri Apr 18 17:26:16 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB2892 - conversation with Jerry
Message-ID: <20030419002531.GA13679@subtend.net>

Behold!  Representative Jerry Drummel, at 16:52PDT, calls me back.

I spoke with him for about 10 minutes.  To summarize:

* He scratched out the discussion of the bill in the general committee
  because he wasn't happy with the amendments.  Two issues:
   - Issue with the "where as" clauses.  I didn't know what this meant.
   - Issue with parts of section 2, did not go into details

* He has been working with Barnhart and and Ken Barber since the bills
  creation.

* He is the one who invited Riverdale and the MESD down to testify.

* Once the bill is finalized and approved through the General committee,
  he would be a yes vote.


He also made a interesting comment about school districts in general (I
mentioned I worked for Tigard/Tualatin SD).  He said that if the bill
wasn't watered down, and specifically said "you must purchase open
source software over proprietary software", school district
administrators would be pissed off because the state would be telling
them what, and what not, to purchase.  

Even if this bill passes, it will be a long journey towards the path to
enlightenment. :)  Education of the procurement people will need to be
done.  School educators will need to be educated on the benefits of
considering open source to proprietary software.

This is also a good opportunity for the unemployed to get out there and
implement open source solutions at half the cost of proprietary software,
with a reasonable amount of profit.

So, I don't think the bill is dead, just standard government
bureaucracy.  I've never had a representative call me back though, which
was impressive.  Then again, maybe I'm easily impressed when it comes to
legislature.  I did mention multiple times throughout the conversation
that this bill was important to myself, and many people known and
unknown to me.

Next I'm going to try and get some response on SB655.  The evil Oregon
"Super" DMCA.

You folks have shown what it really takes to make this happen.

It wouldn't hurt to approch the leadership of both parties in the legislature.  They have the real power.  And, maybe even somebody in the Governor's office since he is obviously not willing to raise any new revenue and would welcome any savings.

My 2 cents.

From michael at robinson-west.com  Sat Apr 19 10:44:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sat Apr 19 10:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple gateway scenario...
Message-ID: <20030419174009.6346.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

I've looked at documentation on RIP which seems to be what I need.  However, 
the example in an OSU networking text uses private addressing on the 
redundant gateways dropping to one Internet gateway.  What I need is 
something that will work where the redundant gateways both have a direct 
Internet connection.  They are both dual nic machines.  With RIP there is
evidently a broadcasting issue.  You don't want to broadcast onto
your service providers network.  If I understand correctly, the gateways and 
other routers broadcast their routes which the workstations and terminals
receive via a listening daemon.  The idea as I see it is to listen for the 
routes and update routing entries dynamically.  Can I controlling the 
broadcasting with iptables?

    --  Michael C. Robinson

    Happy Easter everyone.



From michael at robinson-west.com  Sat Apr 19 11:32:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sat Apr 19 11:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To secondary MX or not to
In-Reply-To: <E195vpe-0006xO-00@bergie.net>
References: <E195vpe-0006xO-00@bergie.net>
Message-ID: <20030419182752.6372.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Wednesday 16 April 2003 03:56 pm, you wrote:
> The advice should've been not to have a secondary MX if your primary MX
> is always available.
>
> The reasons spammers target secondary MX servers are:
> 1. They hope the policies are lenient on the secondary (usually due to
>    not having authoritative account information held locally).
> 2. They believe the secondary will not be faster due to most mail routing
>    through the primary.
> 3. They don't think anyone examines the logs on the secondary.
>
> The reasons to have a secondary MX anyway are:
> 1. Scheduled or unscheduled maintenance on the primary MX.
> 2. Network outages.
> 3. Too much load on the primary.
>

Wouldn't the obvious thing to do be setting the secondary up with 
the same rules as the primary.  Network filesystems 
are popular but I wouldn't want to use them from the primary 
because the event of the primary going down would take the 
secondary out as well.  The best way to set a secondary up from 
what I can see is with the same rules as the  primary and with
the ability to substitute the secondary for the primary.  The latter
may mean that people have to set up another imap account
unless there is a way to transparently have one imap server
address go to the exchanger currently serving the mail.  If
the primary is out it would be the secondary.

The more I think about it the more I realize there should probably 
be a set of redundant network file servers behind gateway/Internet/mail 
servers which distribute authentication services and protect data 
used on the outside boxes.  If you put these cross server 
authentication services on your outside boxes there is the problem 
of having to be able to distribute information from 
a server that is live.  This becomes a problem when none of 
these machines are dedicated to be up for authentication.  If 
you distribute the same information from all of your servers 
you have just defeated the point of distributing authentication
information and probably could have done it more easily by 
manually programming each server's password file to be the same.
More servers means more power though I guess this can be
alleviated by using older computers.  The other issue with
distributed authentication is that it is common to have some
accounts that are unique on each server that shouldn't be
available on all.

With the logs the easy solution is remote loggis available, but some consider 
that practice taking advantage of
> spool space on the sending servers...
ing.  There is one
thing I really don't like about this though and that's having the logs
from multiple machines dump into one set of files on the log server.
I would like to have each machine's logs in seperate files or at
least have the log files sorted so that in chronological order 
there would all logs from machine A ... followed by all logs from m
achine N.  This probably involves turning logging off, sorting the 
logs, then restarting the log daemons.  With the latter approach,
the end of the log would always be unsorted.  It would be nice 
instead of turning logging off to dump to a temporary log during the
sort.  Then one would only sort the original log files once and
afterwards not dump to them directly, but dump to a temporary
instead.  With two sets of temporaries that are recycled over
time, logging would never have to be suspended except when
space is exhausted.  One temporary gets sorted and appended 
to the main logs while the other catches new logs.  Many 
references say to put all logs into one file but this is ugly 
because there are different types of logs which are easier 
to see in their own files and the log file gets very long very 
fast.  I've seen emailers which probe logs, I'd much rather 
figure out how to get a perl script to put graphics based on 
the logs such as histograms, pie charts, etc. on a private 
lan management web site.  The easier it is to see important 
events in the logs the more likely an administrator is to take 
needed action reducing the security risk of providing any 
service over potentially malicious networks.

I don't know about the speed issue.  The cool thing to do 
would be to have a mail server stop accepting mail when 
it's jammed and open up again when it is say 20% free on 
spool space.  I would think that speed is a spammers 
friend as they can send more junk to you unless the 
purpose of spamming is to cause DoS.  At the end of the
day connections for spammers can possibly be refused,
but what's to stop their flood of requests from taking away
all your bandwidth anyhow?  One doesn't have to be 
accepted to send a connection request.  This seems like
an area where a network authority severing the spammers
connection to the Net is the only solution.  There's
something called tarpitting where you allow conenction
but the connection goes into a black hole.  I guess you'd
have to allow the spammer to flood the tar pit though which
probably means that the ISP has to do the tar pitting.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Apr 19 12:19:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Apr 19 12:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] To secondary MX or not to
In-Reply-To: <20030419182752.6372.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <E195vpe-0006xO-00@bergie.net>
	 <20030419182752.6372.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1050779891.27872.35.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sat, 2003-04-19 at 11:27, Michael Robinson wrote:

> Wouldn't the obvious thing to do be setting the secondary up with 
> the same rules as the primary.  Network filesystems 
> are popular but I wouldn't want to use them from the primary 
> because the event of the primary going down would take the 
> secondary out as well.

You don't ever want to put your mail spool on a network filesystem, with
the possible exception of some of the clustering, replicating
filesystems, but I haven't investigated those enough to know.  (And in
practice, it's rarely necessary.)

> The best way to set a secondary up from 
> what I can see is with the same rules as the  primary and with
> the ability to substitute the secondary for the primary.  The latter
> may mean that people have to set up another imap account
> unless there is a way to transparently have one imap server
> address go to the exchanger currently serving the mail.  If
> the primary is out it would be the secondary.

No.  There's no need for the MX hosts to also host the client mail
spool.  Usually the load on MXes is caused by processing that need not
be done on the client spool server, such as spam and anti-virus
scanning.  If your load is that much, you're better making the MXs
separate from the client spool, fed into the client spool via LMTP.  If
client access is such a high load, there are solutions for distributing
that too, such as the "Murder" component of Cyrus IMAP.  (A "murder" is
a group of crows.)

> The more I think about it the more I realize there should probably 
> be a set of redundant network file servers behind gateway/Internet/mail 
> servers which distribute authentication services and protect data 
> used on the outside boxes.  If you put these cross server 
> authentication services on your outside boxes there is the problem 
> of having to be able to distribute information from 
> a server that is live.  This becomes a problem when none of 
> these machines are dedicated to be up for authentication.  If 
> you distribute the same information from all of your servers 
> you have just defeated the point of distributing authentication
> information and probably could have done it more easily by 
> manually programming each server's password file to be the same.

No, you really don't want to do that.  The work of adding a user in a
non-distributed environment increases linearly by a factor of the number
servers; the likelihood of missing a step also increases highly; and the
likelihood of effectively disabling the account across the network is
abysmal.  At 3 servers, it's already tedious.

> More servers means more power though I guess this can be
> alleviated by using older computers.

I don't think this is necessarily the case.  Some of those big old
harddrives take more power than newer ones.  But I don't know much about
power, so I might be wrong.  At any rate, in the trade-offs you're
considering, power is not so much of an issue.

> The other issue with
> distributed authentication is that it is common to have some
> accounts that are unique on each server that shouldn't be
> available on all.

Not really.  There are mechanisms in both NIS and LDAP for controlling
the host that a particular account may be active on.

> With the logs the easy solution is remote loggis available, but some consider 
> that practice taking advantage of
> > spool space on the sending servers...
> ing.  There is one
> thing I really don't like about this though and that's having the logs
> from multiple machines dump into one set of files on the log server.
> I would like to have each machine's logs in seperate files or at
> least have the log files sorted so that in chronological order 
> there would all logs from machine A ... followed by all logs from m
> achine N.  This probably involves turning logging off, sorting the 
> logs, then restarting the log daemons.  With the latter approach,
> the end of the log would always be unsorted.  It would be nice 
> instead of turning logging off to dump to a temporary log during the
> sort.

No need for this.  There are syslog replacements that will do just what
you're asking for.

> Then one would only sort the original log files once and
> afterwards not dump to them directly, but dump to a temporary
> instead.  With two sets of temporaries that are recycled over
> time, logging would never have to be suspended except when
> space is exhausted.  One temporary gets sorted and appended 
> to the main logs while the other catches new logs.  Many 
> references say to put all logs into one file but this is ugly 
> because there are different types of logs which are easier 
> to see in their own files and the log file gets very long very 
> fast.  I've seen emailers which probe logs, I'd much rather 
> figure out how to get a perl script to put graphics based on 
> the logs such as histograms, pie charts, etc. on a private 
> lan management web site.  The easier it is to see important 
> events in the logs the more likely an administrator is to take 
> needed action reducing the security risk of providing any 
> service over potentially malicious networks.
> 
> I don't know about the speed issue.  The cool thing to do 
> would be to have a mail server stop accepting mail when 
> it's jammed and open up again when it is say 20% free on 
> spool space.

Every SMTP server I know of does this.

> I would think that speed is a spammers 
> friend as they can send more junk to you unless the 
> purpose of spamming is to cause DoS.  At the end of the
> day connections for spammers can possibly be refused,
> but what's to stop their flood of requests from taking away
> all your bandwidth anyhow?  One doesn't have to be 
> accepted to send a connection request.  This seems like
> an area where a network authority severing the spammers
> connection to the Net is the only solution.  There's
> something called tarpitting where you allow conenction
> but the connection goes into a black hole.  I guess you'd
> have to allow the spammer to flood the tar pit though which
> probably means that the ISP has to do the tar pitting.

The MX host has to do that.  Postfix does it by default.

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Apr 19 12:21:02 2003

On Sat, 2003-04-19 at 11:48, Michael Robinson wrote:
> Is there a way to disable local logging without disabling remote logging?

Comment out the lines in syslogd.conf that go to local files, while
leaving in the line(s) that send to remote hosts?  Of course, all those
services that don't use syslog can't do this.

I don't see how going after open relays helps.  I guess the only reason
so many sites don't like open relays is that open relays can't be held
