> make much sense to me.  Who's to stop spammers from forging their from
> address or doing other things to cause mail to go either directly or
> indirectly where they want it to go?  I've had a lot of people send email
> to my domain to an invalid user account and I know these aren't people I'm
> familiar with where the from address is an invalid yahoo account.  It's
> hard to see how to stop the spam I get because the from is always changing
> and it would be extreme to block all of yahoo.com.  Specifically the spam
> aimed at me gets to me because of double bounce where qmail can't bounce a
> message properly sending it to the admin instead.  With forging possible
> I don't see how going after open relays helps.  I guess the only reason
> so many sites don't like open relays is that open relays can't be held
> responsible for spam since it may be difficult to track the source.
>

Blocking open relays will stop a sizable percentage of spam, possibly as much 
as half, though it's hard to get good numbers. Spammers are evil bastards who 
expend considerable energy finding ways to steal resources from other people. 

According to the faq at http://relaytest.kundenserver.de/faq/admin/1.html, 
they relay-test every server that tries to send them mail:

"Why do you test my host?

We're testing every host who is trying to send mail to mx.kundenserver.de. 
Since much spam is being received via unsecured mail servers, we're testing 
every host who tries to send mail to our mail cluster to verify that these 
servers have a correct and non-abusable configuration."

I think this is a reasonable policy. The more aggressive RBLs that list open 
relays go out and test anyone and everyone, not just people who try to send 
them mail. Some of our local ISPs, such as Easystreet and Aracnet, will not 
provide connectivity until they test your mailserver.

Forging return addresses or other parts of mail headers are fave spammer 
tactics, but you can still follow their backtrail, they can't hide it 
completely.

Some resources that might be helpful:
http://spamcop.net
http://www.ordb.org/faq/

A great essay, "Thank The Spammers" 
http://www.spamreaper.com/thankspammers.html

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail

>
> We're very linux friendly; alas the product is targeted at Windoze(gasp!)
> users since that's the only way to make it in consumer electronics these
> days:(  You can check out our website at www.streamzap.com and you've got
> to cut us some slack for selling on www.thinkgeek.com and opening up our
> hardware specs to an open source linux developer who made drivers for our
> product (on SourceForge).  I hope to add at least RH linux support in the

Well the playstation II can run Linux.  One would be surprised where open 
source software can be found.  There are many ways to get Linux to consumers.
One is to choose a distribution that is started from Windows.  Another way is 
to have customers run vmware or wine and place certain win apps they "need"
on a Windows system running on virtual machine while having Linux underneath. 
The last is one I really like, network boot X so that Windows customers can 
easily use both environments.  Trick here is to convince customers to use 
PC's that are compatible with both OS'es.  X-Windows is your friend for many 
programs.  If KDE and GNOME are too heavy, use something lighter.  Check 
out www.ltsp.org, very interesting.  My advice is to not write any program in
a way that makes it difficult to port it to Linux.  What is good for 
enterprise is good for a desktop system in general also, expect Linux to take 
more market share from Windows.
  
Windows is hurting the consumer electronics market because the PC
is gaining a reputation of being a piece of junk.  With open source you
can see under the hood and fix things.  Windows is bloated, Microsoft
is trying to maintain compatibility with a line of systems that were never
intended for today's computing needs resulting in severe growing pains
seen by many today in the form of blue screen of death.  There are some
Windows problems that will probably never get fixed and Microsoft is
creating a tremendous opporunity by changing how Windows is accessed
and functions so often for a better designed, more reliable, more powerful
system like Linux to make a real dent in the desktop market.  I see nothing 
wring with writing proprietary applications for Linux as long as the 
libraries that could be considered part of the operating system that 
it needs to function are kept open source.  I think many folks make 
the mistake of the underestimating the desire for solid commercial 
applications that work out of the box on Linux within the security 
and design peridiems of the Linux operating system, source 
code or not.  Indeed, many programs which have been proprietary 
in the past and succeeded have seen their source code released 
where it wouldn't surprise me to find someone discovering a way to 
make money off an open source program through documentation
sales or other means.  My advice is to move toward not supporting
Windows at all.  This move will save you so much money and 
headaches that you'll probably increase your profits.  There are 
many ways to affectively deploy Linux for someone who uses
Windows and maybe isn't a computer genius, go for it.

Just a thought, does the Nintendo run dos or Windows?  How about
the Mac?  The Palm Pilot?  An enhanced wrist watch?  Writing 
software to run under Linux and open sourcing as soon as you
can to build your reputation is a good idea.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From brucek at kingkon.com  Sun Apr 20 03:14:01 2003

Subject: FW: [PLUG] fetchmail and pacifier
In-Reply-To: <2C8BB28F11F9114799C4B80E4CDA55C501739978@usnet-ex01.USNET.CORP>; from dpalin@pacifier.net on Sat, Apr 19, 2003 at 08:01:19PM -0700
References: <2C8BB28F11F9114799C4B80E4CDA55C501739978@usnet-ex01.USNET.CORP>

Doug Palin's Log: StarDate 0419.2001:
> How does fetchmail connect to get mail, eg what protocol?

Here's the entry from .fetchmailrc:

poll mail.pacifier.com proto imap user brucek fetchall fetchlimit 300

Prior to the upgrade, the proto was pop3; and about a year ago, it was
imap. I had done a query some years ago, and pacifier was reporting
that it supported imap4, so I set the proto to imap. Then about a year
ago, it got wierd and tech support told me that they only supported
pop3; but that they intended to upgrade their servers soon and imap
would be supported then.

There's another entry in .netrc that handles the login/password issue.

In this case, the culprit was that the IP for mail.pacifier.com had
changed. I suppose that I shouldn't have that IP in my /etc/hosts
file, but for historical reasons it has been there for along time. It
originally got there because the IP was listed on the settings page,
but the new settings page doesn't show IPs. Something about security
issues -- but not well explained, since I can't figger out what the
security issues are.

So, on the third fone call to tech support, I got someone to tell me
what exactly had changed at the time of the cluster transition, and it
turned out to be the IP address for mail.pacifier.com . I fixed that,
and mail started flowing again.

I should re-read the DNS setup rules again, so that I better
understand how to avoid this issue in the future.

I also asked tech support to put up a 'linux users' web page that
lists all the details that WE might need. It's seldom that linux users
need help configuring their specific tools; but having the appropriate
ISP specific data in a place that said users can find certainly helps
us setup our tools correctly.

Thanx,
-bk

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Sun Apr 20 12:10:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Sun Apr 20 12:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Accused of being open relay and blocked still...
In-Reply-To: <20030420072923.8488.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <20030420072923.8488.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1050865740.11348.23.camel@main>

On Sun, 2003-04-20 at 00:29, Michael Robinson wrote:
> Trying to send an email maria at m-a-schmid.de from my michael at robinson-west.com 
> private mail account.  I don't know when the retest to see if I'm an open 
> relay happens and even if I am one.  I would assume not anymore because I have
> a rcpthosts file under /var/qmail/control that only lists hosts local to my 
> lan and my domain, robinson-west.com.  This is just irritating.


Hey Michael,
Adding rcpthosts to /var/qmail/control is a big part of stopping qmail
from being an open relay. There is one more thing though: Since qmail
runs under Dan Bernstein's tcpserver it uses tcprules to secure the port
25 connection. The rules are compiled into a .cdb file and read into
tcpserver with the -x option. Normally the rules are placed into
/etc/tcp.smtp and compiled with `/var/qmail/bin/qmailctl cdb`. You might
want to look into the /etc/tcp.smtp file and make sure that the only
entry is one that looks something like <10.0.0.:allow,RELAYCLIENT="">
where 10.0.0. is replaced with your internal network address. Once that
you have finished with tcpserver then you can be certain that you not an
open relay.

For more info, see Dan's notes at http://cr.yp.to.


-- 
Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>

brought up by the process that is hosting the other end of the tunnel.  

>From the instructions for bochs, you need to add the ifconfig line to a
script that is executed by bochs as it starts.  You'll be able to tell
if it works by running the ifconfig command after bocks has started,
you'll see the tun0 device listed and configured.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

* Stop the Oregon "Super-DMCA!"

Many states are being pressured by the Motion Picture Association of
America (MPAA) to adopt legislation that would have serious
consequences for freedom of speech, encryption, and the public's
rights. It's not too late to make a difference! Tell your state
legislators to stop this "Super DMCA" (S-DMCA) legislation.

Send a letter using EFF's Action Center:
http://action.eff.org/action/index.asp?step=2&item=2630

Join EFF:
https://secure.eff.org

* EFF Opposes State Level "Super-DMCAs"

Some States Pass, Others Consider Copyright Legislation

San Francisco - The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) last week
released a detailed analysis of the dangers posed by digital copyright
bills in individual states.

The product of stealth lobbying efforts by the Motion Picture
Association of America (MPAA), these new measures are aimed at
criminalizing the possession of what the MPAA calls "unlawful
communication and access devices," but are so broad that they
could ban critical security and privacy tools online as well as
restrict what machines you can connect to the cable, satellite, and
Internet lines in your home.

Because the bills are more extreme versions of the nationwide Digital
Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), pundits refer to them as "super-DMCA"
legislation.

Even before these activities crossed activists' radar, seven states
(Colorado, Delaware, Illinois, Michigan, Oregon, Pennsylvania and
Wyoming) had already enacted them into law. Similar bills have been
introduced and are currently pending in Arkansas, Florida, Georgia,
Massachusetts, Tennessee and Texas.

"The 'super-DMCA' measures represent special interest legislation that
dramatically expands the reach of the federal DMCA, which has already
put fair use, innovation, free speech and competition in peril," said
EFF Senior Intellectual Property Attorney Fred von Lohmann.
"Communication service providers -- meaning ISPs, cable companies, and
providers of digital entertainment services -- can use this
legislation to restrict what you can connect to your Internet
connection and cable or satellite television lines and can ban a
variety of tools critical to protecting the anonymity and security of
Internet users."

EFF strongly opposes these state super-DMCA bills as unnecessary and
overbroad. The proposed bills represent the worst kind of special
interest legislation, sacrificing the public interest in favor of the
self-serving interests of one industry.

Links
For this release:
http://www.eff.org/IP/DMCA/states/20030414_eff_sdmca_pr.php

EFF analysis of state "super-DMCA" bills:
http://www.eff.org/IP/DMCA/states/200304_sdmca_eff_analysis.php

EFF state-level "Super DMCA" initiatives archive, with Action Alerts
for people in affected states:
http://www.eff.org/IP/DMCA/states/

EFF white paper on unintended consequences of the DMCA:
http://www.eff.org/IP/DMCA/20030102_dmca_unintended_consequences.html

* Electronic Frontier Foundation Supports Unlicensed Spectrum

Asks FCC to Broaden Wireless Broadcast Realm

San Francisco - The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) recently
supported a spectrum policy proposal from the Federal Communications
Commission (FCC) and asked the FCC to acknowledge its First Amendment
obligation to allocate additional spectrum for unlicensed use.
Unlicensed use of spectrum would permit the expansion of wireless
communication, including Wi-Fi-style technology.

EFF asked the FCC to adopt the policy proposed in Notice of Inquiry
02-328, "Additional Spectrum for Unlicensed Devices Below 900 MHz and
in the 3 GHz Band." In this notice, the FCC seeks comment on the
allocation of additional spectrum for unlicensed use, similar to the
allocation that makes Wi-Fi devices possible. The Commission proposes
to carve spectrum for unlicensed use out of unused TV station
frequencies, which would dramatically increase the "open" spectrum
available for technological innovation.

"Spectrum regulation is a form of speech regulation," said EFF
Outreach Coordinator Cory Doctorow. "We support the Commission's
proposal to make more spectrum available for unlicensed applications
like Wi-Fi, moving us closer to a world where we all may speak over
the airwaves."

The FCC traditionally justifies regulating spectrum use on grounds of
scarcity, arguing that if anyone were allowed to broadcast, the
resulting chaos would create so much interference that no one would be
heard. The success of Wi-Fi and other uses of the unlicensed 2.4GHz
band demonstrates that unlicensed use models allow far more speakers
than the FCC's old "command-and-control" model of spectrum allocation.

Links
For this release:
http://www.eff.org/Infra/Wireless_cellular_radio/20030417_eff_spectrum_pr.php

EFF comment on proposed FCC unlicensed spectrum regulation:
http://www.eff.org/Infra/Wireless_cellular_radio/20030417_eff_fcc_spectrum_letter.php

FCC notice of inquiry on unlicensed spectrum:
http://www.fcc.gov/Document_Indexes/Engineering_Technology/2002_index_OET_Notice.html

* Editorial: Finding a Better Way with P2P

An edited version of the following editorial, written by EFF
senior staff attorney Fred von Lohmann, appeared in the Daily
Princetonian on Monday, April 14. The editorial appeared a few days
after Princeton undergraduate Daniel Peng was sued by 16 major record
labels for running a LAN indexing tool on the Princeton campus
network. Similar lawsuits were filed against three other
undergraduates at Renssalaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) and Michigan
Technological University (MTU).

These lawsuits are only the most recent examples of the lengths to
which the entertainment industries are willing to go in their campaign
against what they call "Internet piracy." Increasingly, we are facing
a stark choice -- either continuing on our present course, with the
entertainment industries demanding and obtaining the power to
re-architect the Internet, or choosing a path that gets copyright
owners (and artists) paid without compromising our freedoms. The
following editorial explores a possible alternative.

~ ~ ~ ~

Finding a Better Way with P2P
Fred von Lohmann

Suing college students. Forcing ISPs to rat out customers. Petitioning
Congress for unprecedented vigilante powers. Deploying armies of
lawyers to sue technology companies. Threatening universities and
corporations. Demanding that ISPs disconnect tens of thousands of
Internet users. Hiring electronic enforcers to monitor computer users.

None of these efforts by the recording industry has put a single
nickel into the pockets of a musician. And none of these efforts has
slowed the spread of peer-to-peer ("P2P") file sharing. More Americans
have used file-sharing software than voted for the President. 

But we are paying a price. Responding to pressure from the
entertainment industry, the University of Wyoming is now monitoring
and recording all university Internet traffic. One hundred Naval
Academy cadets have been disciplined for file-sharing. Investment in
innovative P2P companies has dried up. Some members of Congress,
addled by a steady diet of propaganda and campaign contributions from
the entertainment industries, have suggested that the answer might be
to expel, or even jail, college students. Music fans are frustrated
and alienated from the musicians they love.

The hysteria over P2P has gotten out of hand. While protecting
copyright is a worthwhile endeavor, suing college students will not
get artists a penny more in royalties. Conscripting cash-strapped
universities to act as muscle for the entertainment industries is
absurd. Putting entire universities under constant surveillance is
simply unacceptable. 

There is a better way.

The problem is not P2P file sharing. In fact, file sharing is a
remarkable innovation that has enabled a world-wide community of music
fans to build the greatest library of recorded music in the history of
the world. 

The problem is that artists are not getting paid. It is time to
address the problem. 

The right answer is obvious: we need to collect a pool of money from
Internet users and agree on a fair way to divide it among the artists
and copyright owners.  There are many ways to do this.  One
interesting way is with something copyright lawyers call a "compulsory
license."  It might work something like this: Internet service
providers (including universities) might add a flat monthly surcharge
to the fees they charge for Internet access. Part of these fees would
be remitted to the record labels, while some would be paid directly to
the artists (who today frequently are victims of unfair contracts and
crooked royalty accounting). The fees would be divided up fairly,
based on popularity on the file-sharing networks, measured with
sampling methods like the Neilsen ratings that respect our privacy
while tabulating the P2P "charts." Having paid the fee, fans could
engage in private, non-commercial file-sharing without worrying about
being hunted down like criminals.

That's only one possible way to get artists paid; there are many
others to choose from. Systems like this are already in place in a
variety of other areas. Anyone can record a cover of a song, without
having to ask permission from the song-writer, so long as they pay a
standard fee per copy they sell. In the cable television arena, cable
networks do not have to ask for copyright permissions in order to
retransmit over-the-air programming. Instead, they simply pay a fee to
those who own the copyrights in the programs. Webcasters, similarly,
are allowed to play whatever they like, so long as they pay a fee set
by the Library of Congress. 

The university environment could be a testing ground for alternative
compulsory licensing models. In exchange for standing up strongly for
their users' privacy rights, universities could begin negotiating for
experimental campus-wide blanket licenses for file-sharing. 

After all, the reality is that file-sharing is almost certainly going
to remain a fact of campus life. The debate should be about getting
artists and copyright owners fairly compensated, not about how many
students should be expelled or how to install surveillance equipment
on campus networks. 

Fred von Lohmann is a senior staff attorney at the Electronic Frontier
Foundation (www.eff.org), a membership-supported nonprofit
organization that defends civil liberties and free expression in the
digital world.

Links
Editorial in the Daily Princetonian:
http://www.dailyprincetonian.com/archives/2003/04/14/opinion/7930.shtml

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Dear Elected Official,

I am concerned that Bill 2892 appears to have been waylaid in the House
General Government Committee(1). This bill would ask Oregon government agencies 
to consider using Open Source software alternatives, potentially saving the 
state millions of dollars.

Because the bill allows the Government to choose commercial products when that's 
the best choice, I don't see why the committee is preventing the
legislature from considering this bill. (Yes, I understand that Microsoft is
lobbying heavily against it).

In these budgetary times, I think it's wrong to not consider options for saving 
money that could be better spent on schools and healthcare.

Please use your influence to get this bill considered in the light of day,

Name
City, State



1. The Oregonian: 
http://www.oregonlive.com/business/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/business/1050666959318260.xml

2. Bill 2892
http://www.leg.state.or.us/03reg/measures/hb2800.dir/hb2892.intro.html

From michael at robinson-west.com  Mon Apr 21 15:47:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Mon Apr 21 15:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux, Portland Schools, and Costs
In-Reply-To: <1050878853.15795.21.camel@lana>
References: <1050878853.15795.21.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <20030421224215.17896.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Sunday 20 April 2003 03:47 pm, you wrote:
> I am currently running for Portland School Board, and one of my
> positions is that the Board needs to get the community involved to cut
> costs and strengthen the schools.
>
> Last year, many of you were involved in an effort to convert many of the
> systems in the schools and throughout the district from Windoze to
> Linux.  I am wondering if you might want to share with me your
> experiences -- for those involved -- with working with the District, how
> well-received you were, what could have been done to make things easier,
> and how much money was saved (if any).
>
> If you are currently employed with the District and don't wish to give
> your name publicly, you can contact my off-list and I will not reveal
> the source.
>
> Thanks.

Well for Scappoose School District I put a sound card into a machine
that I essentially donated and installed the drivers.  It was a 98SE system
and the driver tree was disgusting, but the part that bothered me the
most about the job was the proprietary nature of this Compaq.
I wonder if Linux could even be installed to it.  I am concerned that
XP is designed to be incompatible with LILO also.  I'm concerned about
integrated video cards in various motherboards that don't have that
great a set of features where their features can be matched in Linux
compatible alternatives yet they aren't Linux compatible.  The moral
of the story is that schools have computers that could be designed
to be Linux friendly yet they likely aren't and this is because these
machines are either offloaded on schools or they get in there by
other means, corporate donations perhaps?  If a manufacturer
puts something out that hasn't been ported to Linux maybe it should
be labeled so that those who don't want a non Linux ready machine
can more easily avoid it.  At first a soundblaster live which is supposed
to work supposedly on any PCI system was tried but it didn't work so
I put in an ISA card instead and upgraded my own system.  
Unfortunately, the system stopped working some time after I put 
the sound card in.  I volunteered to do this.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEDJCJAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20030421231018.17945.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Sunday 20 April 2003 10:58 pm, you wrote:
> We?re encountering problem with our mail server. Recently we?ve change ISP,
> we?ve changed the IP add from the one given by the new ISP. Our users can
> receive and send mail through their workstation using an MS client. The
> problem is our IMP webmail, we cannot access mail.bhpi.com.ph remotely.  At
> home using an internet prepaid I can ping the mail server?s NIC, but
> unsuccessful  when I try accessing it through web browser. Where do I start
> to solve this problem?
>
> We badly need this web mail for our VIPs abroad.  I hope someone could help
> me with this

>
>
>
> TIA
> ---
> Billy

If you had to change numbering addressing for your site is likely to be 
broken for 24 to 48 hours after the change.  Remember to go to your domain
registrar and update the information about your site.  If it's your ISP how
easy, just check with them.  Update your domain registrar information, update 
your dns servers for your domain both private and public servers, and update
the ip assignments on your routers and gateways.  Your ISP should be able
to tell you shich number is the gateway.  Make sure your domain name 
registar has updated the Internet whois databases to point to where your 
name servers are now.  Remember that it takes usually 48 hours for that 
change to kick in.  If your clients are looking for your nameserver in the
wrong place, they won't be able to connect.

   --  Michael C. Robinson

	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304211622460.10730-100000@caddis.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1050967804.8912.9.camel@arisu>

On Mon, 2003-04-21 at 16:25, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Someone please explain to me why:
> 	"kill -HUP syslogd"
> fails on my RH 7.3 system ("no such pid") while:
> 	"/etc/rc.d/init.d/syslog restart"
> works.
> 
>   I thought that signals could be used with both BSD and SysV style init
> scripts.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Rich
> 
> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

kill only works for PIDs (Process Id) because you only want to kill 1
process

killall matches by name, so the command you really wanted was

killall -HUP syslogd

From michael at robinson-west.com  Mon Apr 21 17:30:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Mon Apr 21 17:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS problem maybe....
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEEICJAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEEICJAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20030422002532.18035.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Monday 21 April 2003 04:47 pm, you wrote:
> We change ISP a couple of months ago. We only notice the problem when some
> of our users complained, that they cannot access the webmail. We can access
> and view the page within our network. It is only our mail server that is
> having problem, our web server is up and running.
>
Hmmm, does your mail server have a direct ip from you ISP or do you need to 
port forward to it from your web server?  IMP uses imap if I remember right 
so maybe imap is working from inside your network but not outside because the 
permissions don't allow the outside ip of your web server to connect to it.  
Does IMP work from inside your network?  I can't remember if webmail IMP 
config sets the actual ip it is being hosted at or just the hostname.  Maybe 
your web server is missing part of php that is needed to open imap 
connections.  I had trouble with IMP so I gave up on it.  At this point I'm 
planning on secure imap connections.  Another way to provide an off laptop or 
off workstation client like IMP is to provide X terminal support through 
a secure IPSec tunnel.  Maybe check out www.ltsp.org and look into 
that option if IMP proves too confusing to fix.  It might be slow for a lot
of other things over the net but it should be fine for email, especially if
you use a lite window manager in place of kde or gnome.  A site to look
at that micht help is www.openna.com.  Maybe look for Securing and
Optimizing Redhat Linux Ultimate Edition at www.tldp.org.  Redhat isn't
being advocated by me as "the best," though it's seems fairly reasonable
if you compile most of the software you want to use from other sources.  
Redhat seems to work a lot better for example when you use 
www.kernel.org source code. :-)

Take one server at a time, there's no point trying to fix 
IMP if it doesn't really need fixing because the actual problem 
is with the mail server.  What mail server do you use?  I use qmail 
because I couldn't figure out Postfix and my original sendmail 
server eventually broke down.  Qmail is a lot faster than 
sendmail and you can read the help files in the source code 
to install it fairly easily.  There are even migration hints for 
sendmail users though I've never tried that myself.  The only
thing I haven't implemented is Maildir as it seems fairly 
complicated though I guess there's no need for converting 
if you don't put mailspools on nfs shares which apparently isn't
all that great an idea anyways.  Which brings up a possibility,
if using maildir make sure your imap client isn't for the old
mailbox format.

For troubleshooting this I'd look at the log of changes from
the pre change environment to the current one first.  Check
the firewall closely, I think with both ipchains and iptables that
there are tools to check if the ports are open that IMP needs
to make it's imap connections successfully.  I've seen many
recommendations for ethereal and I like iptraf.

A quick thing to check if your IMP is a secure page is whether
or not the page itself can be accessed by your clients which 
may suggest an apache config file error.  With IMP one
gets php errors when something is broken that IMP needs
though I found it very difficult to troubleshoot with these
errors myself.

Check firewalls on both mail and web server, either firewall
misconfigured could be causing all your problems.

If you can get the equipment maybe create a simulated internet
with two machines and use three more to simulate your web
server, mail server, and a single client respectively.  The test
network only needs to troubleshoot the larger one so lower
power machines are probably fine.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

Sounds about right.  Portland Community College has or had
a deal with Microsoft that involved the donation of a lot of equipment
but of course this meant for PCC that officially it has to be a Windows
shop.  I told Heckman once that my interest is becoming a Linux
systems professional which I got criticized for roundly though it was
interesting that he claimed he has had some experience with Linux
before the conversation ended.

Some people are playing a foolish game with Microsoft.  Perhaps
they don't want to change or this is a manifestation of some company
can be held responsible and more importantly sued.  The latter is petty, 
but quite possible.  Another possibility is that funding has been so 
uncertain for so long for Oregon schools that behaviors and attitudes 
have adapted in unfortunate ways.  There may not be much concern 
about wasted money because schools are a sacred cow which have
wanted, and in some places sadly needed , more for a long 
time.  What's telling is that we haven't heard about any administrator 
cuts of any kind yet  even though we've seen school days and 
teachers, etc., hit the chopping block  Are we flooding our schools with 
reform programs resulting in more administrators and high overhead?  
Is the money distributed right throughout Oregon's public school system 
on a statewide and per district level?  No if too much is going to IT or 
other overhead.

The politics of Microsoft have clearly invaded the public sphere 
where Microsoft dominance is accepted perhaps because of the harsh 
methods it used to get where it is, using the work of others of course, 
still in evidence today.  Amazing considering Microsoft is classified as 
a monopoly and should arguably be taking action to improve it's 
own reputation and status.  This political interfence in my opinion 
is unacceptable for a general focus academic environment that needs 
to focus on computer science and the related fields within that which 
span far more than an operating system owned by one man.

Requiring public institutions to consider open source alternatives may be the
medicine that's needed.  Perhaps it will provide the political cover to choose
alternatives to Microsoft.  What I'd really like to see is new donation laws
regulating the strings that can be attached and I'd like to see Microsoft's
software licensing practices reviewed by the courts in light of how XP 
violates people's right to privacy with it's ability to collect any 
information from a system it is installed on.  Companies with tons of money
shouldn't influence the choice of software anymore more than the
brilliant individual with very little or no money.  The cost of buggy software
is quite high and individual discomfort with computers because of
privacy or other abuse will only have negative impacts on the high tech
sector as a whole.  I doubt many people are going to want to vote from
a Microsoft Windows workstation, so far it hasn't happened yet.

If the government would seperate the application and operating system
divisions of Microsoft and not allow these new companies to enter into 
exclusive secret agreements with each other it would go a long ways 
towards opening things up.  This should have been done already.  
Oh well.

I think the best approach to promoting open source in public places is
to develop an impressive presentation and gain an understanding of what
our officials expect, want, and need in their offices.  Windows compatibility
and integration is a lot of work, so flick Redmond.  There are a lot of ways
to deploy Linux to be affective in different venues and for varying needs.
IBM is helping with their Linux ads, perhaps it's only a matter of time before
the software culture will change.

Does this help?

    % rpm -qf /usr/lib/pkgconfig/gtk+-2.0.pc
    gtk2-devel-2.2.1-4

    % cat gtk+-2.0.pc
    prefix=/usr
    exec_prefix=/usr
    libdir=/usr/lib
    includedir=/usr/include
    target=x11

    gtk_binary_version=2.2.0
    gtk_host=i386-redhat-linux-gnu

    Name: GTK+
    Description: GIMP Tool Kit (${target} target)
    Version: 2.2.1
    Requires: gdk-${target}-2.0 atk
    Libs: -L${libdir} -lgtk-${target}-2.0
    Cflags: -I${includedir}/gtk-2.0

This is from a RedHat 9 install.

Subject: [PLUG] Reaching port 25

  OK, experts. Here's a real puzzle for you. What might make port 25
unreachable from one machine but not from another machine on the same
network?

  Postfix-2.0.7 worked just fine. I freshened the rpm to 2.0.8 and outgoing
mail stopped: smtp could not reach port 25 and the connection timed out,
deferring all outbound messages. Spent most of yesterday building
postfix-2.0.9 and BerkeleyDB-4.1.25 and upgrading postfix to that version.
Outgoing mail worked again -- for a few messages -- before port 25 once
again became unreachable. This time it was the queue manager (qmgr) that
showed up in /var/log/maillog.

  The postfix experts appear to be baffled by this and I'm certainly beyond
my understanding here. But, it's quite frustrating and distracting to me and
I'd _really_ like to resolve this ASAP. Your help is greatly appreciated.

  Synopsis: I can ping and traceroute my external IP address from both
hosts. The IP address is also reachable externally and all incoming mail --
including spam -- has no problems making it in. nntp, http, ftp, ssh and
other services work from the one workstation. The _only_ thing not working
is outgoing mail from that machine. This host is running sendmail and I can
use it to get mail out.

  This should be an interesting challenge to you. I hope that you can help
me to resolve the problem early today.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304221018500.21313-100000@caddis.appl-ecosys.com>

  Something here has badly broken and not even the folks on the
postfix-users list -- or Wietse -- can identify the problem. Here's a
synopsis:

  Postfix-2.0.9 running on host 'salmo'. When I'm logged in on 'salmo' (my
workstation, too), I can no longer send out mail. It's deferred beause the
connection times out at 'appl-ecosys.com'. This started last Thursday
afternoon.

  When I also log in on host 'caddis', as I am now, I can invoke pine and
send out mail with no problem, as long as it is addressed to an individual
or a mail list. When I try to send mail to all subscribers to a mail list I
maintain (all 88 of 'em), that, too, is deferred. I think that's because it
has to go through majordomo on 'salmo' and, therefore, also postfix. In
caddis' /var/log/maillog I see a reference to mail.appl-ecosys.com which is
a synonym for salmo.appl-ecosys.com.

  Why would port 25 be unreachable from one host but not another? I suspect
it has something to do with how postfix sees 'myhostname' and 'mydomain',
but I really don't know for sure.

  I recall from a year ago when I first installed postfix that I had to run
the 'hostname' command and change it to the FQDN 'salmo.appl-ecosy.com'
before postfix would start and run. Afterwards I changed it back to just
'salmo' because that's what all the other software expected to see.

  Is there a postfix guru here who can help me track down this problem and
get it fixed? It's taking a _lot_ of my time and frustrating everyone
involved.

Thanks,

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Tue Apr 22 11:44:01 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Tue Apr 22 11:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] HB 2892 Update
Message-ID: <1051037000.1775.22.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Dear Friends,

Never have I been so proud to be a member of this community. By your own
initiative, you have written, called, and met with your Representatives
regarding HB 2892. During this crucial phase, I ask you to continue to
push for this bill; I cannot stress enough how critical this is; a
strong showing of public support will make the difference, guaranteed.

As many of you know, much activity has surrounded HB 2892 in the past
few days. Last Friday, the Oregonian ran a front-page article in the
Business section with the headline, "Stiff opposition derails
open-source measure." Industry group Lobbyists from Microsoft, the
American Electronic Association, and others have worked hard to "make
this Bill go away."

Guess what? Thanks to all of you who have written and called, this bill
has _not_ gone away. I thank each of you who have taken the time to
write or call your Representative or Senator in support of HB 2892.

Further, you can be sure that myself and others will continue to work
diligently toward the passage of this bill. There is no question that I
will do my very best to see this bill pass into law, and I won't give up
on this bill without a fight, of that you can be certain.

There is every chance that we can continue to move this bill forward
through hard work and continued vocal support of this bill. I am not
exaggerating when I say that your support can very well make the
difference. Please take just a few moments to write to your
Representative or Senator in support of HB 2892. The Oregon Legislature
has a web page that lets you automatically write your Legislatures here:

  http://www.leg.state.or.us/writelegsltr/writeset.htm

For those of you who are now just getting up to speed with HB 2892, you
may view HB 2892 itself, the Bill's amendments, and several news
articles here:

   http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/index.html

Also, here is a brief overview:

HB 2892, or the "Open Source Consideration Bill" is a bill currently in
the General Government Committee that calls for the consideration of
Open Source Software whenever State agencies make IT software procurment
decisions.

HB 2892 is an important Bill for several reasons:

   1) HB 2892 will likely save the State of Oregon millions. The
Department of Administrative Services (the central purchasing arm of
the for Oregon) estimates that there are over 53,000 PC's and over 2,300
servers in use by State agencies. This does not count machines used by
Oregon counties or cities. Clearly, if these computers ran software
that do not carry recurring fees or usage restrictions, the State will
definitely see a fiscal benefit. I call to critics of this statement to
both the verbal and written testimony of Oregon educators and to Q3 2002
SEC filings from Amazon.com; they claimed a savings of 17 million in
just one quarter!

  2) This bill helps level the playing field for companies competing for
Government IT contracts. As many of you know, Microsoft controls over 90
percent of all of the PC Operating systems and the desktop Office Suite.
This bill encourages competition by requiring the State to consider Open
Source when procuring software for the State.

  3) This bill will help businesses in the State not only with the
leveling of the procurement playing field discussed above, but also
because the focus is now more on services rather than costly software.
Further, the money that the State saves in licencing costs could be used
to enhance service to the public or to create jobs by helping Oregon
business. This, I think we all can agree (except the industry trade
groups) is preferable to sending license fees out of State.

Critics of the bill argue that this legislation is simply not necessary
because there exists today an open process by which the State may make
it's software purchasing decisions.

Yeah, right.

While there is no official law that says that the State cannot choose
one software product or another, as the old saying goes, "nobody ever
got fired for buying Microsoft." Those who are experienced in IT can
tell you that, like many other fields, managers are often apprehensive
to change their habits, even if the alternative offer more benefit at a
reduced cost.

Secondly, it has been my observation that as many businesses consider
Open Source solutions, the Business Software Alliance seems to have an
uncanny knack for dropping by with a "Software Assurance" audit at just
the right time. We know that this happens in Government too, as
evidenced by the BSA's "random" audit threat to Portland School
Districts last year.

That is definitely not an open marketplace.

Further, Jim Craven, lobbyist for the American Electronics Association,
on Friday told the Oregonian, "Our concern with the bill is the mandate
to state purchasers that they 'shall' do this or 'shall not' do that."

This is basically a falsehood. It implies that "shall consider" equals,
"shall procure Open Source." This Bill simply asks for the IT decision
makers of Oregon to consider Open Source while they are making IT
software purchasing decisions.

Oh, by the way, when you go out to the American Electronics
Association's web sight and search their member directory, guess who we
find:

   Microsoft
   MN - Bloomington    Division

   Microsoft
   TX - Austin    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Bellevue Sales
   WA - Bellevue    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Boise Sales
   ID - Boise    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Denver
   CO - Denver    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Ft. Lauderdale Sales
   FL - Fort Lauderdale    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Orange County
   CA - Irvine    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Portland Sales
   OR - Portland    Division

   Microsoft Corporation Sacramento
   CA - Sacramento    Division

The list goes on. You may view the member list for the American
Electronics Association on their web site here:

   http://www.aeanet.org/default.asp


There's still a long way to go. If you have not written or called your
representative please take a moment to do so; during this precarious
moment with the bill, I'm not exaggerating when I say that it is you who
will make the difference. Keep up the good work!

HB 2892 is clearly a non-partisan win-win bill for the State of Oregon.
It saves Oregon money, it promotes open standards, and it gives the
State more control over public data.

I'll keep you posted.


Very Truly Yours,


Cooper Stevenson
Em:  cooper at cooper.stevenson.name
Www: http://www.mwvlug.org

I have been sort of quiet about HB 2892, but I done some things
behind the scenes.  I don't really know how the group feels
about this bill, but I suspect most of us favor the bill.
Given this assumption, I have written a number of letters
which make it sound like the group supports HB 2892.
I also tryed to testify at the committee hearing a couple
weeks ago, but couldn't because of time limitations for
testimory.  I don't know if any of my letters have done any
good, because I sure haven't gotten much feedback, but ...

Finally, I want to make a couple recommendations for people
writing letter and doing other things to support this bill.

    (1)  HB 2892 has nothing to do with Microsoft.
         Many of the representatives don't understand or believe
         all the bad things Microsoft has done.  Thus, bashing
         Microsoft is likely to be counter productive.

    (2)  Why do we need HB 2892?  Won't it give special breaks to one
         particular type of software?
         The big name industry groups are claiming that they simply
         want a level playing field, so the state can purchase the
         best software.
         We Open Source people are not addressing this argument at all.
         Saying that Open Source software is high quality and/or cost
         effective isn't relevant.
         Instead, we must argue that:
             -  Open Source is so special that it is in the public
                interest to give it a special break.
         or else
             -  Open Source software uses such a different business
                model that we need HB 2892 to get equal consideration.

    (3)  Many of us make our living creating and supporting Open Source software.
         The opponents to HB 2892 have tryed to portray the Open Source
         community as unemployed idealistic socialists who write
         software in a spare time.  We have a Republician legislature
         which is very friendly to small business.  I would like them
         to see the Open Source community as consultants and writers
         and high tech businessmen who make their living from Open Source
         software.

    (4)  Open Source Software needs to be considered because
         it can save the state significant money.
         I think our legislature and our governor understands
         budgets and will probably be proposing a tax increase.
         Can they expect the citizens to pass such an increase
         when the state is wasting money on things like software
         licenses they don't need?

    (5)  Finally, there are all the issues around Open Data and
         open access to state records.
         I think this is extremely important, but I haven't been
         pushing arguments along these lines, because I'm not sure
         they would influence many of our current legislators.
         However, I may be wrong about this.

                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213

                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

From zot at zotconsulting.com  Tue Apr 22 14:16:02 2003
From: zot at zotconsulting.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Apr 22 14:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OO how to search for paragraph mark
In-Reply-To: <1050942742.16482.2.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1050942742.16482.2.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1051046303.2216.374.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

Turn on "regular expressions" then use $

Now be careful, you want to make sure you select first, and have clicked
"current selection only."

But want you really want is a "reformat" command.

So I looked in help.  No luck.

Then I said, hey I am running the beta!  I can record macro.

So I opened a new doc.
I typed some text with paragraphs.
I hi-lighted the text.
I select tools->macro->record
I hit CTRL-F for find.
I entered $ in the find
I entered a space in the replace
I clicked on regular expressions.
I check selection only.
I hit replace all.
I hit save.
I clicked stop macro.
I saved as "Standard->Module1->Reformat"
I then clicked Assign.
I went to keyboard.
I went to CTRL-T in shortcut keys
In function I selected Openoffice BASIC Macros->Standard->Module1
I selected Reformat
I clicked modify.

It works.  Please note though, this does not take into consideration
paragraphs that end in . needing two spaces to follow, or lines that end
in spaces, or what not.  This is like Join in vi.

A better macro would select the current paragraph.  Right now it will
probably reformat the whole document if nothing is selected.


here is the macro from macro->edit

REM  *****  BASIC  *****

Sub Main

End Sub


sub Reformat
rem
----------------------------------------------------------------------
rem define variables
dim document   as object
dim dispatcher as object
rem
----------------------------------------------------------------------
rem get access to the document
document   = ThisComponent.CurrentController.Frame
dispatcher = createUnoService("com.sun.star.frame.DispatchHelper")

rem
----------------------------------------------------------------------
dim args1(17) as new com.sun.star.beans.PropertyValue
args1(0).Name = "SearchItem.StyleFamily"
args1(0).Value = 2
args1(1).Name = "SearchItem.CellType"
args1(1).Value = 0
args1(2).Name = "SearchItem.RowDirection"
args1(2).Value = true
args1(3).Name = "SearchItem.AllTables"
args1(3).Value = false
args1(4).Name = "SearchItem.Backward"
args1(4).Value = false
args1(5).Name = "SearchItem.Pattern"
args1(5).Value = false
args1(6).Name = "SearchItem.Content"
args1(6).Value = false
args1(7).Name = "SearchItem.AsianOptions"
args1(7).Value = false
args1(8).Name = "SearchItem.AlgorithmType"
args1(8).Value = 1
args1(9).Name = "SearchItem.SearchFlags"
args1(9).Value = 71680
args1(10).Name = "SearchItem.SearchString"
args1(10).Value = "$"
args1(11).Name = "SearchItem.ReplaceString"
args1(11).Value = " "
args1(12).Name = "SearchItem.Locale"
args1(12).Value = 255
args1(13).Name = "SearchItem.ChangedChars"
args1(13).Value = 2
args1(14).Name = "SearchItem.DeletedChars"
args1(14).Value = 2
args1(15).Name = "SearchItem.InsertedChars"
args1(15).Value = 2
args1(16).Name = "SearchItem.TransliterateFlags"
args1(16).Value = 1280
args1(17).Name = "SearchItem.Command"
args1(17).Value = 3

dispatcher.executeDispatch(document, ".uno:ExecuteSearch", "", 0,
args1())


end sub

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Apr 22 14:44:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Apr 22 14:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reaching port 25
In-Reply-To: <1051047264.1849.6.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304221439360.29726-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 22 Apr 2003, Derek Loree wrote:

> This should tell you where the packets are being held up anyway.
 
  Thanks to a fellow named Don at Black Sun Communications, somewhere on the
right coast, the problem is solved.

  Turns out that in /etc/postfix/main.cf there are two 'relay' variables. I
had them set (believing that was the right thing to do based on all my
reading last year prior to installing postfix). Versions from 1.x through
2.0.7 couldn't care less what those variables had stuffed in 'em. However,
2.0.8 and up _do_ care that they have _anything_ in them for my small
network. Commenting them out and restarting postfix worked like a massive
enema on the mail queue and all's working again as it should be.

  I'd still like someont to check my configuration of floppyfw-2.9.1 before
I take myself off the 'Net with a misconfigured set of iptables.

Thanks,

Rich

Subject: [PLUG] Samba and Domain groups
In-Reply-To: <2311.195.232.54.24.1051051483.squirrel@sautez.com>

I'm trying to get a Linux Samba server to allow access
to groups in the Domain. I tried "valid users =
@groupname" but that seems to only allow groups from
the local /etc/groups file. The docs talk about Unix
groups and NIS groups, but I couldn't find mention of
Domain groups. I would think this would be a
fundamental part of being part of a domain.

How does one give access to a Samba share to groups on
the NT Domain?

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Apr 22 19:26:01 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue Apr 22 19:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <Law15-F805C74a24LnK0000f243@hotmail.com>
References: <Law15-F805C74a24LnK0000f243@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <200304221924.46066.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I run a single CPU system using OpenBSD as a stateful firewall for my 
home network. I've got dual NICS with one NIC connect to my cable modem 
and the other NIC runs into an 8 port switch. The default install is 
very secure with SSH being the only means to login into the box. 

I'm using Linux for my primary  workstation and other severs within my 
network. I don't need an SMP box for a firewall so using one of the 
freely available BSD OS's can be a reasonable choice. I've found 
OpenBSD's packet-filter "pf" rules much easier to understand and write 
than the sometimes clunky "iptables" or "ipchains" commands that Linux 
uses. I say this after running a Linux-based firewall for 4 1/2 years 
on my home network.

Something else to keep in mind is that what do you do if you ever need 
to run any sort of commercial applications under BSD? I haven't looked 
into it but I've had the need to run Oracle and BEA's WebLogic and 
since I was using Linux this wasn't an issue. I don't know if any of 
the BSDs can run these things. They might but I've never looked into 
the binary compatibilities or emulations that might be available under 
BSD.

For a dedicated file or print servers a BSD box with Samba works quite 
nicely in an office environment. I've got my old firewall test system 
with OpenBSD on it pulling print server duty at work now.

Tony

From dcf at aracnet.com  Tue Apr 22 20:20:03 2003
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Tue Apr 22 20:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <Law15-F805C74a24LnK0000f243@hotmail.com>
References: <Law15-F805C74a24LnK0000f243@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20030422193058.A35840@grond.sourballs.org>

On Tue, 22 Apr 2003, Stephen Young wrote:
> I am building a new server for my house, I have heard a lot of talk about
> freebsd being more stable and faster than linux.  I am considering giving
> freebsd a shot, see what the fuss is about.
>
> Anyone with experience in any of the *BSD's have any thoughts on the subject
> ?

I've been using FreeBSD 4.6 since January.  Prior to that I ran SuSE for
about 3 years, and Slackware for 2 years before that.

Main things that I've noticed -

install process is a bit primitive, compared to current Linux distros I'm
familiar with (reminded me of the first Slackware install I did).  Disk
partitioning not as straightforward as Linux fdisk.

FreeBSD attempts to put tight controls on what gets installed where on the
machine.  'Core' system files go into /usr/bin or /usr/sbin; *all*
additional applications go into /usr/local.  This way the base system
files can be completed wiped and reinstalled without affecting later
user-added files.  If you use the 'ports' collection to add software,
everything should be added according to FreeBSD's rules.  (Tradeoff, of
course, is that very cutting-edge stuff will take a while to get ported.)

In general, the standard way to add or update files on the system is by
compiling from source.  There are utilities that make it a one-command
operation to add/upgrade any single ported application, or base system
files, or indeed the entire system.  FreeBSD has its own package database
mechanism that tracks software versions. Needed dependencies can be
resolved, downloaded and rebuilt automatically.  Because things are built
from source, dependency hell seems to be rare.  If you install via the
ports collection, applications are (in theory) guaranteed to get installed
in the right location.

FreeBSD has a Linux 'emulation' mode, and binaries that run under Linux
often run under FreeBSD.  No guarantees there, though.

Hardware support seems OK, though I'm not a very cutting-edge hardware
person.  SMP is supported.

In general, the impression that I've gotten is that FreeBSD is pretty
tightly controlled, and things seem to work together well.  I've upgraded
things much more frequently since I've been running FreeBSD, because the
process is so simple and because it rarely causes problems.  One thing
that did cause me problems was moving to XFree86 4.3 from 4.2 - X simply
wouldn't run after that, and I had to go back to 4.2, which I reinstalled
off my install CDROM - haven't spent the time to investigate that yet.

Documentation is adequate.  The man pages are good, but it's often not
easy to know where to look in the man pages.  There aren't any documents
filling the 'HOWTO' niche (or if there are, I haven't found them yet).
The handbook
(http://www.freebsd.org/doc/en_US.ISO8859-1/books/handbook/index.html) is
good for an introduction to the system.


I've been satisfied with FreeBSD so far, and will stick with it for a
while.

--
David Fleck
dcf at aracnet.com

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Tue Apr 22 22:16:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304220224190.19654-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304220224190.19654-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I have to wonder about the bill in its current form. When it was first talked
about, the proposal seemed right on the money in that any non-free software
purchase required justification. It seems everywhere I've worked, I've had to
justify all purchases and have had to have an approved budget to charge against
meaning at least to levels of justification and buy off. I've never however had
to justify a free solution to purchasing as it was never purchased. I've had to
justify a free solution to a technical review, and a business practices review
( ROI ), the same as any non-free solution. But no purchasing checks and
balances where involved.

As free alternatives are available and widely know about in company management
levels today, it seems that a company that does spend money on software, would
want to verify why, in a business sense. It seems like it would be prudent and
necessary to make sure the companies interests are being served by making sure
a check is installed to make sure all avenues are examined before money is
spent and there is someone accountable for saying so.  Why should the
government be any different? 

Isn't the bill this simple: We need a purchasing check in the State government,
so the purchase requester has to go on record as saying that this is the best
investment at this time and that all know avenues have been explored? 

Thank you
Russell

Subject: [PLUG] iptables curiosity with user defined chains.
Message-ID: <20030423060517.3135.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

I got a nifty idea to create two user defined chains, one for input rules and 
another for output rules, needed for a web server.  So I flush these chains
first in the init script that starts apache and proceed to propragate the 
server rules into them flushing them again when I stop the server.  I
also put lines in to cause my INPUT and OUTPUT chains in my firewall
to add these chains to their rulesets.  The only problem I've noticed 
is that the way In have it set up stopping the firewall and trying to
restart the web server first will cause it to try to flush a nonexistent
chain and then add rules to it.  If I create the user defined chains
in my apache script can I have a jump statement to an undefined chain
or should I not delete user defined chains in the master firewall script?!?
Maybe firewall stop should be a deletion of all chains followed by a flushing 
and recreation of the ones that are supposed to exist for my other scripts.
With opening the ports when I start apache I'm a little tighter 
than if I set these ports to be open all the time in my master iptables
firewall.  Now if only I could figure out how to put prerouting and forwarding
rules into user defined chains.  One of the nice things about using custom
chains is that it makes it easy to pull transient rules out of your main
firewall.

--prefix=/home/httpd \
--bindir=/usr/bin \
--sbindir=/usr/sbin \
--libexecdir=/usr/lib/apache \
--includedir=/usr/include/apache \
--sysconfdir=/etc/httpd/conf \
--localstatedir=/var \
--runtimedir=/var/run \
--logfiledir=/var/log/httpd \
--datadir=/home/httpd \
--proxycachedir=/var/cache/httpd \
--mandir=/usr/share/man \
--enable-module=ssl \
--activate-module=src/modules/perl/libperl.a \
--enable-module=perl \
--disable-module=userdir \
--disable-module=negotiation \
--disable-module=autoindex \
--disable-module=imap \
--add-module=src/modules/standard/mod_auth_db.c \
--server-uid=www \
--server-gid=www

     --disable-rule=SSL_COMPAT                        I think this is enabled.

All of the directory paths that you mention here can be put into
Apache's config-layout file at the root of the source tree. I find that
adding these here and using --with-layout instead a much easier way to
remember settings and it's nice to minimize the chance for fat-fingering
the configure script.

It's been a long time since I did a mod_perl in DSO, I build it in
statically when I use it, is there a need to do an --add-module option
for libperl.a still or did that go away?

The --server-uid, gid and max can all be set/reset in httpd.conf if you
don't care to add it to the configuration at compile time.

Give Konstruct a try:
http://konsole.kde.org/konstruct/

I'm using it right now and installed it to try out the new KDE 3.1.

It's a tool that fetches and builds (compiles) all the KDE packages and
their dependencies (not all of them, though).  It installs into:
~/kde3.1.1 by default, so uninstalling is just a matter of removing that
directory.

The veterinary management program I use is Avimark; Avimark is used in over
6000 animal hospitals world-wide. It works with M$Word, and they have
recently enabled integration with Ooo. Full details of the merge_words are
in the manual at www.avimark.net/manual/win22.pdf

Essentially, I set up a document for client education. A simple example:
---->

<date>

Owner: <first-name> <last-name>
<address>; <city>, <st>  <zip>

Instructions for <animal> <last-name>
<animal> has just had surgery. When you get <him> home, don't feed <him>
anything for the next 4 hours. Call us if you have questions.

<service-doctor>

<----

live with a 3 connection limit, you don't pay the money.

On Tue, 2003-04-22 at 15:44, Josh Orchard wrote:
> This article was interesting as well...
> 
> http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,1033071,00.asp

Yes, but he says that you're breaking the law if you use a
firewall. Even with Oregon's DMCA law, that's not the case
because the law states:

"...for the purpose of facilitating in any manner the theft or
disruption of communication services,"

Clearly, a firewall does not involve theft of data and
it does not disrupt communications between consenting
parties to the communication.

I'm not saying that Oregon lawmakers are not idiots for
passing the law, however. The author of this article may
be one.

"Yes" with some caveats for suitability and such.  This is actually
where the problem is given that most OSS doesn't have a vendor behind it
to respond to RFPs or "put in the lowest bid."
HR 2892 essentially tries to recognize that fact and include the
"vendorless" OSS in the purchasing process so that it can be evaluated
on a "value for money" basis, rather than not at all as is frequently
the case at present.

From kaile at centerspan.com  Wed Apr 23 14:48:02 2003
From: kaile at centerspan.com (Kaile Riser)
Date: Wed Apr 23 14:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
Message-ID: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC4855DDF@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com>

Hello Stephen,

I personally run a pretty fair number of different Operating Systems,
hardware, etc... Everything from MacOSX on a dual G4, Irix 6.5 on an
Indigo2, Solaris 9 on an UltraSparc, RedHat linux on x86, FreeBSD on
x86, and Windows where it is required for some random task. With all
these choices, I use FreeBSD for my router / gateway / firewall system.

I think a fair assessment is as follows:

FreeBSD is in my experience much more stable and faster than most linux
distros. Installing and upgrading software is extremely easy with the
ports system, though sometimes it takes a while for the latest version
to be added. Upgrading your entire system is fairly simple, and
compiling your own custom kernel is a lot easier than, say, RedHat is
(IMO). Pretty much anything to do with networking seems to be a great
deal faster and infinitely more stable on FreeBSD than Linux. I also
feel that the firewall rules are much easier to understand / implement.
Most linux apps will run on FreeBSD and work just fine under the linux
emulation layer, but if you have a need for a commercial application to
be actually SUPPORTED, then you really need to stick with Linux, most
likely RedHat. One large drawback from my perspective is that the Sun
J2SDKs are not native to FreeBSD. In order to run these, you have to run
them under Linux emulation... Which can be a huge pain in the butt.

I think FreeBSD is a much better way to go in general whether it be for
a workstation or a general server. It is a very robust and stable
system. However, if you have need for either the latest in Java
compatibility or commercial application support, you will want to stick
with something else (Sun or RedHat generally).


Kaile

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Apr 23 15:48:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Apr 23 15:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <Law15-F55IPnt7YzrAx0001471d@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304231543560.1585-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, Stephen Young wrote:

> Thank you all for your replies.  I am reading the handbook atm on 
> freebsd.org.  I plan on setting up a small router (firewall) / web / samba 
> server on my home lan.

  A couple of thoughts for your consideration. First, for your firewall
consider OpenBSD. From everything I've read -- including Mick Bauer's new
book, "Building Secure Servers with Linux" -- that's the most secure *BSD
out.

  Second, read the above book before putting your servers on the firewall
box. Instead, make your firewall box triple-headed (i.e., three NICs) and
put your public servers on a separate box, on its own NIC, and separated
that way from the rest of your lan.

Rich

> is open bsd compared to freebsd ?  Are they like slackware compared to
> redhat, or are the kernels developed by separate groups unlike the linux
> kernel ?
>
> Thanks agian for the help Rich
>
> Stephen Young
>
>
>

I'm not a big fan of going to BSD myself.  I think in part that there's a 
notion that BSD is a full source tree for all your utilities, OS, etc. and 
that this is therefore better.  I think it very likely that much of the 
software will be the same and I wonder what the factions are going to
be like.  Also, what licenses does one get into with BSD?  I'd rather
have a finished widely accepted standard for what a Linux system has,
vendor neutral, to study from and another set of documents on where 
Redhat strays as well as good Redhat alternatives for say graphical
programming under X.  Gentoo seems worth looking into.  Forcing 
compiles from source solves a lot of problems installing programs, 
however, how many problems are caused by optimizations that turn 
out to be more trouble than they are worth or hardware designs that 
are proven foolish.  Compilation is an interesting tool and using program 
design to implement optimizations in a more portable manner is a 
good tools also.  It takes time to compile a whole entire system where 
just because you can compile it doesn't mean your pre compilation 
decisions are going to be wise for your needs or easy to make.
GNU is building a standard environment for what a person should see
in a source package, how about BSD?  Linux is Posix compliant,
is BSD?  Linux is also clustering ready, I don't know about BSD.
The other thing with BSD is that developement could be stymied 
compared to Linux.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From sandy at herring.org  Wed Apr 23 18:08:02 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed Apr 23 18:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL
In-Reply-To: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A038C0E40@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>
References: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A038C0E40@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>
Message-ID: <20030424010751.GA31719@kippered.herring.org>

I have plenty of friends who use and are happy with Easystreet. However, if
you want to NAT multiple boxen and/or run a non-commercial server on your
DSL line, you'll need Easystreet's Enthusiast account. For 1.5M/128k you'll
pay them $39.95/mo (does not include Verizon/Qwest charges). That's why I've
got an Aracnet (aka SpiritOne) account. They don't require a different class
of account in order for me to NAT my 4 boxen (including my web server). I
pay $23.45/mo (actually, $117 for 6 mos. at a whack) for 1.5M/128k (Enhanced
Bronze plus)...

    http://www.spiritone.com/services_dsl_verizonpricing.htm

I've had very few problems during the ~3 years I've had DSL w/Aracnet.

If you're in Qwest territory, you're going to pay through the nose at either
ISP :-\

    http://www.easystreet.com/services/easydsl/enthusiast.html
    http://www.spiritone.com/services_dsl_qwestpricing.htm

Sandy

I'll add I have a New Edge Networks DSL plus we resell(?) the product and
I've yet to hear a complaint about the quality.  Sometimes getting an
install can be a lengthy process but it's to be expected for non
shared-line SDSL (business grade).  The shared-line ADSL sold to the
masses (consumers) usually has no CIR or QOS guarantee.
   We have more problems with the wire owners and the upstream bandwidth 
providers than with New Edge.

I'm an Easystreet customer and I have to say that the service is great.
When there is a problem, and Easystreet problems are very rare, they
take ownership, jump on the issue and stays on it until it is corrected.

For the most part, the service at Verizon (the DSL wire provider) is ok
but getting them to own issues is a little more tricky.

at $10/mo., they will discount your cable internet by $10,
so essentially the internet is the same price, or the cable
TV is free....  depending how you look at it.

But, I have satellite TV, and don't need, don't want Comcast
Cable TV, and am furious that they show up on the scene after
the ATTBI buyout and say "Welcome to Comcast.  Please fork
over $10 more to pay for painting over the ATT logos on our
trucks and repainting the Comcast logo."  So far, that's the
only difference I've seen.

I like the internet service--it's fast and reliable, but I
am ticked at the price hike. If it had been $2 or $3, I
probably would have ignored it (ATTBI just raised it $2-3 6
months ago), but ~25% price increase is bogus.

Worst part is I'm in an area of Salem that still does not have
DSL service, not from QWest anyway.  I know of no other 
telcos who would provide the basic wiring/switching, so I'm
faced with paying up to Comcast or going back to 56k--YUCK!!

Any other anti-Comcast sentiment I can ride?

Brendan

>>>>> "Michael" == Michael Robinson <michael at robinson-west.com> writes:

Michael> I'm not a big fan of going to BSD myself. [...]  GNU is
Michael> building a standard environment for what a person should see
Michael> in a source package, how about BSD?  Linux is Posix
Michael> compliant, is BSD?  Linux is also clustering ready, I don't
Michael> know about BSD.  The other thing with BSD is that
Michael> developement could be stymied compared to Linux.

This is all FUD.  You know not of what you speak.

It's like me saying

        I'm pretty sure OpenBSD won't give you cancer.
        What about Linux?  Huh?  Where is the *hard evidence*?

Please to not be spouting such nonsense.

I make no false claims about OpenBSD, nor derisions about Linux.

I do claim that OpenBSD is more secure than Linux, as borne out by
openly available data.  Yes, part of the reason is that Linux has a
large market share, and hence a better target for the script kiddies.
But part of it is also just a fundamental difference in development
philosophy.  And since I want to be able to sleep at night, I
appreciate both of those contributing factors.

Is it a big deal that I can't get the latest gadget for OpenBSD as a
simple source or binary RPM?  No.

Do I care that I don't run Linux binaries out of the box?  No.  But
I've read manpages that say that with a bit of work, I could run a
Linux binary if I chose.

And maybe that lets me optimize for security, and not gadgetry.  It
all depends on what you're optimizing for.  Others may chose gadgetry
or compatibility over security, or be willing to keep their system
behind a separate firewall (running OpenBSD :).  Not me.

On Wed, 2003-04-23 at 17:28, Daniel B. Herrington wrote:

The best thing I've seen so far are the prism 2.5 chipset cards (Netgear
seems to be sticking with that chipset, so far) and the hostap drivers.

I can't tell you about a RedHat setup, but it acts just like a network
card with an extra layer of control.  I had to download the hostap
drivers, compile them against my kernel headers, install them, and
configure the modules for loading on boot.  The rest of the
configuration is done just like a network card, with wireless_ extras.

I rarely recommend purchasing from Fry's, but in this case, their return
policy makes it worth while.  The card makers have changed chipsets on
their cards, but didn't change the model number.  I bought two cards
(identical model numbers) that where supposed to have the prism chipset,
but only one of them worked with linux.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Apr 23 21:06:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Apr 23 21:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <Law15-F69wNdZynfLz800014c76@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304232057230.2186-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 23 Apr 2003, Stephen Young wrote:

> Is the idea to have the public servers on their own boxes plugged into the
> firewall directly, and have the other nic plugged into a switch for the
> lan, and have teh third plugged into my cable ?

  Yes. The ideal solution, according to Mick, is to have two firewalls with
a switch (or hub) in between. The public servers (http, ftp, smtp) are then
between the two firewalls and isolated from both the internal network and
the nasty world of the 'Net. Of course, for those of us with SOHO or home
networks that's overkill.

  So, putting the cable modem into one firewall NIC (eth0), the public
server on the second (eth1) with its own subnet, and the rest of your lan on
eth2, with a different subnet, you gain a measure of increased security
compared with the servers on the firewall.

> Sounds very logical, never really thought about that before.  How similar is 
> open bsd compared to freebsd ?  Are they like slackware compared to redhat, 
> or are the kernels developed by separate groups unlike the linux kernel ?

  I'm definitely the least knowledgeable person to ask. I've not used any of
them. What I do know of openBSD is that each binary is given a security
audit before inclusion and the whole distribution is oriented toward maximum
security. I'm starting to learn the differences between Slackware and Red
Hat, but I haven't dug deeply yet to really know all the ways they differ.
Give me a couple of months and I'll make sufficient mistakes to learn all
about Slack.

  When I get the new server/workstation built it will replace my current
one. I'll put the guts of the current one in a smaller box and make that the
public server. I'll take the other hard drive from it and put that in my
floppyfw box and install openBSD on it as the firewall. With three NICS. If
it's good enough to recommend, it's good enough for me to use here. :-)

Rich
