From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Wed Apr 23 21:20:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Apr 23 21:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <20030423235313.2618.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <Law15-F69wNdZynfLz800014c76@hotmail.com>
	 <20030423235313.2618.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1051157952.15055.30.camel@zadie>

> be like.  Also, what licenses does one get into with BSD?  I'd rather

Generally the same licenses you get into with Linux, as there's very
little in the way of medium or large projects that compile on only one.
The BSD License is just as major a license as the GPL, and many projects
that are commonly used under Linux are licensed with the BSD license.
Linux's TCP stack is based on BSD's (as is most of the world).

references: BSD License:
http://www.opensource.org/licenses/bsd-license.php

A few projects you might have heard of licensed under the BSD license:
TCL (scripting language that spawned/is related to TK, a widget toolkit)
Webmin (a web interface I use to admin my Linux boxen)
Enlightenment (a window manager, rather well known)
Blackbox (another window manager, also rather well known)
Freetype (truetype font replacement, used by most Linux dists)
SWIG (used by Perl, Python, Ruby, etc to provide access to modules
written in C/C++. If you use any scripting language, you probably use
SWIG)

That's just a brief list culled from the first five pages of
www.sourceforge.net 's list of BSD-licensed projects.

Note: BSD is an OSI-supported license, in other words, it is indeed Open
Source.

> GNU is building a standard environment for what a person should see
> in a source package, how about BSD?  Linux is Posix compliant,
> is BSD?  Linux is also clustering ready, I don't know about BSD.
> The other thing with BSD is that developement could be stymied 
> compared to Linux.

Yes, and the GNU tools are mostly platform agnostic*: that's why you
have to write Debian GNU/Linux, because GNU is NOT the same thing as
Linux. GNU tools compile on Linux, as they compile on BSD, and others.
BSD is Posix compliant, clustering ready (has native cluster solutions).
And I'm not sure what "that development could be stymied compared to
Linux."

reference: Here's FreeBSD's cluster mailing list:
 http://lists.freebsd.org/mailman/listinfo/freebsd-cluster 

FreeBSD has a 4 stable version and a 5 stable-experimental version,
which is the coming version but has only been out a year or so and is
therefore still in more active development. In fact, FreeBSD is far more
conservative than Linux in releases--stable to FreeBSD means proven
stable in production environment, unlike Linux where 2.4.0 is "stable"
(ever run it?) FreeBSD has run many gigantic sites: Hotmail was Apache
on FreeBSD before Microsoft converted it to Win2k. In fact, the
benchmarks generally show FreeBSD with Apache to be faster and more
stable than Linux with Apache.

While on the topic of *BSD, you should check out OpenBSD, the most
secure operating system in the world (1 remote root exploit in 7 years,
compared with Linux: many). NetBSD, the most portable operating system
in the world: they say if NetBSD doesn't run on it, and it's capable of
computation, it will soon. In fact, the motto of NetBSD is "Of course it
runs on NetBSD"

They're separate kernels and development spheres, though generally very
similar, so they shouldn't really be lumped together quite as much as
they are, and they certainly shouldn't be dismissed quite as easily as
they are. FreeBSD is a good replacement for Linux for the hardcore.
OpenBSD makes the most fabulous firewalls, as security really isn't a
concern, and if you happen to have an interesting system lying around
that you can't get anything else to run on it, NetBSD will probably run
on it.

While we're on the subject of "Is *BSD good enough to be taken
seriously," one major company has clearly shown that the answer is yes:
Apple. MacOSX is largely based on the *BSDs, especially FreeBSD, and
Apple is now the largest Unix software company in the world. MacOSX is
fabulous, for those who haven't tried it, though it takes some getting
used to if you're coming from Linux.

Oh, and since you mentioned Gentoo: Gentoo brags about emerge: it's what
makes them special in the Linux world. But emerge is just a port of the
portage system of FreeBSD to Linux. Gentoo on Linux is pretty much
FreeBSD a few years behind.

Jeff

* in fact, Debian too is somewhat platform agnostic. Debian is the only
distribution that will actually run the HURD, which is GNU's kernel,
still in experimental stage. Actually, the HURD has been in experimental
stage since before there was a Linux. Linus's announcement of Linux
mentioned that it wouldn't probably be useful for anything because the
HURD would be out "any day now."

http://groups.google.com/groups?q=linus+torvalds+linux+hurd&start=450&hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&scoring=d&selm=1991Oct5.071651.9658%40agate.berkeley.edu&rnum=455

There's no reason why Debian couldn't build a Debian GNU/FreeBSD system,
though they haven't yet. 

References:

http://www.freebsd.org
http://www.netbsd.org
http://www.openbsd.org
http://www.netcraft.com
http://www.debian.org
http://www.gnu.org

been around a long time but Linux still took popularity that it never
seemed to grab.  Linux must have some things BSD doesn't.

to appreciate it more.  I would like to see the methods of adding drivers

kernel.  I've outlived criticism of gcc's inline assembly where I am

uncomfortable with it or simply don't know enough about it.  I imagine
every system has it's problems where security auditing is something
that can be done to any open source system easily.  Linux uses gnu
tools and perhaps other stuff from BSD land so perhaps these 
systems can be alike where they really ought to be.  Myself I am
not exciting about the thought of yet another operating system,
yuckk.  And about MacOSX, it isn't any smarter about failing to read
a disk than Windows 98 is.  I think Linux is the only system that is
capable of not crashing in that case compared against these
other two.  I suffered from severe pull down fatigue in MacOSX
and I couldn't find stuff.  Applixware was no wordperfect where
ultimately printing proved impossible because instead of an HP
6MP I only have the HP 6P on a Jetdirect 170X box.  No I don't
have Mac drivers for the network box that work on the Mac, a G4
system.

What I'm more curious about is can openbsd and Linux integrate well
and is openbsd perhaps a good system for building small network

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Thu Apr 24 01:17:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu Apr 24 01:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <20030424073037.3862.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <Law15-F13miZuBhvuc80001573a@hotmail.com>
	 <20030423212750.S320@grond.sourballs.org>
	 <20030424073037.3862.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1051172161.15488.22.camel@zadie>

> What has made openbsd more successfull than Linux security wise?

Every line of OpenBSD code, and I mean the kernel and all the stuff they
certify, is security audited by folks who know what they're doing. Many
eyes may be okay in practice, but a few good eyes has proven to be even
better. OpenBSD has only had one remote root exploit since its
inception.

It's true that once you start installing random stuff on it, you can
make it insecure, but that's true of anything. Linux dists frequently
come out of the box with security configuration issues (like RedHat's
many default passwords) or actual holes (like the various kernel, tcp
stack, and daemon buffer overflow mis-codes) that aren't easy to fix.
OpenBSD comes with none of these.

That said, I don't know anyone who uses OpenBSD as a workstation, or
even as a server for many services. Most people I know use it as a
firewall or a server for a few important services.

> been around a long time but Linux still took popularity that it never
> seemed to grab. 

I don't think popularity is really a good way to judge worth. If it
were, we'd all be drooling over Longhorn.


>  Linux must have some things BSD doesn't.

At the moment, mindshare. Other than that, I'm not sure you can really
argue that the Linux kernel is fundamentally a whole lot better than any
of the BSD kernels. AFAIK the NUMA patches haven't made it to the BSDs
yet, but they will, and the same may be true of the 2.5 stuff
(preemptible kernel, low latency, etc).

> I thought 2.4 was bust at first but I'm now at the 2.4.20 level starting
> to appreciate it more.  I would like to see the methods of adding drivers

Linux kernels don't tend to be very stable at 0-4pl. Admittedly, I've
only used the 2 series, but ... *shrug*. Makes RedHat's .0 instability
less unforgiveable.

> yuckk.  And about MacOSX, it isn't any smarter about failing to read
> a disk than Windows 98 is.  I think Linux is the only system that is
> capable of not crashing in that case compared against these

Amusing story: a bad disk showed up the other day with important
documents on it. Linux refused to read it, MacOSX refused to read it,
WinXP and 2k both refused to read it, and then all of a sudden Win98
read it like a charm, saved the files off of it, and then went about its
business.


> What I'm more curious about is can openbsd and Linux integrate well
> and is openbsd perhaps a good system for building small network 
> bootable utility images over trying to come up with a Linux initrd
> system?

I like Knoppix for this. =)

I doubt I'd use OpenBSD for that. It seems like the wrong type of nail
for that hammer. But FreeBSD, or doing Linux without initrd should both
be usable. You can read ext2 with just about anything non-Windows, but
if you're using odd filesystems I'd check first. I'm only just gearing
up to move to XFS on Linux from EXT3, and I haven't checked out what
filesystems the BSDs support.

Jeff





From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu Apr 24 01:17:20 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)

Subject: [PLUG] samba and profiles...

Does anyone know with samba 2.2.0 on up how to get profiles to go in a 
subdirectory as opposed to the root of a user's home directory?

What is the purpose of the latter profiles?  Can they be restricted from 
creating a bunch of links to programs that don't exist if you log in on
different Windows boxes as the same user via samba?

One of my idea has been to network boot dos and via msclient or lanman
for installation of dos/Windows systems as well as backup.  Seems a
lot of cards aren't supported though.  There's the netware option, perhaps
one of the few options that will let me do what I want.  Ultimately though, 
a network bootable Linux system that gets a machine on the network 
with the ability to mount the local drives and dump them to a network 
tape server is the answer.  The latter will especially work well if this 
network booted system is password protected where these passwords
are synchronized with clients' Linux account passwords on the server.

One gotcha I'm running up against is getting an de220pt on an io address
of 0x2A0 to detect by etherboot.  The latter only detects cards on io 0x300.
There is a kernel option parameter via dhcp but the etherboot program 
itself needs to know that the card is elsewhere.

consoles.  The ttyS0 could be ttyS1 is using com2.

boot messages?

Environment), if it has such, or netboot see the HOWTO at

http://cui.unige.ch/info/pc/remote-boot/howto.html

I know the title says it's for Linux remote booting, but there's info on
dos/windows booting and backup options there, too.

-djp 
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From kaile at centerspan.com  Thu Apr 24 11:00:02 2003
From: kaile at centerspan.com (Kaile Riser)
Date: Thu Apr 24 11:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] samba and profiles...
Message-ID: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC4855DE3@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com>

As far as the first question goes, this is how I do it on my system
(just conf excerpts):

[global]
logon path = \\ROUTER\profile\%U
profile acls = Yes
        
[profile]
path = /usr/local/samba/profile
browseable = No
read only = No
profile acls = yes

I am using 2.2.8a however, and I don't know if the "profile acls"
keyword works in 2.2.0. I think it does, but I'm not sure. Either way,
the login path and the profile share are really what you need. I think
the profile dir under the homedir is mostly for windows9x clients... I
believe that's what they use by default. I don't know of any other
reason for it.


Kaile

  I've been a very satisfied customer of Air Touch, now Verizon, since 1996.
Their service has been outstanding and I have no desire to change. Currently
my plan gives me 300 (or 350) minutes per month, no roaming charges anywhere
in the 12 Western states and toll-free long distance anywhere in the US from
anywhere in my "home" area (the 12 Western states). For this I pay $35/month
(plus taxes). My fiancee's plan ($20/month) gives her 75 minutes of local
calling in the non-expanded home area and no long distance.

  My latest phone with them (I think it's the third one I've had) is a
Kyocera QCP-6035. This is a tri-mode phone with a built-in Palm Pilot PDA.
Or, it's a Palm Pilot PDA with a built-in cellular phone. You may be able to
get one for a very good price as the replacement model will be out next
week. It has color (whoopie-doo!) and cosmetic changes.

  What made the expense ($350 net for me about 16 months ago) worth while is
convenience. I carry only one belt decoration rather than two separate ones
and I have all 900+ phone numbers (that's 900 addresses with multiple phone
numbers for each one) and several years' appointments, etc. with me.
Exceptionally handy for the self-employed.

  Verizon Wireless has been very good for me. I call them periodically and
if they have an upgrade in service for the same price they'll move me to
that new plan. I've never had a problem with them or their coverage. There
are spots around Vale and in the Cascades (as well as more remote areas)
where there's no cellular coverage. Period. By anyone. That's where I use
the satellite phone.

From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu Apr 24 20:15:03 2003

Subject: [PLUG] samba and profiles...

On Thursday 24 April 2003 09:01 am, you wrote:
> Another approach would be to use your NIC's PXE (Preboot eXecution
> Environment), if it has such, or netboot see the HOWTO at
>
> http://cui.unige.ch/info/pc/remote-boot/howto.html
>
> I know the title says it's for Linux remote booting, but there's info on
> dos/windows booting and backup options there, too.
>
> -djp
> http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!
>
Interesting information though it looks more complicated than I want
to deal with if I try and set remote boot Windows up for Windows users
to be able to backup their own systems.  I don't want to dabble in the
Windows registry without professional training and the less software
I have to pick up from some obscure site the better off I am.  I have
etherboot working and I have made Tom's root boot netbootable
using etherboot.  Same is true for a dos and 98 boot disk where I
have added a few tools I'd put on a bootdisk intended for creating
partitions to install these operating systems to.
  
What I want to know is how to take a no package group selected custom
install of Redhat 7.2 and fix it for network boot.  This means that things 
like hard drive testing and temp directories created during bootup as well
as the kernel need to be looked at.  The home directory should be an area
on a backup dump disk on the server whereas the temp directories should
either be ram disks on the client machine or a file on the server side.  This
system should have no mail anything, has anyone ever taken the mail
facilities out of Linux entirely?  Linux runs most everything hardware wise
where the time I could spend on PXE would be far better spent learning
about Linux.  I have a partition on my workstation to develop this custom
system on.  The only reason for 7.2 is that it has the 2.4 series kernel
and recent hardware device support though any modern Linux distribution 
where programmability is the key could be chosen.  Redhat 6.2 could be
good enough, though 7.2 is easier to install with extras left out and is
newer.

I've lost interest in netbooting Windows and Dos.  PXE seems necessary
to be able to support the network cards out there, but looking at it it 
becomes obvious why Linux is so much better for networking applications as 
Linux is not designed with rigid assumptions about a local hard disk, etc.
and the kernel itself is largely used to get the various hardware devices
going  It looks a lot easier to prepare Linux for netbooting than Dos/Windows
where dos/windows don't look easy enough to be worthwhile and 
getting a usable Linux system available via netboot is more useful to 
me.

A netbooted Linux system with samba client support, tar, bzip2, 
dd, dump, restore, broad filesystem support, and md5 summing 
for example is a good start.  I can and have created netbootable 
images of 98 and dos for formatting and creating local partitions 
( though I need password protection through a third party program
perhaps run by autoexec.bat or a pre booted Linux system that
has to authenticate you to the server before allowing network boot
of 98 and Dos systems. )  If I could come up with a Linux system
that just has the ability to authenticate users to a server and trigger
a second network boot I would not worry about passwords after
that in dos, windows, or further Linux network booted systems.

If I can avoid getting away from etherboot that is preferred because
that makes the client side so easy.

   --  Michael C. Robinson

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
        boundary="__61D_4.F95.AD.FCF"

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

--__61D_4.F95.AD.FCF
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


I get the above all the time, the rest left off.  It looks like someone is 
trying to email to a non existent account on my domain and I'm receiving it
where it can't be bounced to the address they specify.  I'd like to not 
receive it in the first place though I imagine the sender can send it from 
many different hosts which I may not want to block, especially
since the source can be forged or it could be valid for other senders.  I use 
qmail server.  There has to be some way to block emailing to accounts that 
I don't host or at least a way to have messages to non existent accounts 
turned around and sent back to the sender or destroyed.  I don't want to 
get messages like the above in my admin account anymore if I know the 
message is junk.  I haven't removed any valid accounts let alone one 
named sonya.h and noone who has a right to receive messages on my 
site has ever given out sonya.h at robinson-west.com as a valid email 
address.  My domain name is registered though I suppose it is possible 
that someone else is trying to use it without having registered it.

  --  Michael C. Robinson

here is how you contact your representative. Please take a moment --right now-- 
and show your support for HB 2982. Every contact matters as we continue to move

On Thu, 24 Apr 2003, Michael Robinson wrote:

> <eyz8j5pr at yahoo.com>:

  Spammers use yahoo, hotmail, msn and all the other "free" mail domains as
the return address. That's _never_ where the mail originates.

  'whois' is your friend. As in ...

> Received: from adsl-68-74-144-107.dsl.emhril.ameritech.net (68.74.144.107)

  whois 68.74.144.107 at whois.arin.net

confirms that IP address belongs to Ameritech. Send a copy of the full
message, with headers to 'abuse at ameritech.net'.

  Next, ...

> Received: from jp.cqohg.com ([214.173.254.222]) by 

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ whois 214.173.254.222 at whois.arin.net 
[whois.arin.net]

OrgName:    DoD Network Information Center 
OrgID:      DNIC
Address:    7990 Science Applications Ct
Address:    M/S CV 50
City:       Vienna
StateProv:  VA
PostalCode: 22183-7000
Country:    US

  So, the spammer spoofed the originating IP address, too. Send the original
message, with full headers, to the AmeriTech abuse address.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 25 07:09:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 25 07:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Minimal firewall hardware
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304250647030.7918-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304250701390.22075-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 25 Apr 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> What would be a reasonable minimum hardware setup (specifically,
> what size hard drive) for a firewall box running OpenBSD for a SOHO
> network?

Rich,

I'm running OpenBSD 3.3 (beta) on a SPARC, so the overall distribution
size might be mildly different from what it'd be on an x86 box. My
installation is pretty bare; it occupies just under 500M:

  /      27M
  /tmp    2K
  /usr  460M
  /var   12M

I have /home mounted via NFS (yeah, yeah, I know...), but I don't do 
that much stuff on the BSD box that would require a lot of home 
directory space.

Unless you're planning on doing a lot of work on the firewall box 
itself, any hard drive bigger than 1G will probably do you just fine.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

the packet-filtering stuff has undergone some fairly significant 
changes of late. If the book doesn't specifically deal with the 
version of OpenBSD you install, you'll definitely want to double check 
the pf.conf(5) man page before implementing any ruleset suggested in 
the book.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 25 10:38:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 25 10:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Morning MS Humor
In-Reply-To: <3EA96BA6.9050908@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304251020210.22075-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Interesting: the "front door" for IIS 6.0 is a kernel driver:

  The new kernel mode driver, HTTP.SYS, is a single point of contact 
  for all incoming (server-side) HTTP requests. This provides high 
  performance connectivity for HTTP server applications. The driver 
  sits atop TCP/IP and receives all connection requests from the
  IP/port combinations it is configured to listen on. HTTP.SYS is also
  responsible for overall connection management, bandwidth throttling,
  and Web server logging.

I can see where there could be some big performance benefits, ala the
Linux khttpd, but I'm just not the sort of admin that likes to think
that crashing the web server can mean bringing down the kernel.

I don't know enough about the Windows kernel's privilege levels to 
know if that's really dangerous, but it certainly sounds scary to me.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Thinkpad batteries are Li-ion and have a micro built-in that does the
chargeing, they do not overcharge (unless you have a buggy bios).  They
do like all battries have a limited number of charge-discharge cycles. 
It is my understanding that it is best to let them stay topped off.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Apr 25 12:24:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 25 12:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AOL email policies
In-Reply-To: <1051297747.3ea987d34e60a@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304251218150.22075-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 25 Apr 2003, Daniel B. Herrington wrote:

> Do you know if there is anyway to remove yourself from getting
> blocked?

You'll probably need to define what in sendmail-ese is called a 'smart 
host,' which would typically be your ISP's mail server. All your 
Internet-bound mail gets relayed though the smart host.

It's a pain, because you're at your ISP's mercy when it comes to speed 
of delivery, but at least the spam-fearin' folks at AOL won't balk at 
your mail. Oh, it's also a pain if you're on a laptop and connected to 
a remote network, because your normal smart host won't relay mail for 
you.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From paul at lankow.net  Fri Apr 25 12:49:01 2003
From: paul at lankow.net (Paul)
Date: Fri Apr 25 12:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] AOL email policies
In-Reply-To: <1051297747.3ea987d34e60a@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <Law15-F102CpOpmSNTU0001d7ad@hotmail.com>
	<1051297747.3ea987d34e60a@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <20030425124654.51636181.paul@lankow.net>

I'm a Sendmail user. I created /etc/mail/mailertable with these contents:

aol.com         smtp:smtp.comcast.net
cs.com          smtp:smtp.comcast.net

Of course, if you're not a Comcast customer, you'll want to change the smtp server. Don't forget to restart Sendmail for the change to take affect.

Have a nice weekend,
Paul

Paul Heinlein wrote:
> Interesting: the "front door" for IIS 6.0 is a kernel driver:
> 
>   The new kernel mode driver, HTTP.SYS, is a single point of contact 
>   for all incoming (server-side) HTTP requests. This provides high 
>   performance connectivity for HTTP server applications. The driver 
>   sits atop TCP/IP and receives all connection requests from the
>   IP/port combinations it is configured to listen on. HTTP.SYS is also
>   responsible for overall connection management, bandwidth throttling,
>   and Web server logging.
>

allows a patched kernel, to run user space programs in kernel space.  He 
doesn't say what you can't do, but says he's benchmarked Apache.

Sounds safer, almost to good to be true.

From raanders at acm.org  Fri Apr 25 15:34:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Fri Apr 25 15:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DSL
In-Reply-To: <20030424074013.3876.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0304251524420.32616-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 24 Apr 2003, Michael Robinson wrote:

> What does no CIR or QOS gurantee on standard DSL mean?  
> I would think since DSL is always on that there has to be some
> thouroughput guarantee, especially since it is compared to cable 
> as the option where you get the quoted speed and not  
> shared bandwidth with an unknown number of other people.

I have 'seen' a few DSL contracts before I started to work here and of 
those one guaranteed 10 CPS the others hand none.  Always on and sharing 
it with backbone connection with 2000 others will tend to cut your 
bandwidth right down.  Qwest tends to over sell their circuits (as an 
ISP).  When we resell Qwest DSL (we're the ISP) we don't guarantee the 
speed ... we can't!  Just today we bounced at least 10 Qwest DSL lines 
(take them out of the router and put them back in).

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Fri Apr 25 17:02:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Fri Apr 25 17:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Minimal firewall hardware
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304250915240.22075-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304250915240.22075-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <200304251844.13232.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

On Friday 25 April 2003 11:24, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> My understanding is that 3.3 is substantially different from 2.5,
> though other PLUG folks with better BSD chops might be able to provide
> a fuller discussion of the issue.

Theo de Raadt had a "falling out" with the author of IPFilter, which was 
completely independent of OpenBSD, regarding making modifications to the 
source code.  As I recall, the OpenBSD folks insisted on modifying the code 
in the course of their characteristic security audits and other development 
activities whereas the author of IPFilter wanted complete control over any 
modifications.  A flame war ensued, the end result of which was the removal 
of IPFilter from OpenBSD and the creation of a completely new firewalling 
package written for OpenBSD by the OpenBSD developers.  I believe that this 
occurred during the transition between 2.8 and 2.9 in the middle of 2001.  
So, you might expect substantial differences between the firewalling code in 
2.5 and 3.3, although I believe that the OpenBSD folks at least initially 
maintained compatibility with IPFilter to ease the transition for their 
users.

I built firewalls using OpenBSD 2.8 and 2.9 but haven't done so more recently.  
So I can't tell you how large the differences are without trolling through 
some documentation.

Food for enquiring minds. ;-)  Enjoy,

Mark

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Fri Apr 25 17:40:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Fri Apr 25 17:40:02 2003
Subject: Battery Memory Myth (was Re: [PLUG] Looking for a new-to-me
 laptop)
In-Reply-To: <86u1cmgtn0.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304251718110.9328-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On 25 Apr 2003, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

> >>>>> "Phil" == Phil Tomson <ptkwt at aracnet.com> writes:
>
> Phil> I don't think it's an issue of overcharging - the charging
> Phil> circuitry should prevent that anyway.  I believe that the issue
> Phil> Nickel metal hydride batteries is what's referred to as 'memory'
> Phil> which means that if you don't fully discharge them they begin to
> Phil> lose their ability to hold a charge.
>
> Ow!  Not the "memory myth" again. I wonder how long this bad meme
> will persist...
>
> <http://www.geocities.com/chitianzi/memoryeffect.txt>
>
> Repeat after me: "There is no such thing as NiCd battery memory fatigue."
> And also "even if there ever was, it was only about NiCds!"
>
> {sigh}
>

Actually this site: http://www.batteryuniversity.com/parttwo-33.htm
seems to indicate that there is something similar to the mythical 'memory'
problem with both NiCd and NiMH.

Here are some excerpts:

"The word 'memory' was originally derived from 'cyclic memory'; meaning
that a Nickel-cadmium battery could remember how much energy was drawn on
preceding discharges. On a longer than scheduled discharge, the voltage
would rapidly drop and the battery would lose power. Improvements in
battery technology have virtually eliminated this phenomenon.

The problem with Nickel-cadmium is not so much the cyclic memory but the
effects of crystalline formation. The active cadmium material is present
in finely divided crystals. In a good cell, these crystals remain small,
obtaining maximum surface area. With memory, the crystals grow and conceal
the active material from the electrolyte. In advanced stages, the sharp
edges of the crystals penetrate the separator, causing high self-discharge
or electrical short.

When introduced in the early 1990s, Nickel-metal-hydride was promoted as
being memory-free. Today, we know that this chemistry is also affected but
to a lesser degree than Nickel-cadmium. The nickel plate, a metal that is
shared by both chemistries, is partly to blame. While Nickel-metal-hydride
has only the nickel plate to worry about, Nickel-cadmium also includes the
memory-prone cadmium plate. This is a non-scientific explanation why
Nickel-cadmium is affected more than Nickel-metal-hydride.

...
Crystalline formation is most pronounced if a nickel-based battery is left
in the charger for days, or if repeatedly recharged without a periodic
full discharge. Since most applications do not use all energy before
recharge, a periodic discharge to 1 volt per cell (known as exercise) is
essential to prevent memory.

 ...

Simple Guidelines
* Do not leave a nickel-based battery in a charger for more than a few
days, even on trickle charge.
 * Exercise Nickel-cadmium every 1 to 2 months and Nickel-metal-hydride
every 3 months. Running the battery down in the equipment may do this
also.
 * Do not discharge the battery before each recharge. This puts undue
stress on the battery.
 * Avoid getting the battery too hot during charge. The temperature should
only rise for a short moment at full charge, then cool off. "


So the recommendation seems to be somewhat similar to the
old recommendations for avoiding the 'memory' problem with NiCd cells (but
apparently for different reasons than the old 'memory' theory.)

Phil

From michael at robinson-west.com  Sat Apr 26 13:07:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sat Apr 26 13:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting proftpd configured securely...
Message-ID: <20030426200231.10573.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

Accounts I set up for it.

proftpd:x:121:121::/chroot/ftp/:/bin/false
ftp:x:501:501::/home/ftp:/bin/bash

Config file I currently have.

# This is a basic ProFTPD configuration file (rename it to
# 'proftpd.conf' for actual use.  It establishes a single server
# and a single anonymous login.  It assumes that you have a user/group
# "nobody" and "ftp" for normal operation and anon.

ServerName                      "Robinson-west.com "
ServerType                      inetd
DefaultServer                   on
Bind                            192.168.1.12

# Port 21 is the standard FTP port.
Port                            21

# Umask 022 is a good standard umask to prevent new dirs and files
# from being group and world writable.
Umask                           022

# To prevent DoS attacks, set the maximum number of child processes
# to 30.  If you need to allow more than 30 concurrent connections
# at once, simply increase this value.  Note that this ONLY works
# in standalone mode, in inetd mode you should use an inetd server
# that allows you to limit maximum number of processes per service
# (such as xinetd).
MaxInstances                    30

# Set the user and group under which the server will run.
User                            proftpd
Group                           proftpd

# To cause every FTP user to be "jailed" (chrooted) into their home
# directory, uncomment this line.
#DefaultRoot ~

# A basic anonymous configuration, no upload directories.  If you do not
# want anonymous users, simply delete this entire <Anonymous> section.
<Anonymous /chroot/ftp/pub>
  User                          ftp
  Group                         ftp

  # We want clients to be able to login with "anonymous" as well as "ftp"
  UserAlias                     anonymous ftp

  # Limit the maximum number of anonymous logins
  MaxClients                    10

  # We want 'welcome.msg' displayed at login, and '.message' displayed
  # in each newly chdired directory.
  DisplayLogin                  welcome.msg
  DisplayFirstChdir             .message

  # Limit WRITE everywhere in the anonymous chroot
  <Limit WRITE>
    DenyAll
  </Limit>
</Anonymous>

Service file under /etc/xinetd.d

service ftp
{
        disable                 = no
        flags                   = REUSE
        socket_type             = stream
        wait                    = no
        user                    = root
        server                  = /usr/sbin/proftpd
        log_on_success          += DURATION USERID
        log_on_failure          += USERID
        nice                    = 10
        bind                    = 192.168.1.12
}

I want to make sure that this ftp server only supports downloads from an 
anonymous archive rooted at /chroot/ftp/pub.  There should be no writing
of any sort allowed and user logins should be denied.  I have found that user 
logins do work, ughh.  Do I need the proftpd accounts?  What do I need to
do to my firewall or ftp file under xinetd.d to make this service available 
on my outside interface?

This is a lot easier to set up than wu-ftpd, thanks guys :-)

From ed at alcpress.com  Sat Apr 26 15:03:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sat Apr 26 15:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Morning MS Humor
In-Reply-To: <20030426080713.A9835@patch.com>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304251020210.22075-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
	 <3EA99FAA.6030404@pacifier.com> <1051322939.23101.399.camel@red>
	 <20030426080713.A9835@patch.com>
Message-ID: <1051394508.22995.425.camel@red>

On Sat, 2003-04-26 at 08:07, mikeraz at patch.com wrote:
> On Fri, Apr 25, 2003 at 07:08:59PM -0700, Ed Sawicki typed:
> > > Just read an article in Linux Journal (May 2003) "Kernel Mode Linux" which 
> > > allows a patched kernel, to run user space programs in kernel space.  He 
> > > 
> > > Sounds safer, almost to good to be true. 
> > > http://web.yl.is.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp/~tosh/kml/
> > 
> > Wow. I can run all my daemons and applications in kernel
> > mode - then I'd have Windows.
> 
> Ed, where's your memory?  You wouldn't have Windows.  You'd have NetWare.
> That's what gave Novell the huge performance edge over MS.

Well, kidding aside, NetWare's significant performance edge
was achieved with numerous other techniques besides kernel
mode. Directory caching and (especially) hashing played a big
part when there were large numbers of files in directories
and/or the entire file system. In the early days of NetWare
and PC architecture, elevator seeking algorithms played a big
part as well though this eroded as disk seek times improved
and drives became so large that translation mode was needed,
which, of course, made elevator seeking difficult to do.

The NetWare kernel was always being profiled and
time-critical portions of code were tuned - often with
assembler. The NetWare file system, like those used with
Unix/Linux, didn't lose significant performance from
fragmentation.

NetWare with processes running in user space would still be
a lot faster than Windows.


 
-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

                       On the block bounded by

      **********************************************************

                             PRESENTATION

                         The Open Source Bill

                                  by
                              Ken Barber
                        <pundit at teleport.com>

      House Bill 2892, the Open Source Bill, is a bill in the
      Oregon State House of Representatives to encourage government
      agencies to examine Open Source solutions to their needs
      before purchasing proprietary software.  It also promotes
      the use of open data formats.  Ken Barber who wrote House
      Bill 2892 will be in Portland to discuss this bill, and the
      role of Open Source software in government.

      **********************************************************

          Agenda:

              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects
                   including the monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for
                   Education, etc.

From a23smith at yahoo.com  Mon Apr 28 13:30:03 2003
From: a23smith at yahoo.com (Alan Smith)
Date: Mon Apr 28 13:30:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Installing Windows 95 on a slave drive
Message-ID: <20030428202958.95530.qmail@web14203.mail.yahoo.com>

I have installed a Mobile Dock by inClose as a slave drive
(hdb1).  I also have two trays that fit into the Mobile
Dock with which I can switch the hard drive that is
inserted into the Mobile Dock.  In one of the trays I have
the hard drive I use to backup my master drive, so it has
an ext3 filesystem.  In the other tray I have the hard
drive on which I want to install Windows95.  I have been
trying to follow the instructions in the Debian GNU/Linux
Bible by Steve Hunger, the User's Guide by Progeny Linux
Systems, Inc. (sections 13.3.2 and 13.3.4) , the
Linux+Win9x+Grub HOWTO, and the man pages for update-grub,
mount and umount. Before I made changes my /etc/fstab file
included the following lines:
/dev/fd0          /floppy     auto           user,noauto   
     0     0
/dev/cdrom     /cdrom      iso9660     ro,user,noauto     0
    0

Then I added:
/dev/hdb1       /slave       auto           defaults       
       0     2

I also edited the /boot/grub/menu.lst file to include the
following stanzas:
title Windows 95
             map (hd0,0) (hd1,0)
             map (hd1,0) (hd0,0)
             root (hd1,0)
             makeactive
             chainloader +1

title Windows Boot Disk
             chainloader (cdrom)+1

title DOS Boot Disk
             map (hd0,0) (hd1,0)
             map (hd1,0) (hd0,0)
             chainloader (fd0)+1
Then I entered the update-grub command.  I included the
Windows Boot Disk stanza because the HOWTO states "If your
Windows install CD is bootable, you'll need to have a
'Windows boot disk' section which chainloads to whatever
your CDROM device is called.  There wasn't any example for
that stanza so I guessed how it should be written.  I don't
know if the CD on which I have Windows95 is bootable. 
Neither do I know if my CDROM drive is bootable.  I took
the drive from the computer I had been using for Windows95
and put it into the Mobile Dock, hoping that I would be
able to just select Windows 95 from the grub menu and start
Windows 95.  That didn't work.  Figuring that I might have
to reinstall Windows 95 I put the drive back into the old
computer to check if there was anything I really needed to
backup.  On startup I got a message that there was no boot
sector on the hard drive.  I guessed that Linux had
replaced the first sector and decided it was too late to
try to backup anything on the drive.  Then I put the drive
back into the Mobile Dock and used cfdisk to create just
one partition.  I did this partly because in the old
computer I had installed Western Digital's EZ Drive (due to
the limitations of the old bios) when I switched from a
500MB drive to a 3 GB drive.  I thought the EZ Drive
software might cause problems so I wanted to get rid of it.
 Another bit of history that might be relavant is that I
had installed a CDROM drive on the old computer.  I think
doing that made changes to my config.sys file.  Anyway, I
was able to boot Windows, and log onto the Internet, but I
couldn't read my documents, so I figured I had destroyed
the data with cfdisk. A lot of other stuff was missing so I
reinstalled Windows 95. Then I started getting the
message"The following file is missing or corrupted:
C:\MTM\MTMCDAI.SYS and "There is an error in your
config.sys file on line 6", followed by the lines:
C:|>rem----------------MTM ATAPI CD-ROM-------------
C:\>rem   by Windows setup - C:\WINDOWS\COMMAND\MSCDEX.EXE 
/D:MTMIDE01 /M:10
C:\>rem----------------MTM ATAPI CD-ROM-------------
I figured this was related to having installed the Mitsumi
CD-ROM drive on the old computer.   I had hoped that I
would be able to read my documents again if I installed my
Office 97 software again, but I started having problems
when I tried that.  Later I discovered that the Office 97
CD looked damaged, but I don't think that was the only
problem.  The main problem was that the computer would
freeze after a few minutes if I tried to install from a CD.
 I thought the solution might be to reinstall DOS 6.2,
because that had been necessary a few years ago when I
reformated the hard drive on the old comuter and
reinstalled Windows 95.  I was able to reinstall DOS 6.2
and Windows 3.1 from floppy disks, but I couldn't get
access to the CD-ROM drive.  I removed the lines in my
config.sys file that I think had been added when I
installed the Mitsumi drive in the old computer (the two
rem--------MTM ATAPI CD-ROM lines and the line that was
between them, but left the [COMMON] line that was between
them).  Now I can change from the A drive to the C drive
and look at the files and directories on those drives, but
I can't change to the D drive.  If I try to read my Windows
95 CD while in Debian it doesn't work.  I appologize for
such a lengthy post.  I'm not sure what information is
relevant.  I'm not even sure of the sequence of all the
steps or all of the details.  If you can help it will be
appreciated very much.  Thanks for at least reading this
far.
Alan

From michael at robinson-west.com  Mon Apr 28 14:46:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Mon Apr 28 14:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Installing Windows 95 on a slave drive
In-Reply-To: <20030428202958.95530.qmail@web14203.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030428202958.95530.qmail@web14203.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030428214112.21078.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Monday 28 April 2003 01:29 pm, you wrote:
>

I'm guessing that your Windows registry has links to software and/or DLL's
that aren't linking or aren't installed.  Did you reinstall 95 from scratch?
Is 95 on an extended partition or a primary?  Each primary partition changes
your drive lettering but extended partitions don't.  The other tool that might
be needed is xosl, see www.xosl.org.  This tool is important because it can
hide partitions for you and allow booting off an extended partition also.

95 has the unfortunate shortcoming of thinking it needs to be the first 
system on the first partition of the first hard drive.  I believe xosl can
fix this issue though ;-)

If your data is only on your hard disk then your probably toast.  Hint though,
fdisk doesn't destroy the data when it erases the partition table.  If you 
haven't put a different partition on the drive and proceeded to install
to it or even format, you can recreate the deleted partition and all
your data will be there.  It would not be unlikely that you would need a
boot disk to install dos back to your MBR with though.  

The confusing hard drive lettering is one of the reasons
why it's a good idea to use DVD-R, CD-R(w), or tapes for backup.  The other
option to play with is creating a server that is filled with raided together 
hard disks for the sole purpose of storing backups.  The latter generally has
a short shelf life and probably costs a lot, however, there's no media 
swapping and backups are fast.  The advantage of a server here is avoiding
weirdness on your desktop box.

My brother who was a 95 tech recommends service pack 3 or higher.
Whether your running Linux or Windows it's a good idea to get a true
ATAPI cdrom.  Hopefully, hardware manufacturers and OEM's will
realize the need for quality standards compliant equipment soon.
I've noticed that some of the newer cdroms have stronger lasers
or something.  I guess it's important not to scratch the printed side
although the non printed side has a plastic layer over the media and
can be polished if a cd won't read.  In old cdroms the lasers wear
out.

Hope this helps some.

A lot of people have said something about Windows dropping DLL's
too, don't know what this is about but it may be connected to the I
need to be the on the first drive... problem.

   --  Michael

From barryb at proaxis.com  Mon Apr 28 15:05:02 2003
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Mon Apr 28 15:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Installing Windows 95 on a slave drive
In-Reply-To: <20030428202958.95530.qmail@web14203.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030428202958.95530.qmail@web14203.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030428220439.GA27218@edge>

On Mon, Apr 28, 2003 at 01:29:58PM -0700, Alan Smith wrote:
> I have installed a Mobile Dock by inClose as a slave drive
> (hdb1).  I also have two trays that fit into the Mobile
> Dock with which I can switch the hard drive that is
> inserted into the Mobile Dock.  In one of the trays I have
> the hard drive I use to backup my master drive, so it has
> an ext3 filesystem.  In the other tray I have the hard
> drive on which I want to install Windows95.  

Here is one possible path that may work. Others
may have easier ways to solve your problem.

Make sure the system boots to linux.

Look in your boot logs in /var/log (or use dmesg) and 
make sure that the kernel is finding all of the hard
drives you have mentioned when it boots.

Take all of the drives out of the system except the one
you want to install Win95 on. Make it the only disk
on the primary ide connector.

Install Win95.

Make sure it boots. (Ok, forget this, win95 will
make sure it boots many! times during installation :)

Take the Win95 drive out, put your linux disk back in 
it's place and put your Win95 disk back where you 
want it.

Now make sure it boots to linux again and find out
where the Win95 disk is /hdb? /hdc? /hdd?

Then edit your grub.conf accordingly and boot 
to Win95.


Bill Barry

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Apr 28 16:15:03 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon Apr 28 16:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: HB 2892 Update
In-Reply-To: <200304281330.53835.pundit@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304281518020.10973-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Ken,

    I'm a bit frustrated at the moment.

    Several organizations like the AEA have been claiming to represent
thousands of companies who oppose this bill; whereas in fact only a few
of the members (if they actually exist) strongly oppose this bill and
some of the members may even support this bill.  As a result, I have
tryed to throw PLUG's support behind the bill.  True, this is a bit
strange.  PLUG doesn't generally take political stands, and PLUG hasn't
taken a vote to see where members (who ever that is) stand; but this
is an issue of interest to the Open Source community and there seems
to be general support on the mailing lists and in my discussions with
PLUG members for this bill.

    In any case, I attended the hearing on the bill a month ago, but
didn't get to testify because there wasn't time for all of us supporters.
I did send in written testimony, but I don't even know if it got into
the record - let alone if anyone actually read it.  I have also
written to a number of legislators and written to a couple papers
including the Oregonian.  I certainly haven't gotten much response.
In fact, the only response I have gotten has been nice response from
Melissa White in Rep. Kelly Wirth's office.  Altho Rep. Wirth has a
very different political philosophy than mine, she seems like a
very good legislator and I will probably vote for her in the future.
(I guess I've also talked with Andy Giegerich of the Portland
Tribute a couple times recently.)  But, other than this ...  NOTHING!!

    I guess I'm frustrated.  I don't think our legislators understand
this bill.  They don't understand how much money this bill could save
the state.  They don't understand that Oregon has a growing Open Source
industry which could benefit from this bill.

> States and in the European Union.

> run. Microsoft sometimes argues that organizations using
> Linux/OpenSource do not save money due to the cost of maintaining such
> software.  This may be true in the VERY SHORT run as employees learn to
> deploy Linux/OpenSource, but as skill in open source software increases
> among our very capable IT professionals in Oregon government, this cost
> associated with moving towards open source software will diminish.  The
> payoff of using software developed by communities for communities will
> be more than enough to offset this concern.
>

>

From michael at robinson-west.com  Mon Apr 28 17:47:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Mon Apr 28 17:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The bill for open source...
Message-ID: <20030429004227.21356.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

Could I suggest that the whole proprosed bill be put up on the plug web site.

It may be better to take this to an initiative since that is the best way to 
show broad voter support and it avoids having either party in the legislature
taking credit.  Right now, especially with Kulongoski's slam of Mannix at the 
end of the governors race where the margin of error was easily within
the margin of victory, I'd say there is going to be trouble with the 
political climate in Salem.  As far as lobbyists coming out against the bill, 
the only way to compete is to build not only a base of support but a base 
of support educated about the bill.  The best way to educate people about
the bill is to put the text of it up where all can see it.  My other 
suggestion is to look for industry proponents of this bill since it is going 
up against an industry opponent.  Noone right now wants to be seen as
hard on industry at a time when many who could invest in Oregon are
reluctant to do so and our economy is the weakest in the nation.  

Explain how support of open source by companies is good for those
companies in the long run.  It's interesting that government supported
the developement of Unix to ahieve a standard system for heterogeneous
environments in order to reduce training costs and increase productivity,
yet today there is a real question as to whether or not the option to maintain
an open standard for those latter mentioned reasons is indeed a viable one
anymore.  Why companies develop products that interoperate and how 
open source helps with this is what the legislature needs to
understand.  There also needs to be an argument that collaboration through
open source doesn't hurt companies the state depends on.  This can't win if 
it is simply a proprosal to save money when corporations come out and say 
that those savings are coming out of them.  At this time, the state 
desperately needs many corporations to remain here even if it means not 
giving open source a fair shake in the minds of many legislators.

Is open source a political issue?  If it is presented that way I doubt any 
bill will get through.  

    --  Michael

Subject: [PLUG] PCMCIA wireless card
Message-ID: <EX-20030428-203634-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

> 
> I came across a recomendation of Lucent wireless cards in the 
> archive from a
> year ago. I was wondering if anyone had used the Lucent Agere 
> ORiNOCO and how
> difficult it was to setup on Redhat.
> 
> thanks,
> Dan H.
> 
  I recently purchased an Orinoco Gold PCMCIA card for my RH 9.0 based laptop.  The card, hotplug, and Red Hat's network config tool all work flawlessly.  Hotplug even recognizes when I switch between PCMCIA Ethernet, WiFi, and modem.  It simply "does the right thing" (tm).  I'm very impressed...

  I bought the Orinoco Gold card to replace a Linksys card.  The Linksys was giving me trouble.  I was experiencing signal fade problems and software hangs in the kernel modules.  I haven't seen any problems with the Orinoco card.  The Orinoco card also has a jack for an external antenna.  Now, I can purchase a few more RX Db's if I need them.  

Steve D...

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Apr 28 21:19:01 2003

Date: Mon Apr 28 21:19:01 2003

On Mon, 28 Apr 2003, David Mandel wrote:
>
> Ken,
>
>     I'm a bit frustrated at the moment.
>
>     Several organizations like the AEA have been claiming to represent
> thousands of companies who oppose this bill; whereas in fact only a few
> of the members (if they actually exist) strongly oppose this bill and
> some of the members may even support this bill.  As a result, I have
> tryed to throw PLUG's support behind the bill.  True, this is a bit
> strange.  PLUG doesn't generally take political stands, and PLUG hasn't
> taken a vote to see where members (who ever that is) stand; but this
> is an issue of interest to the Open Source community and there seems
> to be general support on the mailing lists and in my discussions with
> PLUG members for this bill.
>
Unfortunately, the problem with PLUG supporting this legislation -- or
any legislation -- is that it could endanger our standing as a non-profit
organization. IANAL, but as I understand it, non-profit organizations
trade their right to express political opinions in return for exemption
from taxation. That was the problem that Bill Sizemore encountered --
well, that & being a sleezeball.

And to say that we can get around this because PLUG is not a formal
non-profit, then it renders PLUG about as convincing a body as any
imaginary group -- say, the Left-handed Bilingual Protologists Who
Worship marsha Brady as Their Goddess.

I have put a notice on our website concerning this house bill, but tried
to put it in a very neutral manner so that there is no suggestion of
PLUG expressing a partisan stance about it. Because as sure as the sun
will rise tomorrow, I know someone at Microsoft will learn about it, & use
that fact against us in pursuit of their goal of ``MS Windows everywhere,
& everyone rendering something to Microsoft."

If I'm being too timid about this, I'm willing to listen to persuasion.
I want this bill to pass -- but not at the cost of a greater Microsoft
victory.

Geoff

I personally think you are on the right track Geoff. 

Governments are designed to move slow. This is generally a good thing.
Slow moving governments are (theoretically) resistant to the
"public-whim-of-the-day". A short-term-blast of public opinion may
create a sudden, slight shift - but the next "whim" is just as likely
to cause a slight shift in the opposite direction.

If you want long-term, lasting results it requires gentle, constant pressure.

If you guys are in this for the long-haul, take your time and learn who the
players are, what influences them, what their biases are, what their vices
are, where they are strong and where they are weak.

I have had a couple "15 minutes of fame" when dealing with public agencies. 
It took several years worth of gentle, constant pressure for every 15 minutes
of progress. It's the nature of the game. 

Think chess, not hockey.

For those of you who are feeling frustrated by the slow progress, keep
in mind the cover of the Guide: "Don't Panic".

-Eric

The main reason I want to be able to use Windows 95 is for
using the Internet. Some websites, for example job
application websites, have online application forms that
can only be used with Word. Also, I don't have the plugins
installed on my Linux drive that are needed to view some of
the graphics. for example the Java plugins. Also, I want to
continue to learn about Windows because that is important
at my job. My boot sequence was a, c, scsi, so I decided to
try c,cdrom,a. That didn't make any difference, so I tried
adding the lines: map (hd0,0) (hd1,0) and map (hd1,0)
(hd0,0) to the Windows Boot Disk stanza. That didn't make
any difference either. I still got the error 23: Error
while parsing number. I thought maybe "cdrom" was the wrong
name to use in the chainloader line in menu.lst, so I
entered ls -l /dev/cdrom. I was expecting to find a
symbolic link to hdd, but I found a link to /dev/cdrom0,
which linked to /dev/scd0. I entered cat /dev/scd0 and got:
Attached scsi CD-ROM sr0 at scsi0, channel 0, id0, lun0,
sr0: scsi3-mmc drive: 32x/32x cd/rw xa/form2 cdda tray,
Uniform CD-ROM driver Revision: 3.12, cdrom: open failed,
cat: /dev/sdc0: no medium found. I don't understand whether
this means "cdrom" is the wrong name in the chainloader
line in menu.lst. I still can't access the cdrom from
either the floppy drive or the slave drive (hdb1). How
should I write the menu.lst so that I can install Windows
95 from my Windows 95 CD onto my slave drive?
Alan

Evidently what you need is a tool called xosl.
It has the ability to hide the partitions of all but the operating system 
you want to run so that you have the illusion of working with a 
common environment even though you may in reality be using a 
drive as C: which is the seventh partition on your slave.  I've 
also heard that xosl has the ability to support cdrom booting 
where the idea is to set your bios to boot to C only which will 
bring up xosl.  The site to check out is http://www.xosl.org.  This
tool allows moving Windows 98 to an extended partition for people
who say want to run two 98 systems or 98 and NT or 98 and dos...

From michael at robinson-west.com  Tue Apr 29 00:48:02 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)

Subject: [PLUG] Screwed up Mircosoft networking and samba...
Message-ID: <20030429074259.22977.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

Is samba being designed in such a way that it can be compatible 
with Windows without becoming a disgusting piece of code itself?  
If Microsoft doesn't know how to do cross subnet browse list 
collation properly what else is strange?  For moving away from 
Windows completely I wonder if there is a better alternative to 
samba and CIFS world that hopefully is both GPL and non tcp/ip 
based?  I'm admittedly confused by Microsoft's failure to implement 
NBDD and how a domain master broswer is a gross patch.  What 
kind of things is Microsoft trying to add to X.500 and DNS?  Is 
it just me or should Microsoft scrap their own networking and 
use a standard implementation that works?

Security wise is it best to distribute an lmhosts file to all machines 
in a domain group as opposed to implementing wins?  What is
the common approach to the name resolution end of samba?

I sure wish the networking code in Windows could flat out be
replaced.  That would be hard considering that Windows programs
aren't written to a full featured sufficiently flexible API capable of
hooking to any base, lower level protocol, placed under it.  
Imagine Windows 95/98/ME with an open source networking 
code replacement for the standard code Microsoft puts out with
common Windows applications working on top of this replacement.

Netware would probably be a good choice though I don't think there's 
any free program like SAMBA for a netware style network.  It sure would
be cool if an open netware project would start up.

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Apr 29 08:41:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Apr 29 08:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Win 98 ethernet
In-Reply-To: <1051628645.1165.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1051628645.1165.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1051630786.930.15.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2003-04-29 at 08:04, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> When setting my Win 98 hdd for use with my Ipcop firewall box, is
> NetBIOS the windows connection type of choice?

In the interest of smooth communication between linux and other OS, I'm
going to try to answer this.  NetBIOS is not a "connection type" like
TCP/IP or IPX, it is a communication protocol, more like ftp, or http. 
The difference is that M$ uses this proprietary protocol in a way that
hides it from the user.  Without NetBIOS, winblows boxes can't share
drives and printers or access Samba servers (this can be a good thing,
btw), however, the winblows box will still be able to access web pages
and other TCP/IP services.  You're firewall box won't care if NetBIOS is
enabled, or not; though some firewalls don't block the broadcasts that
NetBIOS does during WINS elections.  

Steve Gibson at grc.com has a lot more information.

HTH,

Derek Loree

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Apr 29 11:14:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Apr 29 11:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sound editors
References: <NFBBJJGLMCCHDEEELDPGKEGLCNAA.phil@alcsoftware.com>
Message-ID: <3EAEC0DF.5020103@pacifier.com>

Phil Schultz wrote:
> http://audacity.sourceforge.net/
> 
> Although I haven't had a chance to use this editor yet, I hope to use it for
> the same purpose.  It should actually be overkill for lecture cleanup.

I can vouch for audacity.  Get the latest build from the sourceforge site 
since what comes with your distro may be older and missing some recent good 
features.

You can now auto-scroll in realtime while recording.  There are no level 
meters, though.  If the recordings will be made while someone is present to 
bump up the recording level during the Q&A, that can be done on the fly. 
Might want to use a hardware-based automixer if recordings are un-maned.

Audacity will export to wav, mp3 and ogg.  The later two required external 
libraries.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

On Tuesday 29 April 2003 04:44 pm, you wrote:

I finally got it working.  The suggestion I got earlier doesn't
work but I use the following in globals and created a profile share...

under globals I do:

     logon home = //%L/profile

and my profile share is as follows:

     [profile]
     path = /home/profile/%U/%m
     read only = No
     browseable = No
     guest ok = yes

I create a directory under home called profiles and create a directory for 
each user under it.  These user directories are set, user and group,
to match the user's home directories.  Under the user directories I
create I created a directory named after the computer they are going
to log in on.  Works like a charm, the profile for machine A ends up
under /home/profile/someuser/A.

Maybe the earlier suggestion is for NT or something.

Are you not using dhcp at home?  Either way, how about creating a small 
script (or X launcher) for both kinds of connections?

from_road.sh
#!/bin/sh
# I'm on the road
/usr/bin/ssh -f me at myisp.com xterm


from_home.sh
#!/bin/sh
#I'm home
/usr/bin/ssh -f mylan xterm

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Apr 29 21:11:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Apr 29 21:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting ssh working again
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304291931530.3136-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304291931530.3136-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86llxslj9s.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   When I'm out of the office I want to dial into my shell
Rich> account at my ISP then ssh into my network. But, when I'm here
Rich> in the office with the notebook connected to the ethernet lan, I
Rich> want to use the internal IP addresses.

Rich>   Where are these addresses stored, and do I need to change them
Rich> manually depending on location?

In the "connecting from" machine, look in ~/.ssh/known_hosts.  You'll
see:

  connecting-to-hostname,ip ssh-rsa AAAHURKINGKEY...

Just duplicate the line and edit the ip for the duplicate (ie have one
for the external address and one for the internal address), and I
think it'll work for you.

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Apr 30 07:11:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Apr 30 07:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getting ssh working again
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304300614140.4891-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304300614140.4891-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1051711815.907.11.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2003-04-30 at 06:18, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 29 Apr 2003, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> > In the "connecting from" machine, look in ~/.ssh/known_hosts.  You'll
> > see:
>  ... 
> > Just duplicate the line and edit the ip for the duplicate (ie have one
> > for the external address and one for the internal address), and I
> > think it'll work for you.
> 
>   Thanks, Russell. I tried this but without success. I made two copies of
> the key, on one I changed the IP address to the external IP address and on
> the other I changed it to the hostname (not the FQDN). No go.
> 
>   In /etc/hosts.allow the last set of directives are:
> 
> sshd: .spiritone.com
> sshd: .appl-ecosys.com
> 
>   Could the order be why ssh looks for the external IP address? I obviously
> don't fully understand just how ssh is attempting to contact the host.
> 
This is describing a name resolution problem, not an ssh problem.  You
need to find out how the name is being resolved to an address.  Is there
an entry in /etc/hosts?  Or is there a DNS server somewhere that is
doing the resolving.  The easiest fix I can think of is to have two
names listed in hosts, one for internal access, one for external access;

servername external.ip.address
servername2 internal.ip.address

Then when your outside the office, you would "ssh servername" and when
you are inside the office, you would "ssh servername2".

If you need to use the same name to access the server, then you will
need two hosts files, which will then need to be rotated into /etc/
depending on if your in the office or out.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

setup any mail sending server agent.

As I'm trying to now add this I have heard of a few options.  One is pop
first then allow from that IP smtp services for some amount of time.  I
also think there is authenicated smtp.

Can someone point me in a direction to look for a way to configure my box
to somehow authenicate users then allow them to send email via my server?

Thanks for the help.  I hope you all enjoyed the lightening storm last
night.  I did.

Josh

> As I'm trying to now add this I have heard of a few options.  One is
> pop first then allow from that IP smtp services for some amount of
> time.  I also think there is authenicated smtp.

POP-before-SMTP is a huge kludge. Just say no.

Authenticated SMTP is the way to go. I know sendmail and postfix both 
support it; I don't know about exim or qmail.

> Can someone point me in a direction to look for a way to configure
> my box to somehow authenicate users then allow them to send email
> via my server?

It all depends on what mail server you're running: sendmail? postfix? 
Let us know, then our advice will be more useful.

Josh,

  Postfix supports pop-before-smtp. There have been several threads on this
on the postfix-users mail list. I've not read any of the messages, but the
postfix Web site probably has details. Or the mail list archives.

  This MTA is very easy to set up and it is a drop-in replacement for
sendmail.

From kaile at centerspan.com  Wed Apr 30 09:32:02 2003
From: kaile at centerspan.com (Kaile Riser)
Date: Wed Apr 30 09:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Switching from Linux ?
Message-ID: <B17BD2D33A303B41844F115DF0104AC4855DEB@CSCCMAIL.tmhq.centerspan.com>

In general, yes... However, a good friend of mine runs jails that he
creates virtual filesystems for... He makes an image of a fresh jail,
starts it up, configures it how he wants, runs it normally, and
periodically saves it back to the image file. He also runs read-only
images so that when he shuts down the jail, it goes back to the original
configuration. It's really flexible.

Kaile

On May 1st OSU and ACM are hosting a colloquium speaker from the Linux
Technology Center at IBM.  This talk is open to the community and any
students that wish to attend.

http://eecs.oregonstate.edu/graduate/colloquium/

What: Process Scheduling in Linux: Still Room for Improvement
When: May 1
      3:30 - 4:30 pm
Where: 	Owen 102
	Oregon State University
	Corvallis, OR
Who: Rick Lindsley
     Software Engineer
     Linux Technology Center
     IBM


Biography

Rick Lindsley is a software engineer with 20 years experience in Unix and
Linux. He's worked on everything from Berkeley 4.2 and 4.3 releases to
Solaris to, now, Linux. He spent several years at Tektronix in Beaverton,
Oregon, then gained significant experience with multi-processor machines
while working for Sequent Computer Systems for nine years. When Sequent
was purchased by IBM in 1999, he stayed on board and joined IBM's Linux
team. He's currently working in the Linux Technology Center for IBM in
Beaverton Oregon. Since then he's given talks at universities, national
laboratories, and Linux user groups on topics ranging from what it's like
to work for IBM, to issues with SMP locking, to the current state of the
Linux kernel. His recent focus is on I/O statistics gathering and process
scheduling improvements.





From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Wed Apr 30 11:42:02 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Wed Apr 30 11:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying ASCII codes in a text file
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304301100420.8744-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304301100420.8744-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030430184046.GF8813@dalsemi.com>

On Wed, Apr 30, 2003 at 11:04:38AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   What tool(s) are available to me that identify blocked characters in an
> ASCII text file?
> 
>   For example, I printed a Web page then ran the .ps file through pstotext.
> When I look at the resulting .txt file with the pager, less, I see "<AD>"
> highlighted where a '-' should be. The same file in the editor, joe, shows a
> white-blocked '-' at the same character locations.
> 
>   I'd like to do a global search-and-replace for these in the file (and I
> get other characters in other files, too) but I don't know how to specify
> them.
> 
> Any ideas?

In vim, you'd copy the character into a buffer, then go into command history
editing so that you could paste the buffer onto the command line.

I'm guessing that in emacs you can do something similar, and don't know
enough about joe to say one way or the other.

In less, <AD> probably means hexadecimal character AD.  If your editor
supports 8 bit characters, just figure out how to type it in and there
you go.

Colin

p.s. You could also build a perl/sed/awk/python/shell script that does
the transliteration for you. That way, as you learn about new characters
that you don't like, you can just extend your filter to fix them, too.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Apr 30 14:41:01 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed Apr 30 14:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying ASCII codes in a text file 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 30 Apr 2003 13:26:52 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0304301324340.9098-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200304302140.h3ULeVm16288@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> On Wed, 30 Apr 2003, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > Here's an alias I use for checking the bytes in a file.
> > 
> > alias hd='od -A x -t x1z'
>  
> galen,
> 
>   Reading the man page I almost understand the syntax; I read that x is
> supposed to have a [SIZE] specified and -A should have something, too.
> Regardless, if I run this, does it facilitate my changing of the hex chars
> to decimal chars? That's the end point I'd like to reach.
> 

No, not directly.  It's just a way to confirm the value of the bytes in
a file without getting tripped up by fonts and such.  Don't worry about 
-A.  That's just the offset within the file.  I'm content with the default
size when printing the offset.  I specify a size of one for the data
in order to avoid big/little endian issues.

If you need to
change all occurrences of a character to a different value, you could use
od to confirm the value of the character, then tr to make the change.
If you tell od to output octal, it will make using tr easier.  Change
the -t argument from x1z to o1z.  When using tr, don't forget to use
quotes around the arguments to prevent the shell from messing things up.

galen

be aware of core errata and things like that.

In Linux (2.4.20), it properly identifies the CPU as follows:

processor       : 0
vendor_id       : GenuineIntel
cpu family      : 15
model           : 2
model name      : Intel(R) Pentium(R) 4 CPU 2.26GHz
stepping        : 4
cpu MHz         : 2265.641
cache size      : 512 KB

Is there any way to go from this info (family 15, model 2, stepping 4) to
something like the Intel sSpec or core stepping that Intel uses on their
website?  Or is there another program that will read and decode the 
CPUID info?

From amunk at pdx.edu  Wed Apr 30 16:50:02 2003
From: amunk at pdx.edu (Andrew Munkres)

Subject: [PLUG] Fetchmail from IMAP
In-Reply-To: <20030430222257.GA25694@boora.com>

Michael Montagne writes:
 > How do you specify an IMAP folder for fetchmail to retrieve from?  I'm

Here's a .fetchmailrc recipe:
	poll myserver with proto IMAP
	    user 'myuser' there with password 'password' is 'mylocaluser' here
	    folder blurfle

Also, there's a Tk program called "fetchmailconf" for writing .fetchmailrc.

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Wed Apr 30 22:23:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Apr 30 22:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Debian de-deselct
In-Reply-To: <20030430181343.GA24082@boora.com>
References: <20030430181343.GA24082@boora.com>
Message-ID: <1051766502.555.19.camel@zadie>

On Wed, 2003-04-30 at 14:13, Michael Montagne wrote:
> I got myself into that nasty ground where I need to abort an apt-get
> install, it wants to upgrade glibc and I'm not ready for that.  So now,
> of course apt-get insists I resolve all my issues with uninstalled
> packages.  I know synaptic will let you unselect stuff.  But it is not
> installed.  I'm a little leery of dselect.  How else can I make apt
> forget about those packages?
> 

it kinda depends on where you were in the install process. Sometimes
it's a pain in the ass, unfortunately. The best suggestion I can give
you (other than aptitude, which someone else suggested), is

dpkg --configure -a

which can sometimes solve your problems for you.

apt-get -f install

also can fix stuff. But it may just demand you upgrade glib. I had this
problem the other day when debian unstable updated libstdc++ and it
broke EVERYTHING (it was astonishing just how much stuff was broken, and
how apt-get refused to remove mozilla-mailnews because it said it was
too broken to remove, please reinstall, but reinstall just broke).

Eventually, I have to admit, I had to force a remove and then reinstall
the stuff I needed from stable. Here's how you can force a remove:

dpkg --force-all --remove <pkg>

BE VERY CAREFUL WITH THAT. --force-all is VERY dangerous. It's better to
try it without the --force-all and see what errors there are, and see if
you can come up with another way around it before going with
--force-all.

It's really useful, I discovered, to have stable, testing, and unstable
in your sources.list and then have the following line in apt.conf:

APT::Get::Default-Release "testing";

(or whatever your default release is)

Because then, if you want to install something from stable, or unstable,
you just do this:

apt-get install package/unstable		or
apt-get install package/stable

dpkg is your friend. dpkg-reconfigure is really your friend. =)

Jeff
